title: Thumping sound in right ear in Sync with heartbeat?
content: I have had this thumping in my right ear in sync with my pulse for some time now. It ONLY come when I exercise. If I am just watching tv or walking around it is not there. It is only in my right ear. I went to a doctor and they did a scan on my right carotid artery because there was a lump near it (found out it was a swollen lymph node(its smaller now)). It came back fine. I also had an ECHO of my heart and a stress test. Both came back fine. Now I am wondering. Is it possible the the left artery carotid is blocked? Causing more blood to flow through my right carotid artery which in turn is making that noise? Or would it be making that noise in my left ear if it was the case because of the blood flowing past a blocked section?  Basically my question is. If I hear a thumping in my right ear when I exercise would it be from my right carotid artery or my left if something was wrong?  P.S (I have TMJ and i notice when this happens if I move my jaw forward the noise stops)

author: Dr.M.jagesh kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1303 Joined: Mon Aug 03, 2009 7:24 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Thumping sound in right ear in Sync with heartbeat?
content: Hello,Sometimes a high jugular vein bulb at the level of tympanic membrane can cause a single sided bruit, which is not felt by the examiners.Turning the head to the symptomatic side would often reduce the symptom.The bruit increases in intensity when cardiac output increases,as for example,in exercise.This condition is essentially benign.Do consult your doctor. Best wishes.

author: boots  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Jul 29, 2010 1:28 pm Gender: Female
title: Chronic Sinus Infection Solutions
content: Hi, I am wondering what you can suggest for treatment of chronic sinus infection.  I have never had one before (I am in my 50s) and am generally in good health with some "non-allergic rhinitis", but at the end of May I came down with a sudden pneumonia.  They now think this was from H influenzae (sp?), which was cultured much later (first culture had been lost).  I did two rounds of Amoxicillin 10 days each, then off antibiotics one week, and then 20 solid days of Augmentin twice daily.  Each time, the antibiotics made me feel much better but when they ended, the coughing and congestion came back.  I do feel stronger and no longer have a fever since the first few weeks, and this last time I didn't get the sore throat back.  Chest Xray followup after 1 mo. was negative, but each time the antibiotics ended I have started coughing up some yellow stuff again.  The right sinus seems fairly blocked.  My problem is conflicting advice and information.  My primary doctor now says it is only "post-infection inflammation" and put me on a regimen of daily Claritin, Sudafed and frequent sinus cleansing with saltwater solution. An ENT specialist has felt that it's just a question of the right antibiotic, however, I have recently developed allergies (rash) with a couple including Zithromax and Doxycycline (sp?).  I also once got C-dif after taking Cipro for a stomach infection, so a lot of things are ruled out.  I also use steam inhalation, acupuncture, and have even tried chiropractic a couple of times but after 9 weeks (now one week again without antibiotics), I still have the coughing and congestion and am not sleeping enough.  I am also somewhat depressed and anxious after this long haul, not able to exercise, work completely full-time, and do lots of things.  Do you have any suggestions? I don't find the Claritin helps much and I can do Sudafed but it makes me cough a lot, and both seem to make me feel a little weird and nervous.  My doctor has scared me by saying I could get asthma or get the pneumonia back if I don't follow his regime (he is new to me).    Thanks.
posted_time: Post  by boots » Thu Jul 29, 2010 1:51 pm

author: Dr.M.jagesh kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1303 Joined: Mon Aug 03, 2009 7:24 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Chronic Sinus Infection Solutions
content: Hello,Recently Allergic Fungal Sinusitis is getting recognized as one of the forms of chronic sinusitis.This is due to an allergy to environmental fungi. Thick mucin and fungal components develop in the sinus.This occurs in the immunocompetent,atopics ie with family history of allergy.  .Approximately 5% with chronic sinusitis may fall in this category of AFS.Presentation is similar to bacterial types.Severe types present with proptosis.One characteristic is production of semisolid.thick mucus from the nose.Coronal CT scans,MRI are useful in distinction from the commoner bacterial types.RAST skin response are done. Fungal-specific IgE is found elevated along with total igE.Surgery, Corticosteroids,and immuno therapy are the therapy modes. Diagnostic criteria have been suggested by Bent and Kuhn and include  (1) type I hypersensitivity confirmed by history, skin tests, or serology; (2) eosinophilic mucus without fungal invasion of sinus tissue;  (3) positive fungal stains of sinus contents removed during surgery. This is more common in adolescent and young adults. Though I am not giving this as a  diagnosis in your condition it is worthwhile to think of this as a differential diagnosis, in cases which are challenging in undiagnosed chronic sinusitis. Best wishes.

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Chronic Sinus Infection Solutions
content: Hi, I can well understand your dilemma.You seem to be responding to only one drug (sudafed-that is, pseudoephedrine hydrochloride+ paracetamol) alone, and for all the other drugs, you are either developing some kind of a side effect or the other, or not responding at all. You seem to imply that your doctor has recommended that you should continue taking sudafed.   As you may well be aware, sale of formulations containing pseudoephedrine hydrochloride (as well as ephedrine) are very tightly regulated in many countries although they may be available OTC.  These measures have been put into place because, pseudoephedrine (and ephedrine) in substancial quantities were being diverted to the manufacture of methamphetamine ("meth"), a recreational drug. Also, non-medicinal use has caused concern about potential for abuse. I has been used for its ephedra-like effects for causing weight loss,and by atheletes to get 'pumped-up' prior to an event.There is a potential for unintentional overdose as well.   I am not aware of your country of residence.You have indicated that you are taking upto 4 tablets/day.  If you are taking the formulation containing 60 mg/tablet, then it will work out to 240 mg/day(thus, 7.2 Grams/month).    In the USA, pseudoephedrine is classified under the Schedule Listed Chemicals (SLC). Combat Methamphetamine Epidemic Act of 2005, has reduced the Federal pertransaction sales limit (daily sales limit)from 9 grams to 3.6 grams and  has restricted monthly sales to no more than 9.0 grams per purchaser.For procurement via Mail-service pharmacy, a 7.5 gram per 30-day sales limit. In the UK,formulation containing 60 mg of pseudoephedrine hydrochloride per tablet is available in packs of 12. Sale is preceded by a series of questions from the pharmacist to determine if it is safe.  In Australia,  up to 60 mg of pseudoephedrine/tablet is available OTC subject to a pharmacist matching the purchaser's identity to a computerized database to determine if the purchase history is consistent with personal use. In Canada, pseudoephedrine hydrochloride is available as a 120mg "12 hour time release" capsule.  Whether oral pseudoephedrine hydrochloride is really effective as a nasal decongestant is still a matter of debate. Under these circumstances, as in your case, it may become increasingly difficult and cumbersome to purchase this medication. You should discuss with your doctor regarding alternatives such as saline nasal drops/sprays, or phenylephrine nasal drops. Good luck!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Ear problems after a airplane flight
content: Hi, The Eustachian tubes which connect the middle ear cavities with the nasopharynx have two functions. The primary function of the eustachian tube is as a pressure-equalizing valve for the middle ear.  The middle ear space is filled with air, and this air needs to maintain pressure equal to the “outside” air pressure(atmospheric pressure).  The Eustachian tube is normally in a closed position.  Its opening is controlled by certain small muscles. It needs to open periodically to equalize the pressure to that of the atmosphere. Thus, it allows air into the middle ear to replace air that has been absorbed by the middle ear lining (mucous membrane), or to equalize pressure changes occurring during changes in the altitude.  Under normal circumstances, the Eustachian tube opens momentarily in response to swallowing or yawning.  Anything that interferes with this periodic opening and closing may result in a negative pressure in the middle ear as a result of which, the eardrum gets “sucked inward” and becomes retracted.  In an adult, this is usually accompanied by some discomfort, such as fullness or pressure in the ear (ear popping), and may result in a mild hearing loss.  This type of temporary eustachian tube dysfuntion is commonly experienced during altitude changes during air travel, while climbing mountains or during scuba diving. Upper respiratory infections, allergies or narrow eustachian tubes may predispose to this dysfunction.  There are many options available to treat a poorly functioning Eustachian tubes.  Nasal steroid sprays are frequently tried, and in adults nasal and oral decongestants may be of help.  If an infection is thought to be present, then antibiotic therapy is appropriate.  If allergies are thought to be contributing to the Eustachian tube dysfunction, allergy testing and treatment may be indicated.  When Eustachian tube dysfunction persists despite maximal medical therapy, surgical procedures may be indicated.  Ventilation tube placement into the eardrum is indicated for persistent or frequently recurrent ear infections. Good luck!

title: orange tongue and swollen tonsil
content: Hi, About a month ago I got a basic flu. Had a fever for a night then had nasal congestion, sore throat. Just the usual. But a week afterwards I noticed my tongue turned yellow. So I told the doctor and he ordered me to take Nystatin and I took about 2/3rds ofit but it was clearly doing nothing. One night I used a flashlight to look inside my mouth clearly and realized that my left tonsil was really swollen. So I went to an ENT. He had me take a CBC, tongue culture and throat culture. All the results came back normal. Lymphocites were .3 below the normal range. Both tongue and throat cultures came back negative. Both my GP and ENT say not to worry but I am worried they are not putting 2 + 2 together. I still have a brownish orangish tongue, still a swollen left tonsil, and my throat hurts on and off. Sometimes just when I eat and sometimes when I swallow. But it isnt consisten. And I still have some mild nasal congestion and sneeze a few times a day. The thing that bothers me the most is the orangis color tongue as it is so odd. So any help I would really appreciate it. Many thanks :)

author: Dr.M.jagesh kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1303 Joined: Mon Aug 03, 2009 7:24 am Gender: Male
title: Re: orange tongue and swollen tonsil
content: Hello,Your condition fits in with Lingua villosa.This can appear as black,brown,pink or other variety of hues on the tongue.This is related to use of broad spectrum antibiotics,poor oral hygiene,smoking,heavy coffee drinking etc.This is caused by elongation of filiform papillae on the back of the tongue.Yeast infections can also be present. Most cases respond to improvement in dental hygiene.Commercially available tongue scrappers do help.Bcomplex deficiencies need to be corrected. Best wishes.

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Blisters or sores in just my throat
content: Hi, There could be a number of differential diagnoses for the type of lesions that you describe.  Although the site of the lesions is suggestive of  Angina bullosa hemorrhagica (ABH), it is probably not the case, as they are not hemorrhagic.  Molluscum contagiosum is a benign tumor-like viral disease often seen in children. In adults it is sexually transmitted and frequently associated to HIV infection. Molluscum contagiosum virus, has two subtypes:  - MCV-1 and  - MCV-2.  Lesions caused by both subtypes are indistinguishable.  MCV-1 is very frequent and has a worldwide distribution, while MCV-2 occurs mainly in HIV male patients.  Oral lesions are rare and have been reported in HIV patients. They are very similar to the cutaneous lesions. They present as solitary to several 1-3 mm dome-shaped papules with a central umbilication (giant lesions, sometimes > 1cm, are exceptional). The tends to mainly affect the lips, but the buccal mucosa and tongue may also be occasionally affected.  Oral lesions are associated to HIV infection, decreased number and impaired function of T cells but, there are some reports on immunocompetent patients as well. Therefore, if one is immunocompetent, the chances of such lesions being molluscum contagiosum are extremely small indeed.  Pemphigus is a rare condition belonging to a group of blistering autoimmune diseases.There are several types of pemphigus, one of which is the paraneoplastic pemphigus (PNP). This disorder occurs as a complication of cancer, usually lymphoma and Castleman's disease. It may precede the diagnosis of the tumor. Painful sores appear on the mouth, lips, and the esophagus.This also may not fit the description in your case.  So, as a definitive diagnosis needs a thorough visualization of the morphology of the lesions, you must consult you doctor for the same. Good luck!

author: Dr.M.jagesh kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1303 Joined: Mon Aug 03, 2009 7:24 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Sudden hearing loss from an impact
content: Hello Tony,Hope you have recovered from the transient hearing loss and tinnitus.The commonest cause is age related, the next being exposure to recreational and occupational noise.The cause of this hearing loss is due to impact on the ciliary cells of the inner ear.High impact blasts like gunshot,jet takeoff,rock music all are of high decibels and can cause serious damage if not protected.One should remember that lesser decibels for a prolonged period also may result in damage even though we may find it bearable a sound.Temporary threshold shifts are common in persons exposed to excessive noise, and they represent transient hair cell dysfunction.Assuming that it is of this type you would recover with out any sequelae.However repeated such injuries could lead to progressive hearing loss culminating in  permanent loss of hearing. So do make sure that you protect your ears from this eminently preventable condition.If you have any doubt you can get an audiometry done to make sure. Best wishes.

author: Dr.M.jagesh kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1303 Joined: Mon Aug 03, 2009 7:24 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Both ears ring constantly
content: Hello,Tinnitus is a common problem associated with ageing.This is not necessarily due to ageing process, but due to the number of times we get exposed to loud noise either at work,or at relaxing moments when music is full blast on!Right from wax in the ext ear canal,middle ear infections to the damage to the microscopic nerve endings of the inner ear,all can result in tinnitus.Most cases resolve but the severe types and rarer causes(Acoustic tumor) do cause concern.A CT scan may be indicated in doubtful cases. While there is no specific treatment prevention is most important.Keep ear plugs handy and use them when high decibel noise is being heard.Decrease salt intake, caffeine and nicotine. Best wishes.

author: Dr.M.jagesh kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1303 Joined: Mon Aug 03, 2009 7:24 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Vertigo and Sinus Pressure
content: Hello,The presence of an aura ie hot flashes just before an attack of vertigo makes one think of Migraine Associated Vertigo (MAV).This could occur even in the absence of headache commonly associated with migraines.In these cases sensory amplification is common(Hyperacusis).When examined during attack there would be minimal or no spontaneous nystagmus(if present would be vertical)This may be a differentiating point.Vertigo can last for much longer time than BPPV. Do get your self examined and may be this condition be thought as a differential diagnosis. Best wishes.

I want to try to keep one of the kittens if possible but my father is  highly allergic and the allergy test showed that he has a level 4 allergy for cats. posted_time: Post  by riotgurl20 » Mon Aug 16, 2010 1:58 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Allergies to cats
content: Hello, Cats are one of the most common animal allergies and you cannot depend on your father becoming immune.  Studies have indicated that having pets as a child decreases your risk of allergies and asthma as an adult, but I have not seen such information on adults.  You cannot depend on it and unless your father underwent allergy treatment for desensitization of particular allergies, it is a risk.  It depends to a large degree on just how allergic the person is.  Some people are able to tolerate a pet in spite of allergies with compulsive vacuuming of furniture, carpets (even the cat!) and keeping the cat confined to certain areas of the house - nowhere near the sleeping area.  It's a chance he would have to take if you choose to do this.  Then you must consider how disappointing it would be if you had to get rid of the cat after having it as a pet for a time.  I know this is difficult for you.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Tue Aug 24, 2010 5:16 pm

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Cyst in flesh part of ear
content: Hi, Firstly, the part of the external ear that you are referring to is known as the 'lobule' of the ear.  Have your ears been pierced in the past? If in the affirmative, an implantation dermoid is possible.This arises out of the parts of skin that are carried underneath the skin in the process of piercing.Usually single. But you describe a cluster, which makes it less likely. Other posssibilities are an auricular appendage that arises on the lobule - some of which can be sessile.Again a cluster of appendages may be rare.  Neuromas of the lobule have been described(unilateral/bilateral).They can be multiple.This may need to be ruled out in your case. Best wishes!
posted_time: Post  by Dr.M.Aroon kamath » Sun Nov 22, 2009 7:35 pm

content: Hi,  As i have already explained in the reply to the preceding post, your problem also could be an implantation dermoid (also known as an Post-traumatic epidermal inclusion cyst). author: Dr.M.jagesh kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1303 Joined: Mon Aug 03, 2009 7:24 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Cyst in flesh part of ear
content: Helo,Apart from what Dr.Kamath has mentioned, the other aspect of it would be a keloidal tendency.More common on the black skin one can not predict who would develop a keloid.But then one would expect the keloid to be visible on the superficial skin.So the likelyhood of implantation dermoid is more likely. The only thing that can be done apart from surgery is preventive aspects.If you have such a tendency best is to avoid any body piercings. Intralesional steroids.lasers,cryotherapy and silicone sheets are other modalities if it would be keloid.Implantation dermoids would be treated by surgery. Best wishes.

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Hearing increasingly sensitive, drving me crazy!
content: Hi, Noise, is a well known environmental stressor, has clear health effects (in causing hearing loss) but, other health effects are less understood.   Noise exposure has been known to lead to minor emotional symptoms.There are well documented associations between noise exposure and sleep disturbance, changes in performance,  and emotional reactions notably, annoyance. Annoyance can be associated with both environmental noise levels and psychological /psychiatric disorders(notably depression).   It is unclear whether noise sensitivity is simply secondary to an underlying psychiatric disorder or indeed is a risk factor for psychiatric disorder.  Some workers have observed that noise-sensitive people seem to concentrate on more  noises, discriminate more between noises, find noises more threatening and out of their control, and react to, and adapt to noises more slowly than less noise sensitive people.( http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1488472 ).  I hope you will find this information useful. Good luck!
posted_time: Post  by Dr.M.Aroon kamath » Sun Jun 27, 2010 12:10 pm

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Broken nose and black eyes
content: Hi, 'Black eye', usually follows facial or head trauma.It is due to spread of blood in the loose tissue spaces in the eyelids and around the eyes. Although called 'black' eyes, the color may vary(black and blue or purple).Usually appears within 24 hours of injury.Mostly they are caused by minor injuries and spontaneously resolve in a week's time. In some cases, associated eyeball injuries may co-exist and must be excluded.It is advisable that anyone with black eyes should consult their doctor to confirm that it is indeed a minor injury.  Best wishes!

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Left Ear feels clogged
content: Hello -  Your problem is a really common one, and is usually related to a sinus problem or allergy. The eustachian tube on the affected side is getting air trapped inside, which means the tube is pressed upon or swollen off and on. There is such a network of interconnected chambers, passages, etc., in this area that it's often difficult to visualize it, especially since it can be intermittent. Ideally you would go in to be seen when the problem is actually happening, but that's almost impossible to arrange.   The nasal spray seems to have worked up to a point, but it also may be working against you. If it is used for more than three days in a row, you run a risk of causing a rebound effect, wherein the tiny blood vessels stay engorged and the problem becomes more severe or even constant.   You should probably be put on a course of steroids to reduce the inflammation and congestion, and hopefully that will give the root cause time to correct itself. It's not a serious problem, but it can be awfully distracting.  I hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you.
posted_time: Post  by John Kenyon, CNA » Mon Oct 13, 2008 9:53 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Left Ear feels clogged
content: For FoxHellion: While one of the potential side-effects of Zithromax is hearing loss, this is a nerve effect and not one caused by clogging of the eustachian tubes. You say you took "a Zithromax" so I'm assuming you took only one, perhaps one you had left or one given you by someone else? One might have helped, but the failure to take a full course of an antibiotic can often be a brief improvement followed by worsening of symptoms. The ear clogging is likely due to drainage and irritation caused by the original infection. It could have been a rebound effect due to only having taken the one antibiotic tablet, or it may have happened anyway, given the type of upper respiratory infection (this is a really common and annoying feature of them); it also could have been caused by your having stopped using the nasal sprays, since the ears, nose and throat are all directly connected at the inner end of the two eustachian tubes.   Hopefully this is getting better now. It can sometimes take a while to resolve, but it almost always does. Again, if it doesn't, a visit to an ENT specialist would be the best way to get it resolved. Good luck to you!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Persistent voice loss
content: Hi, it is possible that you may have what are called "vocal nodules".These are relatively small nodules that form symmetrically on the vocal folds in the Voice box(larynx). They interfere with production of a normal speech.They may cause intermittent voice loss, hoarseness and also reduce the range of one's voice.  Mostly occur in persons who abuse voice in some way... such as, [excessive yelling, excessive coughing,having to talk loudly in an environment where the background noise levels are very high etc].Women are more likely to be affected than men.   Diagnosis is fairly straightforward.Treatment generally involves voice rehabilitation and rarely surgical removal may be needed. Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Throat abscess from smoking marijuana
content: Hi, Pot smokers also may be IV drug users. IV drug users are at a high risk for numerous serious infections because of their often poor psychosocial conditions, unpredictable immune status, and often less than optimal hygiene(including oral hygiene) and nutritional status.  Poor orodental hygiene is commonly found, risk factors being... - smoking regular cigarettes as  well as pot and - dryness of mouth induced by marihuana. Poor orodental hygiene leads to dento-gingival sepsis (un-protected oral sex also is known to increase the risk). This, in the background of possibly reduced immunity can lead to  - severe disseminated bacterial or often fungal infections including brain abscesses.  The timeline for this scenario can be(for the sake of your story) quite flexible (acute, sub-acute or chronic), depending on the organism, its virulence and the victim's immune status).  If one wants an acute to sub-acute scenario, one could use this line... Fungal spores(mold spores), are a normal component of Marijuana. They are present in Marijuana especially when damp. Smoking damp marijuana could cause fungal infections in many body locations including the brain.   If a very acute scenario is desired(for the story), one could start from gingivo-dental infections........ on to deep oral or oropharyngeal sepsis(higher risk in pot smokers)....."Lemierre´s Syndrome" which is characterized by thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein  believed to be due to direct extension from  deep oral or oropharyngeal sepsis. If  untreated, it may progress to systemic septic embolization with the most frequently affected organ being the lungs. Osteomyelitis, hepatic abscess, renal failure, and septic arthritis can result.The most common organism isolated is a gram-negative obligate anaerobe, 'Fusobacterium necrophorum'.  One other choice for an acute scenario would be infective endocarditis(especially if there is associated IV drug abuse).  Best wishes for your upcoming short story!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Hoarse Voice For Two Weeks
content: Hi,  Many medications are said to have an adverse effect on the voice.Some of which are.... - certain diuretics,  - decongestants(ex, Pseudoephedrine),   - antihistamines,  - muscle relaxants, - medications for Parkinson’s disease, - asthma medications (including inhaled steroids), - high doses of Vitamin C,,  - Antihypertensive drugs(calcium channel blockers,betablockers,    angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitors),  - estrogen replacement therapy,  - oral contraceptives (can  cause vocal cord edema), &  - Adderall   Many of them are said to cause hoarseness of voice by producing what is popularly known as "vocal cord dryness". Dry vocal cords may be more prone to injuries and result in vocal nodules nodules that can cause hoarseness.  Apart from these drugs many other drugs may be capable of causing this problem.  As you are on hormones and diuretics, they are ofcourse, suspect. But, other causes also need to be excluded. Therefore you need to be examined by an ENT specialist.  Best wishes!

content: When I was pregnant with my first child I developed post nasal drip.  It went away after he was born.  It came back when I was pregnant with my second child and never went away. It is usually yellow and gooey, but sometimes there is blood in it, and sometimes it seems dried out.  It also seems that my sinusus are not as clear as they should be. author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: post nasal drip, throat clearing and tickling
content: Based on your description of the symptoms  and the color and consistency of the mucus, it sounds as though you have a deep sinus infection that probably should be treated with antibiotics as well as symptomatic support (Mucinex or its generic equivalent should help somewhat with the postnasal drip and at least loosen secretions if not stop them). Using an antihistimine would likely dry the secretions but cause them to thicken and make them more difficult to drain, so this may not be the best idea.  I have no idea why occurrence of this would relate to pregnancy, but it could just be coincidental. At any rate you certainly have sinus congestion with postnasal drainage which will eventually cause an annoying cough and possible bronchitis. Due to the color of the drainage I'm guessing this has attracted bacteria and become infected. I'd see someone for this sooner than later, as it rarely resolves on its own, at least not without coming back soon as you think it's gone.   I hope this is helpful. Best of  luck to you.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Hearing loss, Neck Pain, Dizziness, and Numbness
content: Hello -  I think, to get straight to the point, that you should next be seen by a neurologist. While the original treatment was reasonable, you're now descrbing new neurological symptoms that may or may not be secondary to a cervical/muscular problem, but they are more neurological in nature, and suggest some problem with one of the cranial nerves. This could  be due to any number of things, and may be as simple  as an anatomical anomaly that's been aggravated by sleeping in a position that puts pressure on it. Still, it's important to know for sure.   Meanwhile, for the dizziness (which sounds most like vertigo) can probably be minimized, when it occurs, by use of meclazine (either generic or as Dramamine Non-drowsy Formula) over the counter. But by all means get yourself referred to a neurologist, as things have definitely taken a turn in that direction and may have been coming from there all along.   I  hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you and please do keep us updated.
posted_time: Post  by John Kenyon, CNA » Tue Jan 06, 2009 10:14 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Hearing loss, Neck Pain, Dizziness, and Numbness
content: Hello -  The Jan. 6 post was put up after I'd replied to the original post, and the good news here is that this isn't due to a central cause but a viral one. It actually makes complete sense taken in context, and while Bell's palsy can be a huge annoyance/disruption, it's not serious in itself. There is no way of predicting how long it will take an individual to recover fully from this, and there's no clear clinical way to speed recovery, but virtually everyone does eventually regain full function of the affected muscles. There aren't too many useful facial exercises I'm aware of that one can attempt, and they'd only work as the nerves regain function, so it's probably most sensible to just let this correct. Steroids are about the only thing which might be helpful -- or not, but it's worth trying.  I would still absolutely follow up with a neurologist to be certain the diagnosis is correct and to make certain things are progressing as they should. I hope this resolves quickly for you (but be prepared for it to at least seem like it takes forever). Please keep us updated. Good luck to you with this. Hope it doesn't cause too much of a disruption.

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: nasal passage odor
content: Hi, As your question contains few details, it is difficult to arrive at a set of likely diagnoses.  Therefore, let me list some of the conditions associated with abnormal nasal odours. Some of these may be associated with Halitosis.  - A frank nasal infection, such as sinusitis(Chronic purulent nasal sinusitis, esp, odontogenic maxillary sinusitis) is a fairly common cause of  nasal malodor. - problems causing airflow obstruction & obstruction to mucous secretions, such as polyps. - Foreign bodies -Tuberculosis of the nose  - Adenoiditis - A midline nasopharyngeal pouch(may be present either as a congenital defect  or, more commonly, as a result of adhesions in the adenoid furrows). - trauma to the nasal cavity, plastic surgical procedures can deform the nasal cavity, cause obstructions and can result in nasal malodor. - atrophic rhinitis, in which the person loses the sense of smell, but others can smell the malodor.  The discussion on this subject would be incomplete without mentioning certain non-somatic causes such as, - Olfactory hallucinations in various serious psychiatric disorders. The most extreme of these cases may be diagnosed as having a 'body dysmorphic disorder'.In this condition, the patient believes that he/she has a malodour and it is extremely difficult for others to convince that there is in fact no such odor! Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.

content: Hi, Although you mention the word 'Cluster' in passing, your description of your husband's symptoms somehow falls short of the  description of pain in cases of 'cluster headaches'(as far as the severity of pain is concerned).The cluster headaches are said to be one of the most severe forms pain(often described as 'piercing' or 'lancing').They are more common in men unlike migraines, which are more common in women.  It appears(in your husband's case) that it always starts as a block in the ear. This is also not described as a frequent occurence in cluster headaches. Good day!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Very localize ethmoid sinus pain. No other symptoms.
content: Hi, Of late, there has been considerable evidence to suggest that a high percentage of so-called 'sinus headaches' are in reality, Migraines. In your case, you clearly indicate that you have migraine and that the pain of what you believe as sinusitis is different from your migraines. Your problem could well be chronic 'fronto-ethmoidal sinusitis' (obstruction of the ethmoid air cells often leads to frontal sinusitis). The causes of obstruction of the ethmoidal sinus could be manifold (septal deviation,trauma,mucosal swelling, nasal polyps,tumor,  or acute infections). As you suspect, infection is one of the posssibilities. But, as outlined above, obstructing causes should be ruled out. This will certainly need a consultation with an ENT specialist. Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Ringing in ears after concert
content: Hi, It is probable that you might have developed a Noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL) of which there are 2 principal types.  - gradually developing NIHL and  - NIHL caused by acoustic trauma   What is thought to happen,is 'high- intensity sound' induced damage to the cochlea (specifically damage to the hair cells).  NIHL caused by acoustic trauma mostly is caused by a solitary exposure to a very high intensity sound(ex; explosions etc).On the other hand, gradually developing NIHL is believed to be due to chronic,repeated exposure to loud noises.  Not only high pitched noises are dangerous, very low pitched noises emitted by Sub-woofers are also said to be harmful.  Are you perhaps, a regular concert enthusiast? I am unsure your problem fits into which of the two types of the NIHL.  Lots of care goes into the installation of 'acoustics' in dedicated concert halls and opera halls are nowadays,but the same can't be said of other venues. It is perhaps, where an unlucky person is seated in relation to the speaker systems and in which venue, finally matters!. Good luck!

content: Hi, I hope you took azithromycin under medical supervision.This drug has wide ranging side effects,drug interactions and long term side effects as well. author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Retain Fever Due to Throat Infection
content: Hi, A body temperature of 99.3 °C,may be considered normal depending upon which temperature we are referring to (oral, rectal, armpit, or core temperature).  It is possible that you had an episode of follicular tonsillitis.  If you still have tonsillitis (going by the definition of chronic tonsillitis - -tonsillitis lasting for 6 weeks or more) ,by now your condition may be called as 'chronic' tonsillitis.  But, if clinical examination now does not reveal features of chronic tonsillitis then, other causes for the fever have to be investigated.  Good luck!

title: what to expect after removal of mass from vocal cords
content: Good morning Dr,  One month ago, my mother visited her doctor because she was concerned about a burning sensation on her throat. That was the only complained she had. No voice changes were present at all. After assessing her, the doctor said, he has found a mass “polyp” attached to her vocal cords. Apparently, the doctor immediately suggested her that before it gets worse, surgical removal of this mass is the best option. I would like to mention that during this first visit, the doctor only “visualized” the mass. No biopsy of this polyp was preformed during this first visit. My mother went to surgery one month ago. According to the physician, during surgery he removed the mass sent it to pathology and the results showed to be a benign type of polyp.   Today, and after one month of surgery, my mother voice is totally different. Her voice is hoarsely, it gets worse when she cries, the hoarseness seems to be predominantly present when she pronounce specific letters “O”, “A”. She also reported to have some pain in her face and the burning sensation stills present.      My questions are:  It this voice changed to be an expected outcome after this kind of surgery? If so, for how long do you think she may have this changed on her voice? Is this reversible or this a permanent change?  Her doctor told her and keeps telling her that continue to do speech therapy. But he has not siad for how long!  Thank you very much for you time
posted_time: Post  by YGOG » Sun May 31, 2009 2:10 pm

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: what to expect after removal of mass from vocal cords
content: Hi YGOG, A vocal polyp(Reinke's edema) is a growth that is similar to a vocal nodule but is softer. Different from a polyps elsewhere in the body, a vocal polyp is not  precancerous or cancerous.   It most often forms on only one vocal cord & almost always, occurs at the midpoint of the vocal fold.   A vocal polyp is often associated with long-term tobacco smoking but may also be linked to hypothyroidism, gastroesophageal reflux(GERD), or chronic vocal misuse(phonotrauma).  Management usually includes voice rest, voice therapy and  microlaryngoscopic surgery.  The chances of a recurrence are extremely low after surgery and voice therapy.  If voice problems happen to continue following treatment,assessment by a speech-language pathologist may be of help.One should not overlook the importance of controlling the other associated factors(if any) such as tobacco smoking, hypothyroidism, gastroesophageal reflux(GERD).  Best wishes!
posted_time: Post  by Dr.M.Aroon kamath » Sun Nov 08, 2009 7:33 am

Is there a way to have this fixed??  One of my dreams is to become SCUBA certified and dive the great barrier reef, but unfortunately that won't happen unless I can find a fix to this.  Any help would be greatly appreciated.
posted_time: Post  by 9supratt4 » Wed May 27, 2009 11:02 pm

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Eustachian Tube not in the correct position??
content: Hi, "Eustachian tube dysfunction" has been managed by various methods, including placement of a tympanostomy tube, medical management with estrogen nasal drops, and surgical correction.  Eustachian tube dysfunction results in the development of chronic otitis media with effusion and conductive hearing loss.Treatment options however,remain limited.    Aeration of the middle ear by a tube tympanostomy  has been the management of choice for chronic effusions that do not respond well to medical therapy.   Complications of long-term tube tympanostomy placement include persistent tympanic membrane perforations, otorrhea, and the inconvenience of adhering to dry-ear precautions.  I believe,the tympanostomy tubes generally remain in the eardrum for some period of time, (2 - 5 years), before spontaneously falling out of the tympanic membrane. The eardrum usually (but not always) closes without a residual opening at the site of the tube.    Unfortunately, the underlying patho-physiology usually (unfortunately) leads to a recurrence of symptoms when the tube is removed (or falls out) and the tympanic membrane is allowed to heal.  I sincerely hope that your dream to become SCUBA certified and to dive the great barrier reef turns into reality as newer management techniques become increasingly available with the phenomenal growth in technology that we see of late.Good luck!

content: Hi, The symptoms that you have mentioned can be multifactorial. But, as you seek a common explanation for all these symptoms, it will be useful to have some further information from you -such as in which part of the world you reside.  One condition that may explain most of your symptoms is known as "Rhinosporidiosis"- a condition endemic to countries such as India and Sri lanka where the highest prevalance is seen(less so in South America and Africa). content: Hi, Your chief complaint appears to be cough, associated with fatigue, vomiting, fainting, diarrhea & headaches. You don't mention any nasal symptoms.In fact, a sizable number of people with acute sinusitis may have some degree of "Rhinitis"(inflammation of the nasal cavity). author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Swimmers ear from q tips
content: Hi, "Swimmers ear" as the fancy name implies, is generally associated with someone who swims a lot. This was presumably coined because of the increased incidence of this disease (otitis externa) which was commonly observed in individuals or occured in groups of people using certain community swimming pools during the not too distant past when pool hygiene had not been given the due prioity.  It should be noted that "Swimmers ear" may occur in people who don't swim at all!!  The foremost causes for the swimmers ear are:     Water trapped in external ear canal     Sanitation methods     Chemicals in water     Water purification materials. A narrow and short external auditory canal is a risk factor(water trapping).  Despite what many believe,"Swimmers ear" is not primarily caused by bacteria in the water: instead, it's triggered by the 'resident' bacteria normally found in your external ear canal. Water trapped in external ear canal makes the lining of the  external ear canal vulnerable to entry of the 'resident' bacteria. The bacteria thus gain entry into the deeper layers of this skin, initiating the infection.  Also, it is advisable to avoid inserting objects in the ear (e.g.cotton swabs, fingers) that may scratch the ear canal and provide an entry site for infection. Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: one watering eye and lump in front of ear
content: Hi, Sounds very much like "Acute Dacryocystitis".This is due to an acute inflammation of the lacrimal sac. Dacryocystitis has long been noted to occur more frequently on the left side than on the right side (although in your case the right side is affected).  It can be due a number of causes--  such as,  bacterial infections, viral infections, fungal infections,some lacrimal sac tumors,certain other tumors,sinusitis (ethmoidal,maxillary), certain nasal conditions, just to name a few.  The swelling in front of your ear could be parotid lymph nodes which have enlarged in response to this infection.  Going through your profile,i find that you had undergone Mohs' surgery for basal cell carcinoma in 2006 & 2008.If you gave us more details such as the location of the tumour,it may assist us in determining if there is a link to your present symptoms.  It is advisable that you should contact an ENT specialist as soon as feasible and get it sorted out. Good luck!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Bullous Myringitis And Upper Respiratory Infection !
content: Hi, Bullous myringitis is usually a viral  (occasionally bacterial) infection.Bullous myringitis produces vesicles on the tympanic membrane. Since it can be caused by mycoplasma, It is treated with erythroymycin.  It is believed to be a self-limiting disease without significant complications. Clinical evidence has shown it to be frequently accompanied by sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL).  Some studies on Bullous myringitis have demonstrated a significant incidence of SNHL (65% and 66% respectively) with complete resolution of the hearing loss in 57% to 60% of them.The exact mechanism of the hearing loss remains unclear.  The macrolide antibiotic erythromycin is associated on rare occasions with SNHL which is usually bilateral & reversible on discontinuation of the antibiotic.  This hearing loss is most likely at doses of at least 4g/day. Patients at higher risk of developing erythromycin-induced SNHL include patients with pre-existing hepatic or renal failure,  the elderly, and patients undergoing renal or liver transplants.  As you can appreciate, your doctor perhaps changed the antibiotic for this very reason.  As far as your grandmother's advise is concerned,i suggest that you should politely decline. Best wishes!

title: Parathyroid Mass
content: My general practioner found a "mass" that he deemed a parathyroid mass and referred me to an ENT, shouldn't I see an Endocrinologist?
posted_time: Post  by staceyb.241958 » Sun Oct 25, 2009 2:42 pm

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Parathyroid Mass
content: Hi, Parathyroid adenomas (which are one of the causes of primary hyperparathyroidism) are rarely large enough to be detected as a palpable mass in the neck.Parathyroid cancers are also rare causes of primary hyperparathyroidism and are usually not palpable unless they are fairly large.  Pathologic parathyroid glands are palpable in only about 4% of cases. It has been observed that palpable parathyroids occur more often in people with severe, long-standing forms of primary hyperparathyroidism with severe bone disease and in patients with very high serum calcium/PTH levels.Now-a-days, as calcium abnormalities are identified early, a palpable parathyroid has become a rarity!  A palpable swelling in the vicinity of the thyroid gland is more likely to be a thyroid nodule rather than a Parathyroid mass.However, it is possible that your case   belongs to the rare instances. Good luck!
posted_time: Post  by Dr.M.Aroon kamath » Sat Nov 07, 2009 6:22 am

I am not suffering from any breathing complications or swallowing issues, is there anything that can be done about it? and is this fairly normal.  Thanks
posted_time: Post  by GhostInTheMachine » Tue Oct 27, 2009 2:13 pm

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Voice Loss after Full Thyroidectomy
content: Hi, The most important first assessment in your case ought to be detailed phoniatric evaluation using several specific phonic times and measuring vocal frequencies.This will help to ascertain your voice range and hopefully give a clue as to the etiology of your complaint. Other modalities such as Laryngeal videostrobolaryngoscopy, electromyography and spectrography may also be useful.  There are a number of causes for voice problems which may affect the upper end of the voice.... - laryngeal trauma (including blunt traumas) - post surgical - post anesthetic - certain drugs (ex.testosterone),and substance abuse (ex.alcohol) etc. Best wishes!

author: lindsong  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Thu Apr 09, 2009 2:38 pm Gender: Female
title: Discontinuing diuretic use w/Meniere's disease?
content: Last July, I was diagnosed with Meniere's disease and prescribed a potassium-sparing diruetic. My treatment has been successful and I would like to discontinue the diuretic as soon as possible. Would this be a bad idea?
posted_time: Post  by lindsong » Wed Jul 29, 2009 8:09 am

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Discontinuing diuretic use w/Meniere's disease?
content: Hi,  Central to the management of Menier's disease is sodium restriction. Diuretics are used only as an adjunct.  When a strict low sodium diet is adhered to and a diuretic is taken reliably, the disease in the majority of patients would be expected to come under satisfactory control.   After 6 - 12 months, the body becomes sufficiently adapted to the low sodium diet so that the diuretic can be withdrawn. Strict adherence to the diet is necessary to keep the disease under control.  It is an year since you were diagnosed to have been diagnosed with Meniere's disease.  So, the results of withdrawing the diuretic now sill almost certainly hinge upon how serious you had been about your diet.  Good day!
posted_time: Post  by Dr.M.Aroon kamath » Sat Nov 07, 2009 2:26 am

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Swollen lymph node and lump on lower palat of mouth
content: Hi, Recurrent enlargement of the cervical lymph node raises suspicion of a possible source (focus) of infection in its drainage area (which includes the oral cavity).  You mention about the lump on the gum which becomes tender every now and then. A lump over the gum has a wide range of differential diagnoses(ranging from benign to malignant).  From the history you have provided, one would tend to start with the possibility of this being a "Pyogenic granuloma". This is usually  smooth or lobulated,red or purple.This is entirely benign and can be surgically removed fairly easily.  Other swellings which may need to be considered are fibromas, peripheral giant cell granulomas, swellings arising from the sublingual salivary glands etc.  The best course of action should be to consult your GP, then perhaps, a dental consult and evaluation of the lymph node as well (FNA/Biopsy). Best wishes!

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: If you have a burning sensation I would wonder about esophogeal reflux, where stomach acid comes back up the tube and burns the esophagus.    If it's just the tonsils then, yes, a tonsillectomy might be the answer you are seeking.  If I had tonsils giving me this kind of grief and interfering with my daily life, making me uncomfortable, etc. I would definitely do it.    Of course there is always possible risk with any surgery but there is risk with frequent infections too.  It's your call but I would follow up with an ear/nose/throat specialist.  Good luck.

author: heidi81  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sat Aug 01, 2009 1:58 pm Gender: Female
title: Partial Thyroid Removal
content: After right thyroid lobe removal, found inclusion of thyroid tissue located within the right paratracheal lymph node.  Can someone tell me if the paratracheal lymph node is considered a lateral or medial lymph node?  Thanks!
posted_time: Post  by heidi81 » Sat Aug 01, 2009 2:04 pm

author: Dr. A. De la Guerra  Medical Doctor Posts: 70 Joined: Fri Aug 26, 2005 8:00 pm Gender: Male Location: Lima, Peru  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. De la Guerra       Yahoo Messenger
title: Re: Partial Thyroid Removal
content: Hi heidi81,  Lymph nodes of the neck are organized into levels. Level I include the submental and submandibular areas; levels II to IV include the internal jugular vein lymph nodes; level V includes the posterior triangle. The central compartment (level VI) contains the pretracheal and paratracheal nodes; thyroid lymphatics drain first into this compartment. So the answer is that paratracheal lymph nodes are considered as medial lymph nodes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. A. De la Guerra » Fri Aug 14, 2009 10:33 pm

content: Hello seraphim1050,  I was looking at your medical profile.  First, the cpap and nasal medication are not going to provide optimal results if you are still smoking.  Smoking is an irritant to your respiratory tract which in turn can cause sinus and nasal inflammation, narrowing the airway thus not helping the thick mucus problem you are having not to mention other respiratory issues. I am not familar with the injections you had mentioned in regards to treatment.    Best of luck to you.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: Re: Lump on Left Side of Neck Below Ear
content: Hi pattycakes447, Lymph nodes commonly enlarge as a result of bacterial or viral infection. The lymphatic system essentially acts as a filter and is a defense against an infectious process. When lymph nodes do enlarge as a result of an infection, they may not return to their preinfectious size. I would encourage you to have an evaluation by your physician to identify the causative factor. A course of antibiotic therapy may be required. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Jan PA-C MPH  Physician Assistant Posts: 10 Joined: Thu Jul 30, 2009 2:36 pm Gender: Female
title: Re: Outer Ear Pain
content: Dear Carol;  I trust that you have continued to seek care from your primary care physician. Many times when a diagnosis is not initially identified, it is because a bit of a longer observation period is required to allow the symptoms to make it apparent what may be going on. The first step is to make sure nothing critical is going on, which you ruled out with an absence of signs of infection.  The ears are an uncommon site for what is often called 'radicular pain' or pain resulting from a pinched nerve. Otalgia or ear pain can result from a pinched nerve that may be resulting from anything from a stiff neck to cervical disc problems that may be pinching the nerves.  Also don't discount the contribution of your dentist to help you solve this question. They are intimately familiar with the complicated interworkings of muscle, nerves, skin and connective tissue in the face.  A good regimen of gentle stretching may be very helpful, http://www.dcdoctor.com/pages/rightpage ... _neck.html and certainly your fibromyalgia will make this a bit harder for you. For more information about the different causes of ear pain, check out this website info. It relates to children, but is still appropriate. http://www.wrongdiagnosis.com/symptoms/ ... ses-3a.htm  Good Luck!

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Bloody Nasal Discharge
content: Hello --  I would, first, place greater weight on the positive CT, which will not show something that is not there,  rather than the negative nasal endoscopy, which could very easily be fooled. Further, the sort of symptoms and findings you report do, in fact, have bloody discharge quite often as a feature, although it's not generally a sign of anything more serious than the underlying infection and anatomical abnormalities which help make this possible. The website you found which states this isn't a normal feature of sinusitius is absolutely incorrect. The use of Nasonex also can help aggravate this problem, and often does little to help resolve the infection, although it can sometimes help with short term management of symptoms and also sometimes aid in drainage which can on occasion help resolve the infection. The ethmoids, however, are difficult to treat medically and often require vigorous and expert irrigation as well as antibiotic flush (and sometimes surgery to correct anatomic anomalies) to set the situation right.   I hope this is helpful to you. Good luck to you and please follow up with us here as needed.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Still Can't Breath After Deviated Septum Surgery
content: Hello -  I'd definitely support a second opinion. While these surgeries do have a rather mixed outcome, sometimes it requires a do-over to get things right -- and sometimes it  doesn't help all that much, but sometimes it does. This is why the second opinion sounds especially right to me. The original doctor seems pleased with the results but he doesn't have to live with them, you do. title: Clogged Eustachian tube leading to glue ear?
content: Hi,  First of all I want to thank the people who make this website possible.  Thank you to the doctors who are able to help others and hopefully myself...  I personally appreciate any ideas and suggestions.  I have googled my situation many times and haven't found a lasting solution.  Hopefully with your help I can get through this issue...   I will try to keep this as short as possible while still mentioning the most important dates and experiences.   In December 2007 I got some water trapped inside my right ear while taking a shower.  I was already feeling a little worn down and proceeded to go out for a 'night on the town'.  Within a couple of days I had a head cold and took it easy while recovering.  Within the next few days I blew my nose too hard and got a clogged / stuffy feeling in that same right ear.  I figured it would go away as long as I continued to take it easy.  After about 10 days I experienced a loud and sudden ringing in the same right ear.  I figured that my ear cleared and the stuffy feeling was gone.  However after a few minutes I noticed it was still there.  I slept on my left side for days, hoping that gravity would help drain the ear.  I did, but I then noticed that stuffy feeling in my left ear, almost like it switched sides...  At some point during that winter I came down with a week long cold, possibly the flu.  I took some medicine from the doctor and proceeded to rest.  During my cold, both ears felt stuffed up and very uncomfortable.  Eventually after 10 days or so I felt physically normal, however my ears felt different.  With a concentrated swallow I could make both ears "pop" or "crackle".  After a few trips to the doctor over the next two months they suggested I take a decongestant to clear my ears.  When that didn't work, I took a decongestant along with a mild steroid (from the doctor) to try and clear my ears.  To this day - about 16 months later - I still can "pop" my ears by swallowing.  I have been taking an allergy medicine with a decongestant for almost the entire time.  When I stop taking it, my health is impacted.  About 3-5 days after stopping the decongestant I will notice my ears feel much more full or very congested to the point where I can't even "pop" them by swallowing.  I will also start to feel run-down, possibly because an infection is brewing in those ear canals.  Back I go onto the decongestant and they feel much better within a week.  I am 23 years old and very healthy.  I get 8+ hours of sleep each night, exercise 4-6 times per week, eat very healthy, drink green tea in the morning, and take vitamins.  I don't know why I can't kick this ear thing.  Once in a while I will get a sudden ringing in one of my ears and I will think I am making progress, but still, same situation.  I have done a ton of google searching but have not found any great ideas.  I don't have health insurance and I am not so excited about going to the doctor and pay $200 + just to have a look in my ears.  I had my doctor in college do that for free many times and still not find a cure.  I am wondering if getting tubes in my ears is the only long term solution.  I assume that with tubes, the ears will get much better ventalation and the Eustachian tube will better be able to drain out.  Once again, your help is so greatly appreciated.  I don't know what else to do.  Thank you so much.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Clogged Eustachian tube leading to glue ear?
content: Hello --  You most likely have one or more deep sinuses infected. These can sometimes be very difficult to resolve with antibiotics because they're usually far removed from significant blood supply,  so the antibiotics don't reach them in adequate amounts. For this reason  there is the possibility of clinical irrigation and/or tube placements, although probably tubes won't be necessary.  There is a home remedy that goes back a long way, and which is often effective. It is complex to explain, but I can link you here to a site with a very detailed description and suffestions on what products to use. It's just as well to simply purchase the supplies recommended, although almost anything similar will work.   Here's a link to a detailed outline of the remedy. It can be repeated several times at least. If it doesn't work then you'll need to have an ENT do a careful clinical irrigation with packing and some medications not available over the counter. First try this, though: http://www.ehow.com/how_4537025_cure-cl ... -tube.html  I hope this helps. Good luck to you and please follow up with us here as needed.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Frequent Nosebleeds
content: Hello --  There are a lot of potential reasons for this, but since it seems very limited in its focus of origin I suspect it to be fairly benign. It could be due to a natural weak capilary of good size, or it could be due to something happening to the mucosa where this vessel is located. It is probably the same one each time, so may be amenable to simple correction, but should be examined carefully to rule out any systemic cause as well as any local disease of the mucosa itself, such as a tumor or superficial cancer. These are unlikely but not worth ignoring as possibilities. The nosebleeds like this are quite often just due to an anatomical anomaly and can be cauterized or otherwise repaired in the office. Just be sure to rule out any remote possibility of some other, more serious cause.  My best to you. Please follow up with us here as needed.

author: apex  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Dec 24, 2008 10:24 pm Gender: Female
title: Re: clicking noise in throat.. help !!!
content: Hello all-  After reading your posts I felt like you knew exactly what I was feeling!  The first doctor I saw tested me for strep and sent me on my way.  She completely disregarded that I said there was a clicking and popping in my throat when I swallowed.  Like most of you it happened more after drinking liquids and only if my head was in certain positions.  It was very painful!  I went to see an ENT after reading some of your posts and reading about a potential correlation with thyroid cartiledge.  When I mentioned this to the doctor he sent me up for a CT scan.  The scan showed that I had a thyroglossal cyst on my hyoid bone.  The hyoid bone is located near the base of the tongue.  Everyone has this tract in their throat before they're bone but they are supposed to close up.  Some don't close properly and create a pocket where the cyst can form.  After meeting with the surgeon, he admit he had never heard of my symptoms before and couldn't guarantee removing it would solve them.  Since there's a very large possibility of the cyst becomming infected, I opted for the Sistrunk Procedure (the surgical removal of the cyst).  The doctor was surprised to find that the cyst was actually the size of a quarter and located directly in the location of my pain.  I am now almost 3 weeks out of surgery and I have not felt the popping and clicking once!  I have a very small, hardley noticeable incision across my neck and only stayed in the hospital 1 night.    I can't guarantee that this is what's causing all of your pain, but it's definitely something to look into.  I know how painful it was and how frustrating it was when I felt like the doctors either didn't believe me or didn't think it was important enough to spend their time trying to fix.  Keep insisting!  It was well worth the struggle because I am now pain free!

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: clicking noise in throat.. help !!!
content: Hello, I agree that the hyoid bone could be causing the clicking sensation.  Small muscles (e.g. genio-hyo-glossus) adjoin the tongue, the hyoid, and chin.  So moving the head and swallowing would affect the hyoid.    Endoscopy would not see the hyoid.  However the bone can be palpated under the chin.    If clicking is associated with pain and/or difficulty swallowing, an evaluation of the esophagus is prudent (eg. scope or barium swallowing).  A CT scan of the neck would help rule out cysts or tumors.  An ENT or gastroenterologist may be consulted as well.    I agree that what seems like an obscure symptom may be fairly common.  However, most folks probably do not visit their physician unless it is causing problems other than the clicking sound.    Take care.

author: ChestPain43  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sun Apr 26, 2009 4:42 am Gender: Male
title: Adverse Reaction to Clindamycin
content: I was prescribed 300mg of Clindamycin 4 times a day for 10 days because my Dr. stated I had a horrific abscess on my right tonsil. The next day, I want to an ENT specialist and he indicated no abscess, but commented on the strength and type of antibiotic I was taking.  My Dr instructed me to continue the Clinamycin as prescribed.  The following day, I started having horrific chest pain in my right chest, which would shoot up my neck like fire, going into my throat, up my face, affecting the lower part of my right ear and going as high as my right eye, as I could feel my eye drooping.  I didn't associate all of this with the Clindamycin at the time, but kept going back to my doctor loudly complaining about these symptoms. They were sure it was this abscessed right tonsil and that my ENT just couldn't see it for whatever reason. I was instructed to continue with this medication and they hoped that everything would get better.  Day 7 of my medication, I couldn't take the pain (joint pain, muscle soreness, heartburn, lathargic, chest/neck/face pain) any longer and went back to my doctors. They were still sure it was an abscess and were insisting I get a $900 CT Scan. Being that my insurance doesn't cover that, I couldn't afford it and told them.  They did blood work and it all came back "in range".  Day 8 of my medication, after taking my morning dose, within 20 minutes, I was curled up on the floor with my knees pulled to my chest. If my heart was on the right side, I would swear I was having a heart attack. This intense pain lasted for 3 and 1/2 hours and because I thought I was actually on the verge of dying, I called my doctor and agreed to the CT Scan (versus going to the ER), as I was sure there was something horribly wrong. This was the first time I associate this horrific pain with the Clindamycin and I told myself that was the last pill of that, that I would put into my system. CT Scan came back just great.  There was no abscess and my doctor just simply said "well, we should stop the Clindamycin immediately". For whatever reason, stopping the medication was the last thing for them to try, instead of being one of the first.  Now, almost 48 hours after taking my last dose, every time I swallow when I'm eating or drinking soda, I have this unbelievable pain in my right chest that goes through to my back.  In order to get the food down, I have to hold my chest real tight and just get through the pain. Not sure if I should go back to my ENT, or who I should see, as I refuse to go back to my GP at this point.  Would the Clindamycin have damaged something deep in my esophagus or lung?  Any information that you may be able to provide would be greatly appreciated.  Thank you!
posted_time: Post  by ChestPain43 » Sun Apr 26, 2009 5:18 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Adverse Reaction to Clindamycin
content: Hello --  For follow up for the tonsil problem I would certainly go back to the ENT. I would also consider a change of primary, since the diagnosis was clearly wrong or at least exaggerated in its findings, and the treatment was inappropriate due to recognizable GI reactions to the drug prescribed. This could have been corrected most likely by a change of drug. While all antibiotics can cause GI disturbances clindimycin is especially notable for this, and what seems to have happened is that the phrenic nerve was irritated secondary to GI upset, perhaps severely (due to anatomic coincidence most likely) and this could well explain the continued chest pain on drinking carbonated beverages. Your ENT won't likely be able to address this, and a GI specialist or perhaps ultimately even a neurologist (pain management specialist in this case) may wind up getting involved, but only because your PCP doesn't seem familiar with the syndrome often caused by Clinidmyacin and likely wouldn't treat it in a way that might well resolve the problem. (Quite possibly a short trial run of a nerve pain blocker such as gabapentin or pregabalin might be required to shut down this response, although it certainly should eventually resolve on its own).   I hope this is helpful tyo you. Good luck with this and please follow up with us as needed.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Can sinus trouble be causing my bad breath?
content: HI there --  This is often a puzzle, because there are several potential causes of this phenomenon and sometimes they don't follow the obvious trail. While your sinuses definitely could be causing this -- especially a deep ethmoid sinus infection with blockage, which is difficult to reach with both narrow spectrum antibiotics and even home irrigation remedies, and sometimes requires expert chemical irrigation by an ENT specialist. However,  even if this were to fail to correct the  problem, given we are allowed to have more than one thing going on at the same time, there is a  third possibility,  and  that is often something as simple as a mild gastritis, which can cause symptoms almost identical to dental hygeine issues and severe deep sinusitus.  For this reason,  if the sinus theory shouldn't pan out, your next stop would have to be a GI specialist and possibly an endoscopy to be  certain you don't have a mild erosive gastritis. You've eliminated dental hygeine as a likely cause, and sinus problems would definitely come ahead of GI problems in the heirarchy of causes, but that would be the next possibility after sinusitus has been ruled out -- or in.  ENT next,  and hopefully that would be the last consult you'd need.  From your description of the attending symptoms it does sound more like sinus than GI, but you never really know til it's been explored thoroughly.  I hope this helps. Good luck t you with this and please follow up with us here as needed.
posted_time: Post  by John Kenyon, CNA » Fri May 08, 2009 10:03 pm

author: RoyP  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Apr 28, 2009 5:14 am Gender: Male
title: Sinus Odour and bad taste
content: I have a constant odour in my right-hand sinus with associated bad taste; my normal smell and taste of food etc is not effected. It is a bitter taste/smell not very pleasant, although I’m getting used to it, but some days it seems worse than others. It started over 18 months ago and my GP prescribed various antibiotics and nasal sprays all to no effect. I was then sent to the hospital and the consultant tried more powerful antibiotics, still with no positive results so I then had a CT scan, which showed an infection deep in the sinus near to the nerve from the eye. Therefore surgery took place to open up the airways by removing some bone and they scraped away as much of the infection as possible, the idea being that the extra passage of air would heal the remaining infection. Eight months later there has been no real improvement, I still have this odour and horrible taste, if I only breathe through the LH side there is no smell, so it definitely comes from the right sinus. At my last visit to the hospital in February I was told that there was no more help that they could offer and that I would just have to live with it, which is a bit depressing. Can anyone suggest any help for this condition? I do take ‘Simvastatin’ and ‘Micardis Plus’ daily, but as far as I’m aware they are not the cause.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Sinus Odour and bad taste
content: Hello --  First,  there certainly should be further investigation of the problem, as it sounds as though you may have developed an ostial infection at the surgery site in the deep sinus. Sometimes this does happen or swelling causes new blockage with the same or worse symptoms and requires subsequent interventions. The very fact you can readily locate and detect the source or location of the smell and taste (classic for both  sinusitus and osteomyelitis secondary to sinus surgery) tells us there is something more going on, and I would not accept a "get used to it" answer. This is a deep sinus and  so difficult to treat with narrow-spectrum antibiotics and may require further surgical intervention or at least high-powered, broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment. I would by no means accept the last answer as acceptable. You still have a significant problem that in most cases could be resolved by a resolute ENT specialist.  I hope this is helpful. Good luck to you and please follow up with us here as needed.

When walking outside the light killed my head, louds noises.. almost like a migraine but not like it all at once. I felt very sick to my stomach and felt "out of it". Also, I don't know if this has to do with it but I wasn't myself, mood wise. I felt weak and just didn't want to be bothered. My head still hurts and my eyes strain more, also I feel kind of drugged up every now and again. It's hard to concentrate on things without taking a second to remember what I was doing. Reading, Being on a computer, Watching tv.. They all hurt my head. Plus, where I hit it on my temple feels like it's hot and pulsating.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Pure Yellow Liquid From Nose
content: Hi there --  You would seem to have a severe infection of one of the frontal sinuses, which are above the  eyes, essentially behind the forehead and nearest the temple area. Sometimes  this very thing you describe happens, instead of the usual thick, viscous sort of discharge. This thin, bright yellow discharge contains more lymph and less mucous, and will literally pour when the head is tipped. The treatment is the same as for other sinus infections,but this is a little different,  as you've discovered, in terms of how its managed and controlled.   The fact you struck your head earlier may or may not be related to this, as sometimes a blow to the skull can help initiate or aggravate a latent infection. In any case this will need treatment,  probably with antibiotics and an antihistimine -- the latter not always that helpful with sinus infections, but which will help dry and  thicken the secretions,  which in your case might actually be helpful in terms of controlling the  discharge.   A CT scan of the head would probably be a good idea simply because this follows a blow to the head, but likely won't disclose anything, and with the free, thin discharge, my not even show up the congestion.  Still, it wouldn't hurt and might just be helpful.   I hope this is useful to you. Good luck to you and  please follow up with us as needed.

title: Post Concussion, Musician is Hearing Everything Off-Key
content: Mid March I suffered a concussion from syncope. I was out for several minutes and received many stitches in X formation to my upper left back of the head, refused CT and MRI, as after an hour felt fine. Ear fullness (left) and vertigo appeared the next day and several days later an Epley-type manouvre was performed, vertigo gone. Have not performed since, as my voice, and my cello, to me, is flat, off key.  But so is all the music I listen to.... I have until now enjoyed a gift of hearing every subtle nuance many other musicians do not possess, and a hearing range well above average. Because of the vertigo having been an ear problem, and ear still feels full, is this a fixable problem to present to an ENT? I am uninsured and will go only if this a strong probability. Is this an ENT issue or neurological?
