author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Post Concussion, Musician is Hearing Everything Off-Key
content: Hello --  This is something that carries a personal element for me, as a great appreciator of music, so can only imagine the bother to you. Most of the time these things will resolve on their own, rather subtly, over time. However, it could be that there is something neurological or mechanical standing in the way of its self-correction and I'd strongly advise at least a quick otolaryngolical or ENT exam of the area and, if nothing is turned up there, at least a single neurology consult. I suspect if it is mechanical/structural in nature it could be relieved fairly easily. If it is neurological you may as well know what it is and what the possibilities are. I do suspect it will self-correct, but hesitate to suggest you just leave that to chance.   I hope this is helpful. Please follow up with us here as needed.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Loud ringing in ear for weeks
content: Hello --  While you say you have no sinus infection, this is one of the potential causes and is often due to a deep sinus blockage which can cause no other symptoms. This is especially suspect because you mentioned a sensation like water in the ear,  and because it started when you were lying on your right side, but later became constant. Also this could be due to an inner ear infection which would of course likely show no other symptoms with the  possible exception of pain, which is not always present.  I've gone toward infective agents here because while there are literally dozens of potential causes of tinnitus (including something as simple as taking aspirin), the way yours started does sound most like the result of an infection. It could of course be something else, and all causes should be ruled out. I'd strongly suggest a consult with an otolaryngologist or ENT specialist to try and determine the cause so that it can be eliminated or treated. Tinnitus often is part of several syndromes that can result in hearing loss, and if this can be avoided it's always good to avoid it.   I hope this is helpful. Good luck to you and please follow up with us here as needed.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Never Ending Sneezing
content: Hello --  This is not a cold. A non-stop allergy-like thing such as this is, obviously, due to an allergen. Everyone's different with regard to what may set it off, and it could be something as simple as dust mites or as complex as foods in certain combination, but it definitely sounds allergic.  You should be tested for all the common allergies,  needless to say, which would be a huge help,  but also need to be treated for the symptoms. A good non-drowsy antihistimine (and there are many) should be prescribed to subdue or eliminate the symptoms. This seems like a really simple thing and I'm amazed your doctors haven't even tried to isolate the cause nor treat the symptoms. I'd suggest you start with a good over-the-counter antihistimine such as Claritin or even Zyrtec, to see if either of these works for you. Benedryl is also good, but will make most people quite drowsy.   If any of these works for you it's an even better indicator that you're suffering from allergies and need to be tested to see what may be causing this, so that you might be able to eliminate it from your environment or at least know what to avoid if possible. Oh, and yes, year round allergies definitely are common, so don't let anyone tell you it would only occur during certain seasons.  I hope this is helfpul. Good luck to you and please follow up with us here as needed.

title: s/p myringotomy and tube placement
content: Hi there.... My history is that 12 days ago I started taking scuba lessons in the 14 foot pool....when I attempted to clear my ears, I had some problems but eventually cleared them but ended up with both ears becoming clogged and the left one never clearing.  After 4 nights of this and no relief I had one of my coworkers ...a doctor look in my left ear since it was hurting.  My right ear ended up being ruptured and the left was....sucked down.  I went into see an ENT doctor and they gave me affrin and told me to vagal all weekend and take decongestants to open it up....after 3 days of this....I went in this past monday and they performed a myringotomy.  I felt a little pressure relieve as they were cutting with the blade, but it immediately clogged back up.......two days later I went to be seen again.  They did an audiogram which showed a 20 decibel hearing loss on the left and significant pressure.  When the doctor looked in my left ear he said it was closed again/sucked down.  They decided to do another myringotomy and tube placement.  I have had no relief of pressure and my ear is still clogged.  My question is...is there any way to relief the pressure?  Should I be able to hear and not clogged with the tube in?  How long till I should be able to hear......and how miserable will I be when I fly in 5 days?  Sorry to ask so many questions....just tired of being able to hear my own voice in my head and just want to get back to normal.
posted_time: Post  by rondasworld » Sat Apr 11, 2009 6:55 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: s/p myringotomy and tube placement
content: Hi there -  Normally I'd have a pretty ready answer for you as to how you might unclog your ears, but since the doctors haven't done this (irrigate your sinuses) and you have tubes placed, doing yourself could just make it worse. I  would, though, ask the doctor if it might be helpful to irrigate your sinuses, since this is usually the bottom line reason this happens (clogged ears). Air pressure can't equalize in the eucstachian tubes that lead to the eardrums, and things get sucked in, clogged up, etc. You're suffering a pretty severe hearing diminution right now, so something more should be done anyway.  As for the potential pain or discomfort while flying, you'd need to talk to your doctor about this. Taking deongestants may help, but sometimes this is an unpredictable thing and often nothing happens, while other times it can be pretty painful. This can happen even in someone with no current ear problems, so it really is hard to say.   Again, sinus irrigation might help, but I don't honestly know if that can be done while tubes are in place, so you should ask your doctor about this as well as what might be most helpful for the flight. Also, were you warned to not use Afrin for more than three days in a row? Doing it more often or longer can actually make the problem worse as it causes a rebound effect, and this also may be part of your problem right now. Again, something to ask your doctor.  I hope this is helpful. Good luck to you and please follow up with us.

posted_time: Post  by ash87 » Fri Apr 17, 2009 12:44 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Perforated nasal septum: does it heal on its own?
content: Hi there --  Your situation is not unusual, and it can be diffcult  for the patient to determine if there is a perforation or not. While these may sometimes heal themselves (as eardrums will), more often they will not, because the nature of the mucosa is somewhat different, and traumatic injury will be repeated more often than not. An ENT specialist can do a thorough history and physical and clear off the crusting and use instruments to visualize the septum and determine if it is perforated or not. If it is, he can then set up a treatment plan based on the individual case. This is important because some will heal on their own if allowed, while others require either medical or sometimes minor surgical treatment.  No particular need to be alarmed, but it would be very prudent to go ahead and make the appointment and get this resolved now, so you can then work on the underlying problem as well as the impulse to poke around in there.   I hope this is helpful. Good luck to you and please follow up with us and keep us updated.

author: emanon130  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Mon Apr 20, 2009 8:17 pm Gender: Female
title: I have just been Rx'd Singulair, should I continue Allegra?
content: I assume you have access to my posted medical history.  In short, I have just started taking Singulair with wonderful results.  I have been taking Allegra for decades, mainly to decrease runny nose and miscl allergy symptoms.  Should I continue to take the Allegra along with the Singulair? Or quit the Allegra?  In case you find it helpful, recent history detail follows:  Recent history: For nearly a week I had extended - as long as 1 -2 hours non-stop - bouts of uncontrolable coughing, more often than not from tickle high up in back of throat which was seriously disrupting my sleep as well as my ability to perform tasks/work while awake.  Mucinex with benadryl helped some but I still could not get a night's sleep or work without beginning to cough and choke mid-telephone calls.  I did not "feel bad" except for loss of sleep & tiredness from all the coughing which I just had to put an end to.  Went to PCP. PCP told me I had significant inflamation and congestion in nose, ears and throat but clear lungs.  He gave me a prescription narcotic cough syrup and Singulair samples and, while aluding that he thought I might get worse before I got better, he gave me an antibiotic Rx to fill if I decided this was developing into an infection.   Cough Syrup, with the Mucinex & benadryl enabled me to get a couple of nights' sleep but really did not "fix" things.   I took Singulair for 1st time Friday night - like a miracle:  No uncontrolable runny nose, I slept thru the night without other mentioned meds.  I now have only an occasional very congested, deep, productive cough - not bouts of coughing.  Taking the Singulair is like I am in a different world - a normal one.  I take so, so many meds.  Should I try stopping the Allegra?    Thank you in advance for any feedback.
posted_time: Post  by emanon130 » Mon Apr 20, 2009 9:27 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: I have just been Rx'd Singulair, should I continue Allegra?
content: Hi there --  Singulair is unique and has properties that for some reason are much more effective in preventing not only post nasal drainage (PND) but also laryngeal spasm resulting from PND irritation. Allegra is a more conventional antihistimine and so mostly causes drying. You can -- and probably should -- discontinue it now, since there's usually no benefit from taking both, and the combined drying effect could actually cause problems, as conventional antihistimines often contribute to sinus and bronchial infections because of thickening mucous. Singulair works differently and often has very good results in patients with trachiobronchial spasm. If it's working as well as you say, this is wonderful, and if you can manage without the Allegra you'll be all to the good. If, however, after a few days things seem to have worked best with both, there's also no huge reason to not restart it. I'd definitely try going without first, because of the drying issue, as well as because of your very reasonable concern about having so many routine meds to manage. Anything you can get rid of is only going to make life easier.  I hope this is helpful. Good luck to you and please follow up with us and let us know how this all goes.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: I can hear my heart beat in one ear. ALL the time.
content: Hi there --  While this symptoms is often benign and sometimes is only an intermittent annoyance, it also can be a sign of something more serious, and this really needs to be examined more closely, as a look into the ear would likely not expose a new growth, cyst, tumor, aneurysm, etc., even though the pulsing is heard in there. Usually this, when it is a matter for concern, is due to something either growing or pushed out of place and placing pressure on the carotid artery near the ear's apparatus so that the sound is transmitted and becomes audible and annoying. However, while  it's annoying, it's the potential later problems that are of concern, which would result from pressure on the carotid artery. For this reason an ultrasound study, possibly followed by a CT or MRI should be done to rule out any neoplasm or cyst (or even something as simple as a displaced hyoid bone) can be ruled out or handled appropriately. It may not be anything, but this is often not as simple as it would appear, and if it's constant and can be attenuated by head movement something mechanical is causing it and needs to be recognized and handled accordingly.  Hope this is helpful to you. Please follow up with us here as needed. Good luck to you.

author: NurseBrit2  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Apr 04, 2009 11:32 pm Gender: Female
title: Enlarged sternocleidomastoid and small carotid/jugular
content: I have an enlarged sternocleidomastoid muscle on the right side of my neck.  This has been growing slowly for over 2 years.  It was first believed to be a brachial cleft cyst, the mumps, and a tumor, but finally due to an ENT who took me seriously I had a CT scan done in October of 2008 and it showed that it was just my muscle that was budging out and growing abnormally. Also, the scan showed that under the muscle my carotid and jugular were abnormally smaller and on the opposite side of my neck, with the normal muscle, the carotid and jugular are significantly larger than usual.  He wasn’t sure as to why but guessed that the one side was trying to compensate for what the other side couldn’t do because of the muscle pressing down. The ENT wanted to refer me to another hospital but was confident that there was nothing to be done for the muscle.    This was over 6 months ago.  I have since then am having new symptoms.  I get light headed when standing up and have fainted 2 times.  The muscle never really "hurts" but once in a while it feels to get bigger during the day and will ache.  Also, at night it is "tighter" and I feel as if I turn my head one way or the other that it makes me light headed...possibly due to constricting the artery?  The last symptom I’ve noticed is a reoccurring painful lymph node above the muscle that is large and under my jaw.  It is enlarged and painful to the touch but goes away after a day but will also come back. Any thoughts?!?!  Should I go in for another CT or see a different ENT?
posted_time: Post  by NurseBrit2 » Sat Apr 04, 2009 11:45 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Enlarged sternocleidomastoid and small carotid/jugular
content: Hello --  Diseases which can cause localized hypertrophy of large, stabilizing muscle groups such as you describe are rare, but can occur. Otherwise I'd suspect some sort of spasm or neoplasm inside the muscle; however, you seem to have had neoplasms and cysts ruled out, and since the carotids are unequal in diameter, this will need to be corrected, perhaps surgically, to prevent eventualy injury to the brain. The fact that you suffer lightheadedness and fainting spells will force the issue, but it would be good to get ahead of it if possible. I'm not sure your ENT is sufficiently conversant in physiology of the neck to deal with this, so you may need to see either an orthopedic surgeon and/or a vascular surgeon (the latter may be your best bet, since the artery is really the concern here, the muscle secondary) to formulate a treatment plan.   I hope this is helpful to you. The situation is definitely odd, so you may need referral  to a highly specialized center if you can't find someone who can figure this out in a timely way.   Good luck to you with this and please follow up with us as needed.

title: blocked ears after using sodium bicarbonate
content: i had difficulty hearing in my right ear my gp said there is wax built up inside both my ears prescribed sodium bicarbonate drops ..its been three days that i have been using it in both ears and the pressure in my ears has increased and my hearing is very poor. Can a doctor tell me if thats normal
posted_time: Post  by se7en » Sun Apr 05, 2009 6:16 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: blocked ears after using sodium bicarbonate
content: Hello --  Sodium bicarb is sometimes used to help kill off fungal infections, but as far as earwax goes I wouldn't think it would be especially helpful. I'm not sure why it's apparently staying in your ears, but your doctor should do a regular in-office ear irrigation followed by either prescription or over-the-counter drops (such as those made by Murine) which are intended to dissolve wax. Even with this, sometimes the fluid will stay in the ear for a day or so, usually draining during sleep. Murine drops can be used without a doctor's help, as well, and is generally effective. If your ears don't drain properly fairly soon you'll need to go back and have them irrigated, which should have been done the first time, in order to prevent otitis media (inflammation of the ear canal, as "swimmer's ear").   Hope this is helpful to you. Please follow up with us as needed.

author: Optimist28  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Apr 07, 2009 12:05 am Gender: Female
title: Sphenoid sinus inflammatory change?
content: Hello,  I have been having severe headaches. Had a Cranial CT scan done but i don't understand what the results mean and my doctor is on holidays.   This is what it says: Mucosal thickening, polyp formation and some inspissated secretion is noted in the single sphenoid sinus. Summary- Sphenoid sinus inflamatory change.  Could you please explain what this means in a way that a regular person can understand and is there any need for concern?  Thank you for your time!!  Angela
posted_time: Post  by Optimist28 » Tue Apr 07, 2009 12:33 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Sphenoid sinus inflammatory change?
content: Hi there --  Your CT results have a pretty narrow and relatively benign interpretation consistent with your symptoms: "inspissated" means congealed or impacted, and "secretions"  refers to mucus that is secreted by the sinuses. Polyps formation is common and often is the cause of the original blockage and subsequent inflammation. The sphenoid sinuses are deep sinuses located behind the nose and eyes, so are rather isolated from rich blood vessel supply, a mixed thing at best. Because they aren't convenient to significant blood supply they are less likely to allow local infection to more sensitive areas; by the same token, narrow-spectrum antibiotics are often lost in the works before they are able to reach the location of the infection, so this is sometimes difficult to clear up without manual irrigation or possibly even in some cases surgery. Broad spectrum antibiotics are more likely to help, but in the meantime expectorants (such as guaifenesin as in Mucinex) and pain medication (ibuprofin, naproxyn) to treat the headachces and help encourage drainage are helpful. While not usually serious these deep sinus infections can be quite painful and even make a person feel pretty sick at times. Your doctor, when he returns, should provide a treatment plan to resolve this, as well as supportive care for the symtoms. Hopefully this will resolve with conservative care.   I hope this is helpful to you. Good luck with this, and please follow up with us as needed.

author: MedStudent1  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Oct 30, 2008 1:08 am Gender: Female
title: Chronic nasopharyngitis
content: While my otolaryngologist is excellent (he's rated as one of the best in the country), there is one issue of mine he's been unable to solve.  I have one spot in my nasopharynx that produces excess mucous chronically, and is prone to frequent infection.  It had been hoped that removing my adenoids (and tonsils) would eliminate the problem, but it hasn't.  I have been unable to find much information on this condition in my medical texts, on pubmed, and elsewhere online.  The rest of my ENT history is unremarkable.  There is a single spot where my adenoids had been that is producing excess, very thick, ropey mucous.  This postnasal drainage leads to a chronic sore throat.  The thick mucous tends to build up over that spot, and when it is infected, every couple of days or so it will dry out and detach, going down my airway, causing me to cough it up.  What is coughed up is a very large, sticky, green and yellow gob of stuff, somewhat flattened like a scab, and can be up to an inch in diameter.    My doctor has told me that there is little that can be done if it continues after the adenoids have been removed... that existing treatments generally do not alleviate the problem, and that the best we can do is nasal rinses, and treat infections as they occur.  What little I've found tends to corroborate this, but the information appears fairly old and scanty.  I would really like to know if there is anything new that might be done to eliminate this problem.  I sing in a choir, and this condition frequently interferes with my ability to perform.  Also, whenever I get a cold, I automatically go into a bacterial bronchitis (and for the most part, the remainder of my respiratory system is healthy.. I am an athlete as well), and I have to wonder of this could be setting me up for that.    Additional things we have tried are proton pump inhibitors and antacids (even though I have no signs of gastroesophageal reflux), and  various nasal rinses and gargles.  These have included mupirocin in them.  I just want that spot to stop producing this crud and getting infected all the time.  This has been going on for years.  I expect your answers will be the same as his, but I thought I'd post here, just in case someone here knows something he doesn't.   --  -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- "I'll Never Let my Schooling Interfere with my Education." -Mark Twain, a.k.a. Samuel Clemens  "To have a right to do a thing is not at all the same as to be right in doing it." -Gilbert Keith Chesterton --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Chronic nasopharyngitis
content: Hello --  While your doctor apparently comes highly recommended, it seems he is stumped and has no great desire to find a solution to the problem. This is understandable when there is something that seemingly makes no sense, but I think there are some possible avenues that haven't been explored, and that a second opinion/consult might be in order. Your problem sounds fairly unremarkable, really. Chronic nasopharyngitis generally has an underlying cause, and your description of the mucus/phlegm that is brought up (and how it moves down) strongly suggests a chronic infection, possibly rooted in a cyst-like business where your adenoids were formerly attached. Many people who have adenoids removed have short-term improvement followed by unexpected problems such as you describe.   It is difficult to evaluate this at a distance and without appropriate studies, and even if that were possible,  I am not a doctor and certainly not an ENT specialist. I can only draw on what I know from my work with doctors who, for the most part, have not been specialists in this area either, but there is enough personal experience for me to be able to relate to the complaint, and to suggest that it may well be possible to improve or correct this, assuming proper diagnosis and especially location of the tissue which seems to remain chronically inflamed and probaly infected.   I hope you'll pursue a second opinion,  and even though your ENT is highly regarded, once a doctor had exhausted his ideas on a specific problem, it's often best seen through a new pair of eyes. This is my suggestion to you, and I highly recommend it.  Best of luck to you, and please do follow up with us as needed. Update us if anything changes, also.

author: calhob  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri Sep 19, 2008 12:46 pm Gender: Female
title: Can my ear ache be related to my hypothyroidism?
content: Hi, I've seen a lot of doctors and specialists over the past 6 months, trying to figure out what's causing my ear ache, fuzzy hearing, sensitivity to noise, and feeling of fullness and pressure inside my ear. The symptoms are similar to those of Meniere's, but I don't experience any extreme vertigo, just light dizziness at times. I've been on antibiotics, steroids and anti-inflammatories, none of which helped. My MRI and CAT scans both came back normal. During a routine physical, I just discovered that I have Hashimoto's disease. Can this be the cause of my ear problems?
posted_time: Post  by calhob » Fri Sep 19, 2008 12:58 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Can my ear ache be related to my hypothyroidism?
content: Hello --  There's no direct connection between Hashimoto's and Menier's (or your symptoms), but both Hashimoto's and Menier's can be caused by a common link, which is autoimmune response to something. Usually steroids are the therapy of choice for Menier's, while Hashimoto's seems to cause actual damage that steroids don't improve. The fact that your ear symptoms haven't improved with steroid therapy doesn't disallow Menier's, but is odd anyway. There are, however, other treatments for that and similar syndromes, and one of the most significant and effective ones is dietary restriction of salt. This sometimes brings about remarkable improvements. Also there has been some experimentation with streptomycin (which is toxic to nerve tissue in the inner ear in normal  doses). It's something  worth a second look.   I hope this is helpful to you. Good luck with this and please keep us updated.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Swollen ear cartlidge?
content: Hello -  First, the heart disease link, which has yet  to be adequately explained, involved having bilateral, vertical creases in the earlobes. This seems to have gone out  of fashion now, and never did enjoy any sort of cause-and-effect explanation. So you can set that one aside.  This swelling in your ear may have turned out to be providential, since it caused your doctor to find and treat an infection in the opposite ear, even though he didn't address the painful swelling. That is probably not actually the cartilage that is swollen and  painful, but a sebaceous gland in the skin. These often form unexpectedly and can be quite uncomfortable. Generally they either resorb or come to a head and drain on their own.  They can be quite uncomfortable, especially when you sleep on  the affected side. Application of moist, warm compresses (not hot) can sometimes help them to go away, and the antibiotic you're taking may also help with it, but they generally tend to run a benign if somewhat painful course, then  slowly go away.   I hope this is helpful. Good luck to you.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: lump on carotid artery
content: Hello -  While an actual lump on the carotid artery is unlikely, it is a place where a slightly misplaced lymph node could appear to be a lump in the carotid channel. I'm sure it feels as though  you can trace the artery manually and feel this lump as originating on the artery, and you of course may be right, but it seems highly unlikely. An ultrasound would clear this up, however, yes.   Meanwhile, two things must be noted: first, anything pressing on the carotid or up under the baroreceptor below your ear could be responsible for the ear symptoms and dizziness. Second, I notice you have a history of Hodgkins' disease, which means this lump definitely could be a lymph node. Either way it could be, since they are notorious for swelling, and there are others upstream from this location as well, and you could have an infection or this could indicate some recurrence of the earlier disease. Either way it needs to be checked. An ultrasound of the carotids would certainly not be out of order, and could clarify that impression one way or the other. If it's not a carotid lump (as I suspect it's not) then it would be appropriate to have a workup for both localized infection and possible recurrence of Hodgkins.   I hope this is helpful to you. Best of luck, and please keep us updated.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Ringing ear after cleaning
content: Hello, Irrigating an ear canal with a healthy eardrum should cause no problems with ringing.  In fact, if the cerumen impaction caused the ringing, it should improve with irrigation.  If the ringing persists, an audiologist can test the ear for hearing loss and if progressively worsens over a month's time then you may consider an MRI to rule out acoustic neuroma (a brain tumor that compromises the acoustic nerve).    But a trip to your family physician for re evaluation is the first step.  Keep us posted.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Throat, Phlegm, feels like something there
content: Hi there -  This is a common and  often difficult problem. It can be something as simple  as globus sensation, which is often ultimately unexplained but is sometimes psychogenic in origin, and associated with anxiety or sadness most often. It can also be due to nasopharyngeal exudate, which one might think would respond well to antihistimines, but of course since they dry secretions, this is not especially helpful. An expectorant such as guaifenisen (as Mucinex or its generic equivalent) may be helpful, along with making certain you're properly hydrated. You  might even try an atomizer to help moisten your throat (which was long ago a common practice among singers). You may also have mild asthma, which can, via a number of mechanisms, cause this problem. You mention the wheeze when you laugh, and this could be  suggestive of high bronchial constriction related to mild pharyngeal constriction as well. Asthma is often caused by gastroesophogeal reflux (GERD) which you apparently already have, so you are a candidate for asthma as well.  I would suggest a consult with an ear, nose and throat specialist who might be able to sort out these possibilities and help you find some relief. Short of that, hydration and  an expectorant are probably the simplest and handiest possible remedies.   I hope this is helpful. Good luck to you with this, and please follow up with us as necessary.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Cure for tinnitus.
content: Hello -  Tinnitus is an extremely common problem, but it can have many causes,  and so should be evaluated on an individual basis to be certain there isn't a more serious and/or treatable underlying condition. While tinnitus is generally seen as an inevitable part of aging (really long-term exposure to noise most often), you're far too young for that explanation to apply. You may have been exposed to loud noise anyway, and this sometimes happens to younger people due to industrial or musical overexposure to noise, but it also can be due to a number of treatable disorders -- or to nothing in particular. When it is the latter, sometimes niacin has been tried and supposedly sometimes helps, although there's no hard medical evidence for this. It can't hurt and might help. Of course if you're someone who uses common aspiring routinely (again, probably too young for that  to apply) this is another common and ofte-overlooked cause that can be removed in many cases.  It would be very helpful for you to be evaluated by an audiologist or neurologist to rule out any of the more serious causes (unless you know you've been exposed to high decibel levels for prolonged periods, and even then it would still be wise to try and save your hearing).   There is no "cure" out there, other than curing an underlying cause, despite what's advertised on line. As you suspect there are a lot of scam "cures" available, but they mostly do nothing and can sometimes cause other problems.   I hope this is helpful to you. Good luck with this, and follow up with us as needed.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Chronic Sinus Infections
content: Hello, Actually, these symptoms tend to be quite common however the exact cause often remains elusive.  Thyroid disease and anemia can cause fatigue so looking at thyroid hormone level (TSH and free T4) and complete blood count (CBC) are important. For chronic sinus infections, we often get a CT scan specifically of the frontal and maxillary sinuses.  Many migraine headache sufferers complain of all these symptoms. Watch migraine triggers including foods (eg caffeine, chocolate, MSG, nitrites,nuts,cheese) and avoiding frequent use (more than two days per month) of abortive migraine medicine (eg Fiorinal and triptans).  See your family physician for more definite diagnosis and help you to work through this.    Let us know how it goes.  Take care.

author: broadwaybabe1000  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Jan 22, 2009 7:12 pm Gender: Female
title: Thick, Gluey Saliva; Dry mouth; excess phlegm;......
content: I'm a 16 year old female; For maybe about a year now (estimate) I've had a constant need to clear my throat and excessive phlegm in my throat. I'm an aspiring singer, so this makes it very hard to even get through one song without stopping! It's become so frequent, that everyone around me seems to get really annoyed, but I can't help it!   Just recently I've also been experiencing really thick, sticky saliva and a dry mouth, which makes it hard to swallow...and it makes a really disgusting sound! I also seem to always get this sticky, dry saliva all over my lips and the corners of my mouth -- it's really embarrassing! What can I do to treat this?  thank you.
posted_time: Post  by broadwaybabe1000 » Thu Jan 22, 2009 7:19 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Thick, Gluey Saliva; Dry mouth; excess phlegm;......
content: Hello -  This must be really frustrating for you. I can think, just off hand, of a couple reasons why this may be happening. The most simple (and therefore most likely) one is local (or even general) dehydration, which will first dry up the more watery-type saliva which contains digestive enzymes (yes, the process starts soon as the food is in your mouth) while thickening the other type of saliva (these are produced by different sets of salivary glands) which is what you appear to be left with, the thick, serous type which is meant to aid in swallowing the bolus of food.   If you're doing a lot of singing practice you may be locally dehydrating your mouth. If you do, this eventually leads to loss of fluid generally, so increased fluid intake (and sometimes also using an atomizer to help hydrate the mouth and throat before practice sessions) may be necessary.  There are also some rather obscure conditons that can cause this sort of thing, but most of them are discovered early, in infancy, and are associated, usually, with some degree of developmental delay. However, there are variations on each end of the spectrum, so this is something you may want to bring to the attention of a doctor if increasing fluid intake doesn't help. You may be mouth-breathing more, simply because of your singing, or because of some faulty breathing habit or even a nasal blockage which dries up your oral mucosa during the night and leaves it that way during the day. Mouth breathing does cause loss of fluids, as does breathing in a dry environment. Winter or living in arid areas usually makes this worse, but also usually is compensated habitually from early on, unless one moves to a dry area from an area of more balanced humidity.  So the most likely cause is dryness itself, either due to your singing, due to a dry environment (which may be relatively new to you) or because of a failure of the parotid glands to produce enough of the more watery saliva which usually dilutes the thicker stuff.   I hope this is helpful to you. Best of luck with this and with your singing. Please follow up with us here as needed.
posted_time: Post  by John Kenyon, CNA » Sun Jan 25, 2009 8:52 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Inner Ear Canal Inflamation/High Alititudes
content: Hi -  If the inner ear problem is almost resolved, then if you give it a little time (a few days most likely) for it to totally resolve, then premedicate before you head for the highlands, it should be fine. Premedicating would include taking a couple courses of ibuprofin and meclazine (or Advil and Dramamine non-drowsy formula) prior to heading up and keeping both handy while you're there, just in case, although it really shouldn't depend too much on the altitude, since it was caused by inflammation (which was in turn caused by something, if not an infection).   Hope this helps. Please follow up as needed. Good luck to you.

title: far back side of tongue feels sore
content: The back right side of my tongue feels sore when I swallow or move it around.  I just went to the doctor on Saturday because my throat hurt a bit and my glands in my neck hurt as well as my ears,  and I tested positive for strep, though he said my throat didn't look bad and I had no fever.  The diagnosis he wrote was tonsillitis and gave me PenVee K since he said he was obligated to treat me for strep, though I could just be a carrier.  I am almost 3/4 of the way through w/my pills.  My throat started to feel near perfect and then last night I started to notice my tongue hurting when I swallow or move it.  Then again it's hard to tell if it's my throat or tongue now!  I do live in Austin, TX the cedar allergy city of the world.  I have very bad allergies and wonder if there is any correlation also.  Any ideas as to what this could be, should I be worried about the strep/tonsillitis re-emerging or just a plain ol' sore tongue?   I don't want to take more antibiotics for nothing!
posted_time: Post  by maiden75 » Fri Jan 16, 2009 4:08 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: far back side of tongue feels sore
content: Hi there -  The sensation of soreness at the back of the tongue  (where it starts to curve down into the pharynx) is often an illusion, and is freqeuently actually caused by irritation of the back of the throat (pharyngitis), which in turn is often caused by strep.   This could be a tongue-based soreness due to allergy (and  especially given where you live), but given your recent history it's more likely due to a recurrence of the strep,  which may have grown resistant to Pen-VK, which has been used so much for so long  that a lot of bacteria tend to laugh at it.   Regardless of your doctor's skepticism you deserve (and need) to have any potential strep infection cleared up. It may mean a  change of antibiotic. You should  at least have your throat looked at and cultured again. Sometimes this bug can be really obstinate.  Hope this helps. Best of luck to you with this, and please do follow up with us as needed.

title: Re: far back side of tongue feels sore
content: Thanks so much for always trying to reply to all of us!   It is truly appreciated.  The morning after I wrote my question, my tongue felt almost completely normal, and by the end of that day, it was fine.  Not sure if it was just sore, or if my throat was just just irritated from my constant "hacking" to clear post nasal allergy drip.  I work in an elementary school and the nurse that looked at it said my throat looked irritated on both sides and of course she said "just like everyone else, probably allergies."  I wrote another post here asking about the safety of claritin and other antihistimines because i just HAVE to take something. author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: far back side of tongue feels sore
content: I'm glad to hear the tongue/throat soreness cleared up so quickly. That sort of sensation usually does, but your throat is probably chronically irritated by the allergens.  If you have a lot of PVCs and PACs it can be pretty annoying (and anxiety-producing too, for a lot of people), but the newer antihistimines (such as Claritin -- generic is loratadine -- in particular) are pretty "safe" in terms of aggravating premature beats and arrhythmias. Just make certain you don't pick up Claritin-D, which contains psuedoephedrine (Sudafed), as this and other decongestants will definitely raise the blood pressure, increase cardiac output and produce more PVCs and PACs in those prone to them. The older antihistimines had a greater tendency to provoke these things, and pseudoephedrine definitely does (it's a lot like drinking a couple cups of coffee). Claritin/loratadine, Clarinex and Allegra( the latter two are still prescription, but there's a generic for Allegra now) are the least  likely to produce annoying side effects including premature heartbeats, drowsiness, etc. They will, of course, cause dry mouth because their purpose is to dry things out. They're you're best bet, however, for tackling these allergies without having too much else get stirred up in exchange. Oh, and also try to remember that although premature beats are annoying and feel weird, they are absolutely harmless (except emotionally, for those who get anxious when they start up).   I hope this is helpful too, and good luck to you with living in an area with such a potent airborne allergen. I've been there and discovered I'm affected as well. Not fun. Hang in there.

author: oscarwilde100  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Jan 13, 2009 11:55 pm Gender: Male
title: Samter's Triad - Nasal Polyps
content: Over the past 30 years, I have had 6 polypectomies and one Caldwell Luc (1986).  I have Samter's Triad with mild asthma and aspirin sensitivity.  After the first surgery in the 1970's, I did the skin testing and received the allergy shots for a couple of years with no improvement.  I have used a wide variety of antihistimanes and nasal inhalers and on occasion the bronchial inhalers.  The allergy doctor that I am seeing, took me off antihistamines and prescribed Zyflo CR which I take with Singulair, Advair 250 and Nasarel.  The polyps are back again and I have scheduled an appointment (next month) with a new ENT ( I recently moved).   I also developed a serious sinus infection from the polyps and I believe a fistula above a problem tooth.  I have read that there are theories that nasal polyps may be triggered by infections.   I went to urgent care and as prescribed predisone and amoxicillin for a short duration.  I have used this before through the years and I get better almost immediately and slowly worsen after the medication ends.  My question that I will take up with the ENT is it less "risky" to take the Predisone and possibly a low dose antibiotic every two months instead of the combination of drugs that seem to have a lesser affect on my disease.  I have annual liver function tests for the Zyflo, so I know there is a risk to that medication that is taken daily (600 mg tabs 2x2).  I have experimented with not taking the other medication when I am on the steroid and antibiotic and do not notice any affect.  I would utilize Advair and Nasarel daily.  I did start using the Zyflo about a year after my last polypectomy and some of the growth had returned so I don't know if the number of polyps is less this time but something triggers the reaction and they swell and get the resulting sinus infection.  The initial reaction and infection is always on the side with problem tooth (which I will have extracted after seeing the ENT).  Additional risk factor is the surgery which is now done with general anesthesia and proximate to the brain cavity and facial nerves which are a concern to me.
posted_time: Post  by oscarwilde100 » Wed Jan 14, 2009 12:27 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Samter's Triad - Nasal Polyps
content: Hello -  This does pose a number of problems that tend to cascade. Your idea of taking the steroids  pre-emptively and the antibiotic occasionally to tackle infections as they arise makes the most  sense to me. Taking them both at the same time is problematic because the steroids  tend to mask the symptoms  of infections until they've progressed quite a bit, but in your case if you can prevent the infections by discouraging the irritation that provokes the growth of polyps (and so creates new breeding ground for infection that otherwise wouldn't happen) you should be ahead of the game.  I'd present the idea to your doctor. Be  prepared for some resistance, as many doctors don't take  kindly to the patient trying  to "help" with the treatment plan, but this is a trend that is slowly turning around. I'd encourage you to ask for this option. It  can't be worse than what you already have to work with and might  well be a better approach. As I said, it makes sense -- it at least looks good on paper.  I hope this is helpful.  Good luck to you with this. Please follow up with us as needed.

title: Re: Small Painful Blisters on the back of throat.
content: Hello, The back of the throat sometimes contains crypts (hidden pockets).  Normally, they cause no problem and may house small particles of food.   You may have some crypts that have become irritated with food.   Try rinsing the throat with gargles after meals for a few days. If signs of infection arise (pain, redness, swelling, drainage) then see your family physician for evaluation of the throat.  Keep us posted.

author: jstorm  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri Jan 09, 2009 11:32 am Gender: Male
title: continuous popping after sinus and ear infection
content: im 43, male.  about two weeks ago i contracted what i thought was a cold in my sinuses.  the drainage became yellow after a couple days but i assumed it was viral so i just treated with OTC drugs that usually work for me to manage symptoms.  they didnt work and i was constantly congested in my head (not chest) and could get only minor temporary relief from steam.  i was blowing my nose constantly, lots of drainage and had horrible sleep for 3 nights in a row because i could only breathe through my mouth and was up regularly blowing brownish/yellow crud out.  because of the repeated blowing (with resistance from mucus membrane swelling near shut), i started getting some ear popping when i was blowing and then my left ear started to feel irritated and became blocked from sound.  i suspected ear infection (never had one before) so i went to my PCP (internal med) and he said the drum was red and swollen "classic ear infection presentation".  he prescribe amoxicillin for 10 days.  the sinus pressure relieved almost immediately (the day after) and today (one week later) my sinuses feel back to normal and clear.  however, my ear tube is completely blocked and i still blow that sticky yellow gunk out of my nose at least once every hour or so - more when i'm bending over and active (i'm doing some inside house painting).  the more concerning thing is that every time i swallow or blow (even lightly) my ear pops.  the ear canal feels a bit more irritated than when I started the antibiotics and probably a little more pressure.  since i'm 7 days into my the amoxicillin, should i be concerned if nothing changes when i'm through with it in 3 more days (still plugged, irritated and blowing out yellow crud)?  i do have a high frequency hearing loss in this ear and for the past several years have had strange intermittant periods (a day or a few days) of feeling deaf in that ear and then it clears up and is normal (just high pitch and low volume hearing loss - wispers and crickets are inaudible)
posted_time: Post  by jstorm » Fri Jan 09, 2009 12:01 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: continuous popping after sinus and ear infection
content: Hello, Popping sound in the ears are due to pressure changes withing the middle ear and withing the eustacian tube.  These are normal and common occurences with and after upper respiratory infections.   It would be good to ask your physician to look at the ear again to make sure the infection has cleared.  Sinuses and middle ears are hard for antibiotics to reach so longer duration or higher dosage are needed.   Sometimes the infected fluid behind the eardrum clears but the fluid remains in the middle ear. It will resolve with time.  May still have popping in ears.  Let us know how things go.

author: Tamorama  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Jan 14, 2009 10:54 am Gender: Female
title: ENT questions RE: GERD and Sinus issues
content: Hello!  I have a few related questions:  1. I have GERD - since I can't have natural chocolate - can I have artifically flavored chocolate? (Like Swiss Miss Hot Cocoa?)  2. Right after I was diagnosed with GERD, I was also diagnosed with asthma and chronic Rhinitis? Are they all related?   3. Whenever I take the typical drugs for GERD (Prevacid, Aciphex) - then I have trouble swallowing because it makes me constipated and food stays in my stomach too long. I end up just taking Zantac 2X a day instead and I feel better. Is that a normal reaction to those PPI medications? Is there a way around it?  4. I have hiatal hernia. I was told if I lose weight it could go away. Is hiatal hernia similar to what women get when they are very pregnant and complain of heartburn very often?
posted_time: Post  by Tamorama » Wed Jan 14, 2009 11:11 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: ENT questions RE: GERD and Sinus issues
content: Hello, 1. Some foods like chocolate, alcohol, peppermint, caffeine, and fatty food may decrease the tone of the lower esophageal sphincter and contribute to gastric reflux.  I do not know which component of chocolate does this... so not much help on the Swiss Miss.  2. Yes. Asthma and GERD can be related.  The basic idea is that some gastric secretions may work their way up the esophagus and toward the bronchial tree causing a bronchial response ie asthma.  This occurs more at night in the recumbent position.   3.  Yes, these drugs (proton pump inhibitors) can cause constipation and abdominal pain. 4. A hiatal hernia is named for the occurence when the stomach (a pouch) works its way up through the diaphragm.  Normally, the esophagus alone is supposed to occupy this particular opening.  When the stomach herniates (literally: to protrude through an abnormal body opening) more secretions are likely to enter the esophagus and to the back of throat causing a brackish taste.  Pregnancy and obesity both add more abdominal pressure on the stomach pushing it upward against the diaphragm and increases the chance of hiatal hernia.  Hope this helps.  Keep us posted on how things work out.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Fri Jan 16, 2009 6:34 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Neck Pains After Slight Altercation.
content: Hi there -  There are so many interdependent structures in the area where you were struck, and so many possibilities for chronic injury, especially since the symptoms are now more than a week and a half old, that I would definitely suggest seeing a doctor about this. You could have anything from a cheek fracture (nothing to get excited about if that's the case), to misalignment of your jaw (more likely and with much more potential to cause major aggravations), with a lot of other things in between.   By all means bring this to a doctor's attention. If it had resolved off the pain meds in a few days that would be different. At this late date I wouldn't look for it to just go away on its own, nor should it be allowed to now.  Best of luck to you, and please follow up with us as needed.

author: kidwave  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Jan 10, 2009 10:36 am Gender: Male
title: Sneezed out a chunk of flesh.
content: Male 39. I had been in bed for 4 days with a bad cold and strep throat(which i get much to often). Taking 500 mg of Amoxicillin (6hr periods) since 2nd day.  Yesterday,(day 5) I was seeming to clear up and feel better. I was blowing my nose, rather agressively i admit, to try to remove meucus.  A few times it was quite a lot and VERY thick. Suddenly while blowing very hard a chunk of flesh came out(right side). I am positive it is flesh and NOT meucus. It did not hurt at all and i did not bleed afterwards. My right nasal passage feels "more than just clear". Needles to say this freaked me out. I cleaned the piece and took some photos and noticed there were blood vessels in it. I called my sister who is an RN and she said if i was not bleeding and not in pain I would probably be ok. After sleeping through last night, I am still in no pain and there is still no blood. Im just wondering what this is and why this happened. I have never had ANY health issues to speak of other than the unusual frequency of strep. Am i going to start having Sinus issues?  Did I just sneeze out important parts of my Sinus because i was blowing to hard? should i be afraid to sneeze now? Basically, What the hell just happened?
posted_time: Post  by kidwave » Sat Jan 10, 2009 10:53 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Sneezed out a chunk of flesh.
content: Hello -  I think your sister is right, and I strongly suspect that what came out was probably a peduncular polyp which had a very slim (and possibly dead) stalk. These things cause a lot of sinus problems and if one is removed, there is often a sudden sense of the passage being "more than clear." It had probably been in there for a long time and may have either torn loose or, as I suggested earlier, may have lost its blood supply due to the stalk having been twisted or just too slim.   I'd mention it to a doctor and maybe even (if you still have the evidence) show it to a doctor, but given where it came from and the subsequent open-ness, I'm pretty sure you blew out a pendulous polyp. If so,  that's all to the good and may have solved some future problems and even saved you some money.   Hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you. Please follow up with us as needed.
posted_time: Post  by John Kenyon, CNA » Wed Jan 14, 2009 11:27 am

author: SLSCaregiver  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Wed Jan 07, 2009 2:40 am Gender: Female
title: Nose bleeds following Head Injury
content: I work in a Supported Living Services environment for mentally disabled adults, my client (moderate-severe mental retarded) suffered from a head injury 5 days ago, she fell on her head board which produced a deep laceration across her forehead which required 8 staples. She went to the emergency room right after this incident and got the staples in place. Its been five days now, and since the initial impact, she's been having nose bleeds each night for the past 3 nights. These nose bleeds would just occur spontaneously with no provocation of the nose.   I was reading a bit online and came across possibility of a " skull fractures" in her frontal lobe, and or maybe high blood pressure.  Should I bring her to the hospital? Is there anything I can do to help the situation?  Because of her disability, it is hard to determine whether her symptoms are natural or in an effort to gain attention.   However, I have been observing her lately, and she seems like she is more off balanced, she seems more confused and she is restless, she has trouble sleeping at night, she wakes up a lot throughout the night.   Do you have any advice of what I should do in this situation?   Thank You for your help!
posted_time: Post  by SLSCaregiver » Wed Jan 07, 2009 3:03 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Nose bleeds following Head Injury
content: Hi there -  While your patient's behavior could, in part, be due to a wish for attention, this could be warranted, since she may be having symptoms she's unable to communicate to you directly. That said, I don't think spontaneous nosebleeds are a deliberate attempt to communicate, and since they follow a head injury, they are very  possibly related to that injury and should be evaluated on an urgent basis. She could have a concussion at least, and possibly a fracture or other injury below the superficial one.   I think there are enough apparent neurological symptoms, in addition to the nosebleeds, to warrent taking her to the emergency room ASAP. Please either do this or have her taken there by ambulance for evaluation, since it appears there was no in-depth neurological eval done at the time the injury was treated.  Hope this is  helpful. Please keep us updated.
posted_time: Post  by John Kenyon, CNA » Thu Jan 08, 2009 8:31 pm

author: SLSCaregiver  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Wed Jan 07, 2009 2:40 am Gender: Female
title: Re: Nose bleeds following Head Injury
content: Thank You for your reply. When my patient went to the hospital for her staples, she went through Xray and MRI which showed no sign of fractures or breaks, and just a day ago, she stopped having those nose bleeds. I think due to the heater being on in this dry climate, it could have been a factor in the cause of her nose bleeds. A day ago, I turned the heater off during the night and she didn't have another episode.   Could something else have been responsible? Should we still get her checked out?   Thanks
posted_time: Post  by SLSCaregiver » Fri Jan 09, 2009 1:28 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Nose bleeds following Head Injury
content: Hello and you're very welcome.  If x-ray and MRI studies revealed no fractures or other underlying injuries, then that pretty well rules out those possibilities. The fact that your patient has been in a room with an auxilliary heater (and this is something a lot of us are suffering from now), that is a very likely cause of the nosebleeds, as it dries the nasal mucus membranes and the capilaries break at random.   So long as there are no behavioral signs that something is wrong (and it is difficult, I'm sure, to infer from this patient when that may be happening), she's probably fine. The two other (cardinal) signs you should watch for, and which should have passed by this point, would be unusual periods of sleeping and unexpected vomiting. The farther from the time of the injury, the less likely these are to be indicative of any intracranial problem.  I think you've solved your riddle regarding the nosebleeds. I hope everything else is well. Good luck with this and please keep us updated.

I am thinking that perhaps this injury has caused internal physiological damage, could this be possible too?  Also, she scratched off 2 of the 8 staples that were on her forehead covering the suture, and is now bleeding, should I recommend that she just gets those staples off? or do you think stitches would be a better alternative? content: Hi again -  Well it was a good idea anyway. An even better alternative, if it's workable with this wound, would be to glue it (the surgical equivalent of Super Glue), which is least likely to be picked apart and which leaves generally the least scarring.  Let us know how things turn out.

author: teachnic  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Jan 03, 2009 7:18 am Gender: Female
title: Chronic Sinus Problems after Antibiotics
content: Beginning about 2 months ago, I started having normal sinus problems (sore throat, dizziness, pressure, ear pain, etc). Went to the doctor and got a Z-pack and some shot to clear the symptoms (can't remember what it was). Symptoms somewhat subsided for a couple weeks, and then came right back. Went back to the doctor and got Augementin and steriods. Felt MUCH better while on the steriods, but (literally) the day I got off, immediately felt awful again....sore throat, severe congestion, cough, headache.   I am also having a lot of trouble at night. Can't fall asleep, wake shortly after and just toss and turn. I'm not waking because of any symptoms, just waking and very restless....these are very unlike me.   After 2 antibiotics, shots, and steriods, I'm worried something else may be wrong. I have allergies, but am on Allegra-D which has kept them under control (and I have no sneezing or allergy like symptoms). I have had a CT scan of my sinuses several months ago and they have not shown anything irregular. Please help!
posted_time: Post  by teachnic » Sat Jan 03, 2009 7:29 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Chronic Sinus Problems after Antibiotics
content: Hi there -  This is a fairly common course by which chronic sinus problems start, after an acute infection. There is often a blocked sinus involved, although not always. A CT of the sinuses can often be helpful in determining if there is something preventing proper drainage (and so giving bacteria a place to keep regrowing). Since you had one months ago,  a followup one would certainly be reasonable now.  Also, and only in my own humble opinion (although it is supported by many doctors as well), using steroids to treat an infection in order to mitigate symptoms is not generally a good idea, even though I'm seeing it and hearing about it being done more and more often. Many times the results are the same as you experienced: soon  as the steroids are withdrawn the symptoms return with a vengeance, because the steroids compromise the immune system somewhat, while not actually killing any microbes. Just a thought.  Again, a followup CT of the sinuses would be in order, and definitely a referral to an ENT specialist for consult and possibly creative treatment to clear this up once and for all. I'm guessing the end of the course of steroids would have been a couple weeks ago, so between that (which could have disrupted your sleep cycle even this far along) and the residual annoying symptoms, so these are probably the reasons for your difficulies with sleep. Then again it may just be coincidental.   I hope this is helpful to you. Please follow up with us here as needed.
posted_time: Post  by John Kenyon, CNA » Sun Jan 04, 2009 8:20 pm

author: sevenhm  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Dec 30, 2008 1:14 pm Gender: Male
title: Breathing out of only one nostril alternates
content: Most of the time it seems like I'm only breathing out of one nostril while the other is blocked, is this normal?
posted_time: Post  by sevenhm » Tue Dec 30, 2008 1:20 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Breathing out of only one nostril alternates
content: Hi -  This is not normal, but it is relatively common. It can be caused by either a nasal polyp or a deviated septum. If this has been a lifelong problem it could be a septum deviated since birth. If there have been lots of colds and sinus infections over the years it could be a polyp, as these are often created by unequal pressures and hard blowing of the nose. It can be determined easily enough by an ENT  specialist and a handy little light to look up in there and see what's in the way.   I hope this is helpful. Good luck to you.

title: Ear pain with base of head,molar, and eye pain
content: Hello everyone,  About 2 weeks ago I had cold like symptoms, Full and runny nose, cough, congestion. These symptoms went away after 4-5 days. 2-3 days latter I started geting a dull ache in my left ear and it hurt to touch. I thought it was a common ear infection. Then something weird happened 4 days ago. I was having sex with my wife and upon ejaculation i experienced SEVER pain at the base of my head and neck, both ear canals started throbing, my molars hurt as if I had a cavity and I had sever pain behind my eyes. My mouth tasted bitter. The pain lasted for about 4 hours, subsiding slowly. the pain was so bad I vomited. the pain or discomfort to remain was to my ear canals. So I thought it was a ear infection...but today the ear pain was gone, the ear was just sensitive tot he touch. so I wanted to test out ummm how do you say, my ability to have sex. so I tried to masturbate, with in minutes the pain came back, this time with a pressure in my head. I am not sure what this is, and I am a little scared. I want to go see the doctor but I am living in malaysia (I am an American) and i have found the level of care not that good. Plus I only know of ONE ENT in all of Malaysia, even though I am sure there are more. If I could get some advice on this so that when I go into see the doctor I am armed with some knowledge. posted_time: Post  by slylock » Wed Dec 31, 2008 3:50 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Ear pain with base of head,molar, and eye pain
content: Hello -  Given your relatively isoloated situation (medically at least) you first probably don't want to aggravate whatever this is any more. Secondly, when you see some doctor (and an ENT may not be what you're needing at this point) you're going to want to rule out (or in) the most serious possibilites first. Since sexual activity produces a number of physical consequences (unrelated to one's enjoyment) which are normally unremarkable, this could become a problem.  First, the symptoms you describe could involve the temporary increase in intracranial pressure (ICP), the increase in blood pressure (BP), or the postural  pressure on cervical and cranial nerves. The possibilities are listed in descending order of potential seriousness. The first two usually go hand-in-hand.  If  something has happened inside your head which is affected by increased BP or ICP, this could be a serious problem. If what's going on  is related to postural stresses and is  causing nerve irritation (you do state the ear was sensitive to the touch and had probably been involved in the recent upper respiratory infection) this may be just a very "raw" nerve irritated by some residual effects of the infection, which seems to have now cleared up. If this is so then the problem may not be as potentially serious, but the effects suggest something more, such as an inflammation of a cranial nerve (perhaps, most worrisome, the oropharyngeal nerve). It is of course impossible to be remotely certain at such a distance, but since this seems to be a new  and possibly emergent problem,  I'd suggest you find yourself at least a competent MD to do as comprehensive a neurological check on you as is possible. An ENT exam by a general practitioner should be adequate by now if this is, in fact, an ENT issue, since the problem  should be readily visible or palpable by now. What we want to make certain is that it isn't more central.  Hope  this is helpful to you. Best of luck and please follow up with us as needed.

author: xtrace  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sat Nov 01, 2008 11:56 am Gender: Male
title: 8 month long cough
content: Please help. I have had a dry persistent cough for going on 8 months now. It only is in the morning for about 5 to 10 min. I don,t smoke. I am a 29 year old pretty healthy male. I got a cold one day about 8 months ago and the cough never went away after everything else did.
posted_time: Post  by xtrace » Sat Nov 01, 2008 12:01 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: 8 month long cough
content: Hi there -  This sort of cough can become chronic if the mucus membranes of the sinuses and nasal passages are chronically irritated, which can be due to allergies, dust and mold, or just dry air (as from forced air heat, etc.). All these situations provoke the mucus membranes to produce thin, clear mucus which drains post-nasally during the night when one is lying horizontal, and in the morning there is often a tickling, dry, unproductive cough that can be quite irritating. Trying one of the "non-drowsy" antihistamines for a while prior to bedtime might help a good deal.   This problem also can sometimes be caused by mild gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which is also most active during sleep. If an antihistimine trial doesn't help you might want to have this evaluated, as it may be due to GERD, which can sometimes actually eventually produce a form of asthma.  Hope this is helpful to you. Please follow up here as needed.
posted_time: Post  by John Kenyon, CNA » Thu Jan 01, 2009 11:10 am

author: TheKeg  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Sun Dec 21, 2008 12:14 am Gender: Male
title: Mucus Retention Cyst in Left Maxillary Sinus
content: Hello,  I have been having constant headaches since the beginning of October.  The pain was mainly in the back and sides of my heads (more towards the back).  I have been through 3 doctors, 1 hospital, 1 MRI and about 8 or 9 different medications.  The first doctor put me on Epidrin and Prednisone 2.5mg for migraines.  A few days later those didn't help, so I called back the doctor and he wrote me for Prochlorperazine, which caused me to have no control over my tongue or jaw muscles after 3 days of taking it.    All the rest of the medications proved no help at all.  I have taken lortab 7.5mg, 10mg, and Percocet 10mg because the pain has been so intense.  It has gotten to the point where the pain is so high that I wake up in the middle of the night from it.  I got the MRI on December 4th of this year and was told that I have:  FINDINGS: "4.  The visualized paranasal sinuses demonstrate partial opacification of the left maxillary sinus which appears to be a mucus retention cyst rather than an acute inflammatory process.  A small area of partial opacification of the left sphenoid sinus is seen.  minimal mucosal thickening of the right ethmoid air cell is seen."  Ever since Sunday, December 13, I have been getting sicker.  It started out with a sore throat and moved on to coughing up phlegm about 20 times a day.  Also my nose has been stuffy and runny all the time and have been blowing out a lot of clear snot.  The phlegm started out as a medium-dark green but is now basically clear.  Is it possible that the mucus retention cyst could be the cause of me being sick?  I have been going crazy for the past 2 and a half months because I don't know what's wrong.  I've been told that the cyst couldn't be causing my headaches and that it was just stress, but I believe there is something more to my headaches and my symptoms.  I Appreciate your time for reading this.  All thanks,    TheKeg
posted_time: Post  by TheKeg » Sun Dec 21, 2008 12:27 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Mucus Retention Cyst in Left Maxillary Sinus
content: Hello -  While it's rare for a mucus retention cyst to become infected, they can, and they also can also can cause secondary sinus infections by way of blocking the drainage of the sinus cavity involved. Its sounds as though this is what's happened in your case, although blood work (a CBC) would be helpful in ascertaining you have a bacterial infection up in there. While the location of the headache pain is  off base for this sort of problem, it still is very likely, given the other symptoms, that this is the root cause at least.   Have you been running a fever at all? This would also be highly suggestive of a sinus infection or infected cyst.   It's pretty clear you're not having migraines, so it's hard to understand why any of these doctors wouldn't at least go for the next most logical explanation and try treating this as an infection, especially now that you have these symptoms. The colorful discharge you had at first is pretty obviously due to an infection. Now that it's clear it's a little more difficult to know based just on the description, but I strongly suspect you have a blocked sinus due to this cyst and it's causing global headaches at this  point.   I hope this helps. Best of luck to you. Please follow up here as needed, and update us if anything new comes to light.

author: Skye  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Thu Dec 25, 2008 12:19 am Gender: Male
title: Hemp Allergy
content: So, my girlfriend is allergic to hemp. She was wondering if this can translate into an allergic reaction if she smoked marijuana (she's never smoked before) as a result, and how serious it could be. There's no reliable info about this online, and I don't want her to get hurt. I hope you'll answer this, and thank you! Just looking for some info.
posted_time: Post  by Skye » Thu Dec 25, 2008 12:24 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Hemp Allergy
content: Hi there -  Coming from a strictly clinical point of view, my answer, also intended to keep your girlfriend from getting hurt, is that while it might not cause an allergic reaction or only a mild one, allergic reactions are utterly unpredictable (especially first-time ones), and I can't in good conscience tell you your girlfriend could not have a serious anaphylactic reaction, because she could. She well might not, but she could. Marijuana is relatively benign as a substance, but allergies change everything.   My advice to her (or to you, to pass along) is that the risk of anaphylaxis would be tantamount to playing Russian roulette. Since marijuana isn't necessary to life  but breathing is, I'd not try it if I were her.  Hope this is helpful to you. Good luck.

author: Solid1911  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Dec 24, 2008 11:28 am Gender: Male
title: Dime sized white spot on throat/mouth
content: Hi,  Well, I have waited a week having these symptoms, but this is starting to get annoying and does not seem to be getting better.  Maybe you can shed some light on this...  Last week I had a pretty bad cold, to the point where I felt physically sick and had to miss work.  Usually with a cold I am able to function, but last week it was intense.  I had massive discharge from my sinuses, coughing, etc.  I lived on Nyquil as I could not sleep without it.  So midway last week as the symptoms were lessening, I woke up in the morning with what felt like a sore throat.  I thought it was post-nasal drip as it had the same feeling.  I shrugged it off as nothing.  The "feeling" lessened during the day.  The next day I woke up with the same feeling.  A very dry mouth/throat and pain from the same spot.  This time, it felt like there was something kind of stuck there.  I went to the mirror and looked in to find a dime or smaller sized white spot.  It is like a very large cancer sore (which I am prone too) almost crater like and nearly perfectly round.    So, I thought it was a cancer sore.  I have dealt with it since last week and it has not gotten any better.  I have this white spot, red on the edges located on the back of my mouth near my throat.  I can feel it with the VERY back of my tongue, as my tongue rubs it when I move it upwards.  It is not really in the throat, but the VERY back of my mouth.  It does not hurt "badly" when I swallow, but did when it first appeared.  There is really only pain when I wake up in the morning otherwise, it is just annoying.    It just does not seem like it is getting better.  I have no other symptoms (re: cold) now and am just wondering if this is a big annoying cancer sore or some sort of infection that I should worry about.  Oh, it does not hurt when I eat or swallow.  Strangely, the only thing that really "hurts" (like a 2 -3 on a scale of 10) is if I drink water or very cold things.    Anyways, please let me know.  I have no insurance and really cannot afford going to a Dr. during the holiday season unless it is super-necessary.  Thanks!
posted_time: Post  by Solid1911 » Wed Dec 24, 2008 11:46 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Dime sized white spot on throat/mouth
content: Hello-  What you're describing does sound like an outsized canker sore (apthout stomatitis) and the size concerns me a little, but they can get pretty large sometimes. It may also be candida albicans (a fungal infection) however. Try gargling with salt water or hydrogen peroxide (and, if you can find it, apply Gly-Oxide directly to the sore). If this doesn't resolve within a few days you'll need to have it looked at, as if it is candida it can possibly get into the bloodstream and cause more serious problems. Hopefully this will resolve shortly on its own or maybe a little sooner with the suggestions above.  Hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you.
