author: FF_EMT6556  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Dec 27, 2008 2:50 pm Gender: Male
title: Temporary Loss of Smell When Fighting Resiratory Illness
content: I have found that sometimes while fighting an upper respiratory infection, I temporarily lose my sense of smell.  It my most current battle I am fighting bronchitis.  I was wondering if there is any way to speed the restoration of my sense of smell?    Randy Sizemore FFII / NREMT-I85
posted_time: Post  by FF_EMT6556 » Sat Dec 27, 2008 2:57 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Temporary Loss of Smell When Fighting Resiratory Illness
content: Hi Randy -  First, let me just salute a fellow FFII/EMT (although I'm no longer on the NR and after 40 years don't do much with hose and ladders anymore).   Now then: what you describe is a very common problem, and there's no generally recognized way to speed up the process. However, it's also true that people who work in the fire/EMS business (and certain other fields) are often exposed to both noxious atmospheres and dry air (from SCBA) so we are more prone to suffer noticeable olfactory deficits when we come down with respiratory infections.   Probably the most effective maintainance for the olfactory process is to maintain humidification (nebulizer with pure water is sometimes helpful and would also help break up bronchial congestion).  Wish I could tell you something better. Good luck to you and keep up the great work.

author: labtechmom  Guest Posts: 5 Joined: Mon Aug 20, 2007 1:44 am
title: parotide gland infection
content: Hi, my 3 year old daughter has been experiencing strange things.  For the last 5 months, it happened 6 times.  I would put her to bed, perfectly fine, and a couple of hours (2-3) after, she would wake up screaming.  When I get to her room, the right side of her face is VERY swollen.  Her mouth is so streched, she barely can talk! The lump is rock-hard and is very painful and she has fever.  I brought her to ER and they treated her for acute parotidis with antibiotics and told me it is very rare and should not come back...just to see that exactly 4 weeks after it comes back again!  We have seen a ENT that tols us it was probably Reccurent parotidis of childhood and it would go away when she grows (around 12-13 years)  But in the meanwhile, to treat each infections with antibiotics.  The fact that she already had it 6 times + the fact that we might have to face this for the next 10 years, I am very worried that she will develop antibiotic resistance.  The last episode needed 3 times 10 day treatment with different antibiotics.  Is there anything else we could do to prevent this?  (Also, I noticed it comes every 4 weeks...is that typical?)  Thank-you

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: parotide gland infection
content: Hi there -  This  is something that seems to have been more common in the past than it is now, but I don't know why that is. Sometimes a child may have an anatomical anomaly that causes the parotid gland or glands (as the case may be) to not be able to drain properly, or there may be some infection above the site (an abcessed tooth, in some cases) which causes this to become chronic. They do seem to outgrow it eventually, but this is now. It would be helpful if the primary cause of this could be located and corrected.  As for the concerns about antibiotics,  the greatest problem there is simply that bacteria becomes resistant to certain antibiotics and then get into the general population. It's not so much a problem of a given patient becoming vulnerable to the bacteria involved, which are always present anyway. For these reasons it's important to rotate antibiotics or at least alternate them when there's a chronic or recurrent infection.   Meanwhile, if the infections continue to recur you may want  to look for a second opinion, since a fresh pair of eyes may help isolate the underlying cause of the infections (and there usually is one but it may be difficult to isolate).  I hope this is helpful to you. Good luck to you and your little girl. Please keep us updated.

content: Raised wbc count - @guest51  Probably due to Otitis media (middle ear infection)  Ruptured ear drum and fluid are the factors highly in its favor. author: brookie03  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Oct 30, 2008 9:30 am Gender: Female
title: Youth Tinnitus and Allergies
content: My daughter is 5 years old and has seen her PCP reguarly since she was born. She has never had any medical problems other than the common cold and once having an ear infection.  In late Sept. 08 she began this hard sniffing through her nose. It is like when someone doesn't blow the nose they sniff it back up instead. The sniffing sounded very dry and when I had her attempt to blow her nose nothing would come out. The "sniffing" got louder and harder over a few days. One day she explained to me that there was a constant buzzing noise in both her ears and by "sniffing" it gives her some relief from the buzzing.   Took her to her PCP on Oct. 2 and he checked her ears, throat, nose, and eyes. He then said she has Allergies and this is causing the Tinnitus. He said she will have to learn to cope. She was prescribed Zyrtec and Nasonex to take once daily. He also said we will do a follow up in 6 months to determine whether the Zyrtec would be continued at that time, but for now she must take it once a day.  On Oct.17 she came home from school running a low fever, the fever stuck with her throughout the weekend and on mon. Oct 20 we were at the doctor's office. She was diagnosed with a sinus infection and prescribed an antibiotic (cefdinir) to take for ten days. She completed the cycle yesterday. The fever is gone, which it has been for awhile now.   Since her first appointment the ear noise has gotten louder and she is having lots of trouble coping with it. She calls her ears ugly and thinks that when she speaks others hear what she hears, which makes her call her voice ugly. I have also caught her hitting her ears so the noise would stop.   I am at a loss, I am unsure whether to get a second opinion from a specialist or to stick it out for the 6 months and hope that the Zyrtec will provide the relief she needs.   Thank you
posted_time: Post  by brookie03 » Thu Oct 30, 2008 10:17 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Youth Tinnitus and Allergies
content: Hello -  A second opinion probably wouldn't be a bad idea. While the prescriptions were appropriate, they obviously haven't resolved the entire problem, and one Catch-22 involved in treating sinus infections with antihistimines is that while they suppress the production of secretions,they also have a drying effect, so that what secretions are produced don't flow easily, resulting in thick pooling in the sinuses, which in many patients only serves to provide a breeding ground for the next infection. It also leaves the head feeling stuffy and can cause problems with the inner ear, including tinnitus and vertigo. So while they work, they sometimes also work against themselves.   At this point your daughter seems quite uncomfortable with some of the rather typical annoying symptoms that sometimes come with chronic sinus problems, and a fresh pair of eyes might be a good idea. An ENT specialist would be a very appropriate choice at this point. Perhaps the PCP will even be willing to provide a referral, since a young child won't  tolerate this sort of aggravation for six months, and it seems to not be improving much if at all,even  though the infection, for now at least, seems to be  knocked down.  I hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you and your daughter.

author: jason90  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Sep 04, 2008 11:13 am Gender: Male
title: Chronic sinusitis and fatigue
content: Hello. I am an 18-yr-old male and I have been recently experiencing unusual symptoms. I went to my doctor about a week ago because of lightheadedness, dizziness, headache (isolated to right side of the head, temple area), and eye-twitching (all of which had started about two weeks prior to my doctor visit). I of course assumed the worst, was expecting a neurological problem especially because my mother passed away two years ago from brain cancer. Well, I had an EKG, normal; bloodwork, normal (slightly high potassium but was retested in different lab and results were perfectly fine); and MRI without contrast, normal EXCEPT for inflamed sinuses. Doctor diagnosed sinusitis. I looked up acute and chronic sinusitis and my symptoms actually seemed to fit very well, even the eye-twitching (because of nerves that run through/around the sinuses and, if irritated, can produce muscle spasms). I was put on a 10-day regimen of Augmentin (which I am due to finish this weekend). The lightheadedness has pretty much subsided, but I still don't feel right. My biggest problem now is fatigue, almost as if my head is so heavy I just want to drop it and sleep all day- I am getting plenty of rest, usually at least 9 hours a night but I wake up in the morning, then, three hours later, am ready to sleep again. I took a three-hour nap yesterday after having slept for 10 hours and still felt so drowsy. Oddly though, it seems to get better in the evening, perhaps because that's when I'm "supposed" to feel tired and so I don't notice the fatigue as much. I also have random muscle twitching throughout my body (I've had this for a while though, and am not overly concerned because I understand benign muscle twitching is actually quite common and it seems like the more I think about it the more anxiety I will get [and the more often it will occur]). However, what I have also noticed is that I often feel like my whole body is vibrating or tingling, in a way, especially when I am relaxing or about to sleep [again, more noticable when I am thinking about it, but I am sure it isn't psychological]. Sometimes I will wake up suddenly in the night and feel like I'm trembling [this is a recent symptom], but it isn't actually outwardly visible. Sometimes I almost feel like my brain is vibrating, as weird as it sounds, and I feel like my head is pounding, like I am suddenly VERY aware of the blood pumping through my head. My headaches are less frequent and not that painful, but when I get them, they are still only on the right side and often radiate down to my neck (sometimes I feel like they may be starting from the neck). I find myself cracking my neck a lot to try to relieve tension/pain, also cracking/popping my jaw seems to help temporarily. Also, and I don't know if this is just because of anxiety over my symptoms and/or my medication, but my feces has been VERY loose, sometimes diarreah, for the past two weeks, and very frequent [4-5 times a day]. Appetite has also been a little less than usual, but still ok, and I've been trying to stay well-hydrated.  My biggest concerns right now are whether or not this could still be neurological and, if it is only sinusitis, how to manage fatigue. I have been doing some research on chronic sinusitis and have read that often aniobiotics work poorly or not at all, and oftentimes it is either viral or fungal. I even read multiple articles published a few years back about how chronic fatigue may be one of the biggest indicators of an undiagnosed sinus issue (this seems plausible to me because I have had allergies my whole life and a stuffy-nose feeling for many years, but no discharge) I have all sorts of crazy worries, like MS, fibromyalgia, some sort of brain infection (can sinus infection spread there?), chronic fatigue syndrome....I just don't know what to do especially because my symptoms seem to fit chronic sinustis very well but also a multitiude of other things. Should I also look into Chiari malformation (there has been a case of spina bifida in my family, grandma on mother's side lost a child to severe spina bifida upon birth)? Or would that have been very evident on an MRI? Also I noticed for a few days a couple weeks ago I kept smelling this kind of grape smell, but that has just randomly stopped happening. If anything, I am having problems smelling because my nose feels perpetually clogged or narrowed.   I would appreciate any input you have! I am especially anxious about this because I am leaving for college this weekend and do not want to have to deal with these symptoms. I am strongly considering having an appointment with an ENT, but, until then, would like any suggestions. Thanks!  ~Jason
posted_time: Post  by jason90 » Thu Sep 04, 2008 11:52 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Chronic sinusitis and fatigue
content: Hi Jason -  From your description of the symptoms I'd say you sound like someone who is essentially healthy, somewhat anxious (probably in no small part due to the untimely passing of your mother), and probably have a blocked deep sinus which may well  be infected. You've done your research well, and it's true that sometimes a sinus infection  can cause most (but not all) the symptoms that concern you and that antibiotics are sometimes not especially effective (particularly in cases of deep sinus infections and where there is a blockage due to enlarged turbinate or polyp formation). Sometimes these things need to be corrected surgically and sometimes a rotation through several different antibiotics will do it. There is also sinus irrigation, which can  be done at home but is best (and most effectively) done by an ENT specialist.   The various subtle sensations you describe are most likely a combination of normal-but-usually-not-noticed events, and some of them may be  due to (or at least noticed because of) anxiety.   The symptoms you describe, especially the fatigue and need to sleep a lot, are completely consistent with a chronic, unresolved sinus problem, whether infectious or not.  Failure not only to drain properly but to permit smooth pressure changes inside the head (sinuses) can cause feelings of fatigue,  malaise and even a sort of "stupid" feeling, where it is difficult to think simple problems  through clearly. Balance can be affected also, as can hearing.   I don't thing anything suggests Budd-Chiari, and it would have shown up on MRI. Even the olfactory hallucination (smelling the scent of grapes) is common with this sort of problem. Some very unusual smells are frequently reported, and usually they are not unpleasant.   If this should be caused by an allergic reaction (possible also), it will be more difficult to diagnose, but would respond well to antihistimines. The  only problem with this is that antihistimines dry and thicken the secretions, their use, without something to keep the secretions thinned, can often lead to recurrent infections. So if antihistimines are used, they should probably be used in combination with something like  guaifenesin (long-acting brand name: Mucinex) to keep the secretions moving, but less of them produced. This helps avoid  perpetuating the infection if there is one.   I hope this is helpful to you. Please follow up here as needed. Best of luck to you.
posted_time: Post  by John Kenyon, CNA » Sun Dec 07, 2008 8:52 pm

content: Yes, I have a dry persistant cough only in the morning for 5 to 10 min. I had a cold one day about 8 months ago and my cough never went away. I don,t  smoke. I am a 29 year old male. The doctor tried antibiotics didn,t work, tried alegra didn,t work. Please help.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Persistant cough in morning
content: Hi there -  The cough could be due to any number of things: chronic sinus drainage, gastroesophageal reflux, even just a normal phenomenon. If it's a dry cough antihistimines are less likely to help, but were certainly worth a try. More likely to be effective would be either an expectorant (guaifenisen, brand name Mucinex), or a cough suppressant (dextromethorphan, the "DM" in many over-the-counter cough remedies); There's even a combination, Mucinex DM, which contains both.   It may also be something that will resolve in time. I assume it's especially bothersome, and since there appears to be no obvious respiratory reason for it, suppressing it may be the best bet.   I hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you.

author: levinv  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Nov 01, 2008 10:45 pm Gender: Male
title: strange long-term cold/fatigue symptoms
content: Hello, I have had recurring symptoms that I don't understand for several years. Because the problems I am having are intermittent and rather vague, I don't know how to broach them with my family doctor. I hope that you might at least give me some idea of what this might be so that I can approach my doctor with a bit more confidence. Here goes:  I seem to have sore throats that make it difficult to talk which develop into full blown illness frequently throughout the year - maybe 3 or 4 times a year. After a week or two of this throat irritation,I develop a bit of laboured breathing, some headache in the forehead, and extreme fatigue that makes it hard to stay out of bed during the day. I can easily stay asleep almost the entire day and night for a week straight (though I force myself to work and drag myself through the week).  Sometimes after a couple of weeks I get some more traditional cold symptoms (running nose, coughing). The pattern seems to be moderate discomfort ( ~2 weeks)  where I feel as though I am fighting something but am more or less ok,  then the terrible fatigue (~ 1 to 2 weeks) at which point I start to feel normal again with a great deal of relief. Here's the catch, it often seems to go right back to the feeling of fighting something. Eventually (close to a month) I seem to get to a fairly normal level again for a few months until it all repeats itself. The fatigue aspect seems to be getting worse in the past two years.   I've had a fairly standard set of blood tests done but nothing has come up from that. I get very worried about it until it goes away and then I don't want to think about it until it comes back. Then I get through it again. Thus I haven't pursued this with my doctor as much as I wish I had. Does this fit any known patterns?
posted_time: Post  by levinv » Sat Nov 01, 2008 11:00 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: strange long-term cold/fatigue symptoms
content: Hello -  What  you descrine actually might describe a number of conditions, most of them not serious, but it certainly warrants a medical workup. You may have something as "simple" as a chronic sinus infection (deep sinus, often without the usual headache and fever). You could also have a compromised immune system, which happens more often than one might think, and often is due to something relatively innocent or at least easily managed (though not always).   My suggestion to you would be to copy and paste what you've written here into a document and print it out (or else hand-write the same details if you prefer) and take that with you to the doctor, who should be able to interpret the information and do the appropriate tests and examinations to get to the bottom of this.  You've described it very well in writing, so it may be that's the best way to convey it. This works for a lot of people. You'd probably be surprised.  I hope this is helpful  to you. Best of luck, please follow up as  needed here, and by all  means update us when and if you get a diagnosis of this thing.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Chronic Enlarged Tonsills
content: Hi there -  The sheer size of your tonsils should warrant at least some sort of medical treatment if not removal. While adult tonsilectomy is more complex than that in young children, it still can be done and sometimes needs to be. author: maiden75  Guest Posts: 60 Joined: Thu Aug 26, 2004 1:19 pm Location: Texas
title: Is Nasonex safe?
content: I just got a prescription for Nasonex and while reading online (I know, big mistake) I saw that you should make sure and tell your doctor if you have had any recent vaccinations.  Well, I did have a flu shot last week, and wasn't asked that question, so i didn't even think to mention it.  Can i still use it?  Also, I have been diagnosed with PACs/PVCs.  Is Nasonex safe for me to use or will it aggravate the problem?  If you have time to answer one more....is fish oil safe for people w/PACs/PVCs?  I thought I read that it can aggravate arrythmias so now I am kind of scared to take it for my Triglycerides.
posted_time: Post  by maiden75 » Thu Nov 13, 2008 10:18 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Is Nasonex safe?
content: Hi there -  Nasonex is a nasal spray steroid medication that is primarily topical. Very little of it manages to get into the bloodstream. The reason for the warning about recent vaccinations is that some are made  with live viruses rather than killed (as with your flu shot), and steroids can suppress inflammatory responses (in fact, that's its job), which can mask reactions to vaccines. As a rule this isn't a big deal anyway, but with live virus vaccines it is remotely possible to actually "catch" what you were vaccinated for,  at least in theory. This isn't the case with the flu vaccine currently in use, so no problem  there.   Also, with PACs and  PVCs,  while  they are benign, they are annoying and disturbing, so you don't want to ingest things that might aggravate them or increase their frequency, but, again, Nasonex is a topical drug (barely any gets into the bloodstream, it is applied to the surface of nasal passages), so should not have any effect on an irritable heart muscle, although oral or injected steroids may sometimes cause an increase in PACs and PVCs. Nasonex shouldn't affect that  problem at all, and even if it could,  it wouldn't be catastrophic,  just annoying. But it shouldn't at all. Some decongestant nasal sprays (like Afrin, etc., that are not steroid-based) can aggravate these arrhythmias, so Nasonex is actually a much better bet all the way around.   Fish oil (or omega-3 fatty acids) will not have any affect on PACs/PVCs at all and are very beneficial in many ways besides.   I hope this answers your concerns. Please feel free to follow up here as needed.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Nose Clicking
content: Hello -  While there's no way to know exactly what's causing this without a direct exam, it's a fairly common complaint, and sometimes it is broken cartilage, but it can also be due to an anatomical anomaly involving the structure of the nose cartilage and may just require an adjustment. If there's a break or a congenital separation, it may benefit from minor surgery or, if you know what it is, you can at least make an informed decision as to whether to put up with it or have it repaired. Again, it could just be something that needs an adjustment or other non-surgical treatment.  Hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you.

Again, no fever, but a few of the cases of Strep that I contracted I did not have fever either.  Could this be Strep again, or could it be just a cold? author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Swollen Uvula
content: Hi there -  This is not due to a cold. You most likely have strep again -- and it can be recurrent. The swollen uvula isn't something you want, either, as it can interfere with swallowing and sometimes even with breathing, so you need to have this looked at and treated, probably with another course of antibiotics. I wouldn't let something like this go too long,either, since recurrent strep infections can lead to involvement of other organ systems.   Go see a doctor.   Hope this helps. Best of luck to you.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: tonsils and throat swollen
content: Hello -  If there is no pain or discomfort associated with this, there is a chance this is angioneurotic edema, a potential serious allergic response to something. The reaction is swelling in the upper airway, and doesn't hurt, but can make swallowing difficult and can sometimes make breathing difficult as well. For this reason it needs to be evaluated at once. There is a small but discrete risk of this becoming dangerous. In the meantime, if you happen to have Benadryl handy, I'd take one, in hopes it will help control a possible  allergic reaction in progress.  Best of luck to you. Please follow up with us as needed.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: Re: Tonsil Stones but...
content: Hello, This white headed bump on the throat is more likely to be due to throat infection. Most common cause of throat infection that give this picture are streptococcal infections (bacterial) and infectious mononucleosis (virus-EBV).  These condition are usually associated with fever, throat pain, difficult swallowing with or without lymphadenopathy. Viral infections are usually more mild. The only way to confirm diagnosis is through throat swab and culture.  The other possibility is the presence of tonsillar remnants that may get infected and give clinical picture similar to tonsillitis.  Having white headed bump in the tonsil without signs of inflammation may indicate tonsillar stone which usually gives bad odor and chronic irritant cough.  However, it is not expected to have this problem after tonsillectomy unless complete removal of the tonsil was not done and remnants are there. They usually result from postnasal secretions, recurrent infection and irritation. Dead bacteria and debris forms the stone.  Other causes of white patches in the throat include oral thrush (candida).  ENT examination is essential. I would advise you to follow up with your doctor and please keep us updated. Best regards.

author: ajf7279  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Mon Nov 17, 2008 3:46 pm Gender: Female
title: Hard, Golf-ball type lump in neck?
content: I'm embarassed to go to my doctor and ask this so if someone could give me an idea if this needs to be addressed, that would be great.  So my 3 year old's pediatrician is watching a group on lymph nodes in her neck and ordered blood work last week that we're waiting on.  I was sitting here today feeling around on my neck, just to see what's what and I came across a lump in my neck.  I can feel it if I'm poking around and I am a very thin individual and when I shrug my shoulders up and forward, you can see this golf-ball sized lump above my clavicle, just below what I think is my trapezius muscle on the left side.  It really doesn't hurt unless I press on it really hard.   I guess my question is, what could this be?  I know you can't diagnose me over the internet but could you maybe throw out a few possibilities or if I should see my doc?  Could a lymph node be that big and that deep?    Thanks in advance!  Amanda
posted_time: Post  by ajf7279 » Mon Nov 17, 2008 4:00 pm

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: Re: Hard, Golf-ball type lump in neck?
content: Hello,  Lymph nodes enlargement can occur due to many causes: of them infections and inflammation in the area drained by them.  Following infection or inflammation lymph nodes become enlarged, painful, and tender. When recovery occurs, they then regress in size but never disappear and remain palpable. They are known as non specific lymph nodes and are of less than 1cm size, soft and mobile.  Infections and inflammation in the upper respiratory tract and the upper digestive tract result in enlarged lymph nodes mainly those felt on both sides of the neck (the submandibular and the cervical group of lymph nodes).  Lymph nodes that continue to grow in serial clinical examination are alarming and should be properly investigated. The same is applied to nodes with abnormal characters like being hard, fixed or of considerably large size as well as those of uncommonly involved site. So, if it is true, the enlarged lymph node is that big (about 4cm), further investigations are needed to exclude serious causes.  Supraclavicular lymph node enlargement is not commonly seen to be enlarged after infection in these areas although possible.  What you felt might be a lower cervical lymph node. The supraclavicular nodes are felt just above the inner part of the clavicle in the supraclavicular fossa. Its enlargement is commonly seen in problems (mostly cancer) in the lung or upper GIT, and breast. So, its enlargement mandates proper investigations for exclusion of serious causes.  A contracted muscles may be mistaken for a swelling so a thorough history and direct clinical examination are essential.  I would advise you to follow up with your doctor. He might recommend CT Scan to exclude other swellings in the body. And if suspicious lymph node is seen by examination or radiological a biopsy is mandatory. CBC and other blood tests like LDH, and ESR may be helpful.  Please keep us updated. Best regards.

author: proaudiohd  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Sun Oct 07, 2007 3:18 pm
title: Why does my hearing get better when I pop my ears?
content: I'm an audio engineer and this is getting to be a serious issue for me.  I do not have health insurance so I thought I'd see if I can get some help here.   When I do the "plug your nose and blow" maneuver to clear my eustachian tubes, and my eardrums pop out, i notice a VERY, very dramatic change in my hearing.  It is mainly in the high frequencies say above 8khz.  Things like cymbals come through very  crisp and detailed. I can hear so much more clearly I almost want to cry to think that's how I'm supposed to hear.  I'm not holding the eustachian tubes open, as I can tell what that sounds like too.  I just pop them out once.  My hearing will stay amazing but as soon as I swallow, my ears pop back again and the high frequency detail goes away immediately . It stays that way until I pop my ears again.  I had previously been diagnosed with eustachian tube dysfunction and my doctor told me my eardrums were sucked in.  Whatever treatment (antibiotics i think)  did not solve anything.  It has been many years now.  I am 27. Could the structures of my inner ear be damaged?    This will affect my career so it's pretty important I figure out why my hearing changes when I do this.   In a normal state without popping my ears, I pass all hearing tests with flying colors.  I do not have any measurable hearing loss for my age. However, popping my ears yields such a dramatic difference in the high frequencies that I'm sure there is something wrong.  What could be going on and how do I keep my hearing 'better' as it is when I pop my ears?  Does this happen to everyone?  Is it a temporary pressure increase that puts more pressure on the chochlea and activates different nerve cells?  I'm really interested to figure out why this is and which way i am supposed to hear.  The difference is night and day!
posted_time: Post  by proaudiohd » Sun Oct 07, 2007 3:41 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Proaudiohd,  Likely, what is happening is that your ear drums are normally retracted (sucked in) due to the Eustachian tube dysfunction not letting the air inside the middle ear equalize pressures with the outside atmosphere.  When this happens, the pressure differences keep the ear drum tighter than it should be, causing its ability to move with sound to be diminished.  When you clear your tubes you are likely freeing the ear drum and allowing it to move normally until the pressures are again returned to unequal.  I would suggest you see an ear, nose, and throat specialist to have this evaluated.  I do not think that this is some permanent structural damage since your hearing gets better when you clear your Eustachian tubes.  There may be a treatment that can help resolve this situation for you.  One possible treatment you may want to talk to your doctor about is using a nasal steroid for a little while.  Sometimes the Eustachian tubes become inflamed (from allergies or various other reasons).  Using the nasal steroids helps relieve the inflammation and resulting swelling allowing the tubes to function normally.  This may help in your case and has very minimal side effects so it is not likely to be dangerous even if it doesn't help.  I've done this with a few of my patients with similar issues and it has helped dramatically.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Sun Oct 07, 2007 4:51 pm

Theoretically could this have been providing a layer of protection against noise related hearing loss (concerts, loud machinery etc) versus if my eardrums were free to move as they should have?  That would be pretty nice.   I will try the nasal steroid and see if it helps open things up.

author: proaudiohd  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Sun Oct 07, 2007 3:18 pm
title: [no title]
content: Just an update..   I have tried nasal steroids.  It has improved the function of my eustachian tubes..They now equalize much more readily.  However, I still have the issue of my hearing improving vastly when i forcibly pressurize my inner ear.  The improvement is very dramatic, and it goes away as soon as the artificially high pressure equalizes back to normal..which now happens much faster thanks to the steroids and the freely flowing eustachian tubes.    I am starting to think there is some kind of obstruction that I am 'lifting' my eardrums off when I pressurize them, allowing them to move freely all of a sudden.  When the pressure goes back down via the eustachian tubes, it seems as though the eardrums are returning to rest against whatever it is, and the movement is dampened again.   I've been reading about the long term effects of retracted eardrums such as pockets of dead skin forming on and behind the eardrum, preventing proper movement.  See also Cholesteatoma.   I think its time to see an ENT !

author: proaudiohd  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Sun Oct 07, 2007 3:18 pm
title: Re: Why does my hearing get better when I pop my ears?
content: I went and saw an ENT specialist.  I had a hearing test both normally, and with myself artificially pressurizing my inner ear. Both tests showed completely normal hearing.  However, the difference I notice is in the higher frequencies and their test only went up to 8k.    The ENT determined that I have no hearing loss in the frequencies they could test, and everything appears fine physically.   She told me that everyone's frequency response will change slightly as a result of over or under-pressurization of the inner ear.  Her suggestion was that my sound job just led me to be more aware of these changes that other people would ignore.  She also suggested I take an antihistamine to reduce any possible inflammation of my eustachian tube tissues.    I am not convinced though.  When in noisy situations such as a loud resturaunt or bar, I cannot understand conversations at the same distances that other people can.  However, if I pop my ears and hold the pressure artificially high, I can hear everything very, very clearly.  Sounds immediately localize better and they are more detailed.  I can discern one person talking against all the other people in the room very readily.  But as soon as I swallow and the pressure equalizes back out, my high frequency detail goes away and I can't hear the people close to me as well.  The same is true for music, falling water, or rushing air.  The difference is very very strong, and focused entirely in the high frequencies.  I am only a human, so I cannot have superhuman hearing when I hold high pressure behind my ears.. Therefore I must have reduced hearing at a normal state.  Perhaps from noise damage?  If that is true, how can those frequencies suddenly come alive with a shift in eardrum position? I'm still searching for an answer..

content: Hello my name is Austin and im 16. Last year i had my tonsils removed because they were infected pretty severely. I mention this in regards to the lumps i now have in my throat. author: dr. janak patel  Medical Doctor Posts: 5 Joined: Sat Nov 01, 2008 5:46 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Hard Lumps under my jaw/neck for 2-3 months
content: It is good that you are concerned and are watching these areas. Of course, a primary concern should be for occult cancerous process especially w the history of chewing tobacco. These could just be acne type though they don't sound it, or saliva glands that are working extra hard to make saliva especially to clear the toxic tobacco juices from your mouth and throat. These glands are under your chin, lower sides of both cheeks above and below the jawline and they drain inot the cheek mucosal surface on the inside where your molars are. Sometimes massaging these areas where the glnds are will relieve some of the pressure built up in these glands from extra saliva and will make them empty some of the saliva into your mouth or at the very least help w the discomfort. Most importantly they could be lymph nodes totally unrelated to the saliva but much more to the job that they are supposed to be doing and that is to drain and localize all the infectious materials from our blood, skin in the region from which they drain, or they could be enlarged lymph nodes from a more serious cancerous source but much less likely hopefully given the tobacco history and the chewing history. Make sure there are no skin or mucous surface ulcers or sores in the gums, ,inner chheeks everywhere as these may be cancerous or precancerous or certainly at least adding to the lymph nodes being swollen to try to control the infectious drainage from these areas. Most importantly, get to your main primary care doctor asap and get an exam of these swollen areas, your mouth where the practitioner should use gloved hand to examine and use pressure also to feel for any hidden lumps in the inside of the cheeks and thruough the walls of the cheeks, gums, etc. Also, the practitioner will most likely also want to lab testing such as cell blood count (cbc) w differential and serum chemistry labs as well as liver lab tests possibly a monotest  though very unlikely given your history. These tests should help us decide if we wnat to do more expansive deeper testing and exams to illict the cause of your lumps and determine the treatment if any is needed. Antibiotics for 10-14 days might also be a good trial treatment while awaiting followup of the tests just to be sure we are eliminating the possibilty of some type of skin, neck, gum, gland infection. These are just suggestions and very thorough workup which may even include chest xary, Cat Scan (CT) of your sinuses but again these are just suggestions and points to consider. DONOT, I repeat DONOT be panicked that I mention cancer as a potential cause because that is something that we must always keep in the back of our mind not the first thing and as such nothing that we cannot face and even overcome sometimes even w very little treatment.  So, keep your chin up and get to your doctor soon, get to a immediate med/urgentcare setting in between if you're truly panicked but just remember that they are just a reassurance and you realy need a complete exam by a doctor who knows your whole history and is skilled in the diagnosis and treatment of this what appears to be actually a common symptom and finding that usually has a benign or very simple, safe cause and can be easily treated and the treatment can even begin in the urgent care if you desire w antibitotics even before your primary care doctor appt. Hope this helps set you off on the right road to addressing your problem and I commend you for being so observant and concerned a person and best of wishes!

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: ear infection is getting worse with antibiotics & drops
content: Hello -  The infection may not actually be in your ear since the swelling in your face is actually over the temporomandibular joint by now. This could be extended from an ear infection but seems more likely caused by either a cystic gland near the ear, or perhaps even an abcessed tooth. It's difficult to tell without being able to see the site, inside your ear, etc. I think a whole area exam is warranted at this point, as the antibiotic you're on  doesn't appear to be making much headway, and you may require something stronger, or even some slightly invasive procedure to drain this infection. These can often be confused between the ear, a tooth, a sinus or a gland, since so much is contained in such a small yet deep area of the head.   I'd definitely call or go back and let the doctor know this isn't improving but is, in fact getting significantly worse. You can't afford to let something like this just go and hope it will improve on its own. Hopefully a change in antibiotic will do the trick, at least in the short run. Later you may require some minor surgery to keep this from happening again, depending upon where the source of the problem actually lies.  I hope this is helpful. Best of  luck to you. Please keep us updated.

author: lucy2008  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 4:14 pm Gender: Female
title: Swollen lymph nodes, ear pain, swallowing problems, headache
content: Hi  I'm not sure if I'm in the right forum but this is where my symptoms started 3 months ago. I'm 36 year-old female, previously healthy who has been taking preventative antibiotics (for recurrent UTIs) for 6 months.  About 3 months ago I started getting sharp stabbing pains in my neck. Shortly afterwards the glands in my neck became swollen and I had frequent sore throats and fatigue. I then developed what I can describe as ear pain/ear fullness which makes me feel slightly deaf. I went to see my GP who thought it might be an infection in the eustachian tube and prescribed antibiotics. I did not get any better and in fact started feeling slightly worse.  I went back to see my GP and he said it might be glandular fever so sent me off for a few blood tests. All came back fine apart from slight anaemia and advised me to take some iron tablets.  A few weeks later I had awful pains at the back of my neck/head which referred needle-like pains all over my head. I went to casualty but as I didn't have a temperature or unusual blood pressure sent me home with painkillers.  The headaches/neck pains persisted and I then developed burning stinging pains in my elbows that has left me with aching heavy arms. I also have this in my knees (heavy legs when walking up stairs).  I went back to my GP (who is baffled by my symptoms and is now tired of seeing me) who had no idea who to refer me to for further diagnostic tests - an ENT? neurologist? rheumatologist? orthopedics?   I'm seeing a chiropractor to help relieve my symptoms but her opinion is that my nervous system is not working well.  My lymph glands in my neck are so swollen that I think this is causing ear pain and problems swallowing? They have been swollen for 3 months.  Can you help me please? I'd appreciate any advice you can give. Many thanks

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Swollen lymph nodes, ear pain, swallowing problems, headache
content: Hello -  Naturally my first thought was mononucleosis (glandular fever), but since that was ruled out, given the precise description of your symptoms, I'm concerned you may have either a walled-off glandular infection or possibly viral meningitis. Either could persist without a fever, espcecially a trapped infection encapsulated in a parotid gland. However, with the addition of the newer neurological symptoms it brings us back to possible meningitis, probably viral (if it's that at all). Something is certainly infected, and it is begining to infiltrate tissues beyond the original site. Since the neurological symptoms have progressed along with the local symptoms I can't help but suspect an abcess-like  infection or viral meningitis. The latter would likely have run a more rapid course; an abcess may only have local heat and discomfort, but could eventually spread and turn into meningitis.   Someone needs to do some really thorough lab work to diagnose this. It may require an MRI of the local site and maybe the brain as well. This can't be allowed to simply continue, and the argument for infection as at least the underlying cause is pretty strong, I think.  I hope this is helpful. Best  of luck to you and please do follow up with us as needed.

author: lewilhe  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Sep 16, 2008 8:37 pm Gender: Female
title: Lingering Swollen Throat w/ White Spots
content: OK, so sorry if this is long winded.  Week one: I went to the clinic for a swollen throat - after the initial examination, the Dr. diagnosed me w/ strep (although he did not do a culture).  He put me on Cefaclor (?).  After three days my symptoms got worse and I developed white spots on the back of my throat.  Other than being extremely tired, I really had no other symptoms (no fever).   After a week, I went back to the Dr.  Based on the lingering throat that did not respond to medication and the constant fatigue, he thought I had mono so he did a blood test.  To be sure it wasn't baterial related, he put me on Levaquin until the mono test results came back.  I got the test results back, no mono.  After four more days (and a week an a half into this), there was no change in fatigue or the swollen thoat w/ white spots.  I went back to the Dr.  By this time, I had small bumps on one side of my stomach which was diagnosed as Shingles.  The Dr. decided to retest me for mono thinking the virus hadn't developed enough from at the point I was tested the first time.  So he ran more blood work for mono and diagnosed me with shingles.  I was prescibed Valtrex for the shingles.  A day later, the second mono test was negative.(and other cell count levels were normal)   Its been another week and I'm part in to week three of this fiasco. The shingles bumps are gone, however, my throat is still still swollen and the white spots are still there.  I went back to the Dr. for the fourth time today and he is clueless.  He has referred me to a Ear, Nose & Throat Specialist, who can not see me for six weeks.  My primary care Dr. has told me to continue another 15 days of Valtrex and take Levaquin for another week and see what happens until I can get in to the specialist.  I'm frustrated.  Any ideas?
posted_time: Post  by lewilhe » Tue Sep 16, 2008 9:06 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Lingering Swollen Throat w/ White Spots
content: Hi there-  Your frustration is understandable. You've been subjected to the "shotgun" approach to treating something that wasn't diagnosed properly the first time. You very likely do have shingles, and since this lives in your body even when dormant, it can manifest in almost any area. The throat lesions are probably related to it, which means the Levaquin won't do any good (and wouldn't against shingles anyway). However, shingles is not only painful where there are lesions, but can make a person feel pretty lousy in general at times, and these outbreaks can last a long time. Valtrex should help push this into submission if it is one of the more common types, but since it was already well underway by the time that was started, it could take a while for it to become effective. It can help suppress future outbreaks, but it's not as effective with outbreaks that have already gotten a good start.  It's a shame the ENT wasn't able to see you for such a long time,  as it's fairly likely the throat lesions will have resolved by that time. At least I hope they do. If they don't you may have something else going on, but it certainly does seem to be viral.   My best suggestion (which you may have already done on your own) would be to ask the ENT's front office people if they would notify you if an earlier appointment becomes available, as once the throat problem goes away it will be very difficult to tell what it may have been -- unless it recurs sometime in the future.  I hope this is of some help to you. Good luck with this and please follow up with us as needed.

author: JessNElvis  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Sep 16, 2008 4:32 pm Gender: Female
title: Why does my nose smell... toxic? Eww...
content: I am a 25 year old female.  I DO have asthma (diagnosed in 2007-ish)  I take the following medications (I am a walking pharmacy) : Inderal 60 mg WellbutrinXL 300mg Seroquel 100-400mg Biotin 5000mg Hair/skin/Nails vitamins Phentermine 37mg (45 lbs and still losing!) Singulair 10mg Xoponex inhaler (I can't ever remember to use this) Symbicort Inhaler (I can't ever remember to use this, either) Orthotricyclen (I stopped taking this about 2 months ago)  For the past 3 or so months, I've had this really horrible smell in my nose. I don't know how to describe it, except to say it's sort of infection-smelling. It's a strong, sharp smell... kind of ferment-ish, or like... rot (I know that's gross, but I don't know how else to describe it). It's so bad at times that I stay paranoid that other people smell me, and it turns my stomach (I've gotten more used to it, though, lately, since it's decided not to go away). My mother swears that she can't smell it, but it doesn't make me feel better. It started about 3 months ago. It just sort of showed up and hung around for a few weeks. It went away for a few weeks, and then came back every 2 or 3 days. For the past month or so, it's been there pretty constantly. About 3 or 4 weeks ago, I went to my physician and told her that I thought perhaps I had a sinus infection due to the yucky smell in my nose (but I didn't feel bad, or have pressure on my face or headaches or anything). She prescribed an antibiotic, which I took as prescribed. The smell didn't go away, though. It's still here, and it's just awful.   The last couple of weeks, I've had some minor sinus drainage, but it's not bad (it doesn't cause me to cough or clear my throat constantly or bother me or choke me, etc... I really don't notice it).  If it helps any (and this may be more info than you need), I've also had other weird things going on, too. For example, for the past 2 or 3 years, my nose runs when I eat (almost 90% of the time). It's funny... like clockwork, when I start eating, my nose will run and I usually spend most of my meals wiping and dapping and rubbing my nose with a napkin or kleenex (which also bothers me, because there are a lot of people who think blowing your nose at the table is rude...) I told my physician this a while back, and she just sort of laughed. I really think she thought I was just joking or something... so I didn't mention it again. I figured maybe it wasn't anything bad... just me being paranoid or something. AND- quite often when I lean over, water comes rushing out of my nose, even if my nose hasn't been running or anything. If I reach down to pick something up off the ground or on a low shelf or such, it's like a faucet has  been turned on in my head and it just pours out of my nose. It doesn't look (for lack of better words) snot-ish or phlegm-ish. It is clear and has the same texture consistency of water. It makes me feel super gross, though...  What in the world could this smell in my nose be, and what do I need to do to get rid of it? I'm tired of worrying that other people smell me and think I stink... and it's rather unnerving when you have a infection/rot smell in your nose (I know that sounds gross, but I don't know how else to describe it... sorry).  Thanks in advance for any help :)
posted_time: Post  by JessNElvis » Tue Sep 16, 2008 5:18 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Why does my nose smell... toxic? Eww...
content: Hi there -  You need to have a CT scan of your sinuses and a consult with an ENT specialist. It sounds very much as though you have a blocked deep sinus, probably infected as well. The smell you describe is fairly typical of this, as is the "pouring" of fairly clear, watery mucus in certain circumstances (and especially when the head is tipped forward). By the way, for those who feel blowing one's nose at the table is rude, I wonder what they would think if you didn't blow your nose at the table  when it was appropriate. I know, it's pretty much a no-win for you.   You may need to have your sinuses irrigated, may require antibiotics prescribed, and may even (possibly) require surgery, eventually, to correct this problem if none of the simpler measures work.   Everything you describe actually does fit with a deep sinus blockage. These often don't present the same way the more superficial sinus infections do (often no pain when pressing on the face, no headaches, often even no fever). This is what makes these so problematic. People assume there's no sinus involvement. There may, in fact, not be, but I'd be willing to bet that's exactly what's going on.   I hope this is helpful to you. Please follow up with us and  keep us updated.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: Re: Swollen lymph node, sinus and allergy issues and sore throat
content: Hello,   This is more likely to be an enlarged lymph node but direct clinical examination is essential for confirmation.  Following ear, throat, gum, dental or sinus inflammation or infection, the draining lymph nodes especially those in the upper side of the neck become enlarged, painful and tender.   When inflammation subsides, or after adequate course of antibiotics, they should regress in size but never to normal size. Thus when you have another attack of infection or inflammation they regrow and become painful again.   I would advise you to follow up with your doctor after proper examination, he may prescribe you an antibiotic treatment accordingly.  Please keep us updated.  Best regards.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Feeling hot all the time & excessive sweating - tonsils?
content: Hello -  While I doubt your tonsillectomy had any bearing on your symptoms (you were having this before and still have it afterward), there are plenty of other things to be ruled out. You could have a form of autonomic nervous dystem dysfunction which is causing your body to keep itself warmer than necessary (dysautonomia), then there is that matter of the thyroid exam which did show something abnormal but was dismissed as not significant. This puzzles me, since the first thing one would think of, on reading of your symptoms, is to rule out hyperthyroidism. If there are nodules on the thyroid and/or swelling of this gland, it is entirely possible you're suffering from an excess of thyroxin. I don't understand how this set of symptoms along with thyroid nodules can be seen as "not significant." It may not be the case, but this does need to be ruled out first.   Dysautonomia is a more difficult thing to diagnose, often becoming a default diagnosis once organic disease has been eliminated. Raynaud's phenomenon can also cause this sort of derangement, although it usually manifests as cold, blanched extremities (fingers, toes, tip of the nose, etc.), followed later by flushing and warmth in those areas.   All these things need to be considered in a differential diagnosis. If your doctor doesn't grasp the degree of your discomfort, it may be time for a second opinion. I would definitely persue this, as it's obviously not normal and is causing you a great deal of distress, both social and physical.   I hope this is of some help to you. If you have any other information to add, please do. Otherwise, stay in touch and let us know how things unfold, at least.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Ringing in ears, hearing different pitches
content: Hi there -  While  tinnitus is frequently treated as a "natural" annoyance and the patient told "get used to it", it is, in reality, a symptom, not a condition, and  if the underlying cause can be found and eliminated or treated, it often can be relieved or at least managed successfully.   While the  pitch problem is one I haven't heard specifically before, I am familiar with cases of tinnitus associated with various sorts of perversions  of normal hearing, so this one isn't especially surprising. The important thing is to get to the bottom of the cause (and the potential causes are far too many to list here) and treat it. This is espcially important  given your chosen  area of profession.   Some of the more simple causes are use of aspirin and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, caffeine, nicotine, excessive salt in the diet, a number of prescription drugs, etc. There are a lot more of these, as well as many more physical (medical) causes.   Seeing an otolaryngologist would probably be the best starting point for you. While the MRI certainly ruled out certain things, there are plenty of others that wouldn't show up via that route. It could be something very simple.   I hope this is helpful to you. Best of luck, and please follow up with us as needed.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Sore/Throbbing lump under skin near chin
content: HI there -  Since you have a history of thyroid disease (probaboy Hashimoto's thyroiditis, which is the most common cause), you could be feeling something related to the thyroid or parathyroid, since the location you describe is near that area. However, it also could be an inflamed lymph node or nodal cyst. Either a cyst or some sort of parathyroid growth could account for the symptoms, although I am inclined to lean toward the likelihood of an inflamed or congested lymph node.   There is nothing here to suggest any remote relation to MS.   I would strongly suggest you see either your GP or an internist first, with possible referral to an endocrinologist, but this latter probably won't be necessary, especially if the lump can be identified as a lymph node or cyst.   I hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you. Please keep us advised of what you find out.

author: jfenn001  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Sep 23, 2008 9:56 pm Gender: Female
title: Chronic sore throat & Vocal Polyp
content: About two years ago I went to an ENT doctor because I had a chronic sore throat and loss of voice.  He diagnosed me with a vocal polyp, which I was able to treat through a year of voice therapy.  The voice therapy reduced the size of the polyp to the point the doctor said surgery was unnecessary.  All was fine for about 6 months then I started having sore throats again.  I went back and was told they could not see anything wrong, which I confirmed with a second doctor.  They told me it was due to acid reflex which was one of the causes for my polyp in the first place.  So I changed my diet, stopped eating before bed, starting taking Zantax (over the counter acid reflex medicine), and did a 2 week cycle of Prilosec.  But I still wake up every night because my throat hurts so much and then it lingers until I go to bed.  It's definitely worse in the mornings and then gradually gets better as the day progresses.  It is also extremely painful when I exercise and start breathing heavily.  I drink water to try and keep my throat lubricated, but nothing seems to be helping.  I have had the same sore throat on and off at varying degrees of intensity for about a year.  Is there a possible cause for this besides acid reflex?  Could this be cause be stress or a sign of a bigger problem?
posted_time: Post  by jfenn001 » Tue Sep 23, 2008 10:16 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Chronic sore throat & Vocal Polyp
content: Hello -  The problem is probably still acid reflux (this is always worse at night because the patient is horizontal and stomach contents can move up into the esophagus and over the glottis, where it gets aspirated and can damage the vocal cords and can also cause exercise-induced asthma). While any more serious cause of the symtpoms also needs to be ruled out, the greatest likelihood is this is secondary to reflux. Quite often over-the-counter (OTC) medication will work, but the problem has to be evaluated over time, and it may require a more potent,  prescription medication if this is what's causing this. You'll probably do best seeing an ENT specialist who can confirm the cause, which could well rule out anything more serious (and this is serious enough, but I understand what you mean). It already sounds as though you've got the stage set for exercise-induced asthma,  or at least a very serious  exercise-related reflux problem. There is now a remarkable little device that can be placed in the esophagus to measure the amount of acid and the conditions  under which it comes up, which can be very helpful in coming up with a treatment plan. The problem usually is due to the lower esophageal sphincter (ring of muscle around  the  bottom of the esophagus where it empties into the stomach) doesn't work, and there are new, non-invasive ways of fixing this if it's extreme.   The best way to rule out anything more serious would be  to have a complete upper GI workup for GERD (gastric espohpageal reflux disease) and have it treated professionally instead of on your own using OTC medications. The complcations can be serious, so you don't want to let this go, hoping it may fix itself. It won't.  Best of luck to you. Please follow up with  us here as needed.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Took ear drops for an ear infection but still dizzy
content: Hello -  Your ear infection sounds as though it is still active and of course this can affect balance and cause dizziness as well as a full feeling in the head with associated "weird" sensations including derealization. Since this has happened before and is not really getting better this time, you may need to see an otolaryngologist (ear, nose and throat specialist, ENT), in order to get this properly cleared up.   In the meantime, have you tried any of the over-the-counter anti-dizziness and nausea medications such as Dramamine (Non-drowsy Formula -- generic name meclizine)? If this works it would not only pin down the focus of the problem, but would also manage it for you til the problem can be addressed medically.   I hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Sporadic dizzy spells
content: Hello -  I am going to assume the dizziness you describe is just that, and not lightheadedness nor faintness, but more like a disabling spinning sensation. Please correct me if I'm wrong.  Assuming the above is correct, it would seem you're having frequent bouts of what's known as benign positional vertigo (BPV). While it is benign (not life-threatening) it can be very disabling while it's happening. Movement of the head (turning or looking  upward), bending down, and  other changes of position can all trigger the episodes, and it frequently happens upon waking and trying to get out of bed.   There are over-the-counter medications which can often manage this if it is chronic, usually caused by an inner ear problem (inflammation, usually viral in  origin, of the labyrinth). Because of the frequency and severity of the episodes, I'd suggest you be seen by a doctor to be certain this is garden variety BPV, and if so, meclizine (as Dramamine -- Non-drowsy Formula or its generic) can be very effective. This can also be prescribed (as Antivert or the generic). The drug has very few side-effects and works well in most cases.   I hope this is helpful to you. If my assumption about dizziness vs. faintness is not correct, please let me know.  I'd definitely have a doctor do a quick exam to be certain this is BPV, and if  so, it should be fairly easy to manage. Best of luck to you.
posted_time: Post  by John Kenyon, CNA » Fri Oct 10, 2008 10:45 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: SMOKE HURTS MY THROAT
content: Hello, Many people are extremely sensitive to such environmental insults and there may not be a known condition such as documented allergy, but your body is trying to tell you something and the best thing for you to do is avoid the offender.  I know of a man who must avoid all such odors, aerosols and pollutants and it is difficult for him.    Explain to those around you that you are very sensitive to these things and that you need to avoid them.  People who care about you will try to accommodate I'm sure.    If your doctor feels a tonsillectomy is in order, there is probably a good reason - perhaps they are inflamed or infected (thus, antibiotic treatment).  If he believes you might benefit from this it is probably worth it and while there area always risks associated with any surgery, it is a small risk and the benefits are likely to outweigh the risks.  Don't be afraid to ask the doctor whatever questions you have to be confident this is the right course.  Ask what he hopes to accomplish with the surgery, how it might be aggravating your condition and what alternative treatments he would suggest.  Then make your decision with confidence.  Best wishes.

author: BrandiWyne  Guest Posts: 5 Joined: Thu Apr 26, 2007 9:23 pm
title: Retenton cysts, Haller Cells and Marked deviated septum
content: Grettings:  My history:  Chronic sinustitis.  The smallest sniffles will produce big infections.  As long as 10 years ago, I had a head xray that suggested a cyst in my right sinus.  They told me not to worry about it.  Fast forward to now.  I snore (no apnea, was tested), I have difficulty breathing through my nose, my ears hurt, massive ringing, and had a neurological event that warranted an MRI of my brain.  This led to the eventual discovery of the following (and I quote the radiologist report): -Bilateral maxillary retention cysts, right one measuring 15mm -Bilateral Haller cells present -Focal mucosal thickening within the infundibilum of the right maxillary sinus causing occlusion of this Fairly marked deviation of the lower nasal septum to the right  I do not meet with the ENT surgeon until late next week, and I am fairly alarmed at all of this.  May I get a perspective on the above?  My thanks in advance,  Kim
posted_time: Post  by BrandiWyne » Thu Jul 17, 2008 1:34 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Retenton cysts, Haller Cells and Marked deviated septum
content: Hello -  Not to worry, at least no more than you would about the known proclivity for sinus infections. The cyst is formed by mucus trapped in a sinus cavity (in this case one resting upon the maxillary structure); Haller cells are just abnormal (but benign) cells that form beneath the orbit of the eye, usually due to repeated sinus infections. These all tend to worsen sinus ventilation and drainage, which only contributes, as you unfortunately know, to more and more severe sinus infections which, in turn, creates more likelihood of cysts and cells and symptoms which sprng from blocked sinuses.   The deviated septum, often present from birth, just as often due to trauma, only adds to the impeded flow and drainage. All of these things (or as many as are appropriate) can be corrected by surgery or treated symptomatically, depending on the individual patient.   Again, nothing new to worry about, just all things which help to explain why you have such severe and frequent sinus infections. Hopefully this can now be corrected to some degree.   Best of luck to you. I hope this is helpful.

author: JenniferM  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Sep 02, 2008 2:09 am Gender: Female
title: Severe sinus Doctor says he can't help.
content: Hi 39 yo suffered allergies and asthma entire life. Parents left me untreated for both. At age 30 1998 had severe infection ( frontal sinus) surgery 18 months later.Until this point I grew up thinking my constant runny nose etc was "normal". Recovery after surgery, sensitive sinus for approx 1 year post op. 2002 I was feeling great.... Oct 2007 ( In Australia) instead of usual spring/summer sneezes it turned constant, severe post nasal drip, vertigo, deafness in my "bad side"/right side. Feeling like constant flu, head cold burning and runny nose like water. By Jan 2008 developed swelling below right maxilliary I thought was a tooth abcess....two sets of xrays revealed nothing but whatever this is puts pressure on an upper tooth ( like nerve pain) below my right sinus area. CT scan in Jan and March this year show nothing except thickening of the lining on the right side ( bottom) sinus area which I was told is normal. Swelling continued to swell and can feel it above my tooh extending across the bottom of my cheek and on the maxilliary bone ( bottom end). This was not visible to the doctor but feels predominantly swollen to me. April started to develop what appeared to be a blister on that same location above my upper tooth and what appeared to be coming from under the maxilliary area. this blister appears to fill with fluid on and off through the day. It DID disappear for approximately 2 months this year but has now returned....making my face ache afwully on the right side and my sinus area not to mention pain and right side headache. The Doctor says it's not in the sinus area on the CT and face scan. The dentist says it's up way too high to even show up on my teeth xrays. Numerous thorough blood tests show nothing. Recently diagnosed with Fibromyalgia and Chronic Fatigue I am certain these effects are closely related to how awful my sinus is. Please need some advice on how I should attack this "blister" and swelling if it's not on a CT scan, xray or blood tests....It's like...nobody wants to "own it"...and i'm left feeling miserable. I wonder why the blister and swelling temporarily appeared to go away. We are in our first part of spring here, thought maybe it's entirely related to my sinus regardles of what the CT says...my right side sinus feels very BAD....often have to sleep it off. Thank you, Jen

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Severe sinus Doctor says he can't help.
content: Hello Jen -  Clearly there is something bad going on in the maxillofacial area. It's amazing no one can visualize it, but the signs and symptoms  should speak for themselves. I strongly suspect you have, perhaps as a result of the old surgery, something on the order of a fistula between one of your sinuses and the root canal of a tooth. It does happen, usually because of some trauma to the facial bones, and would explain both the nasal and periodontal/dental complaints. I can't imagine why this wouldn't show up on CT, but since it hasn't I feel fairly certain an MRI of the affected area would show up what a CT has been unable to.   Have you been treated with antibiotics? The signs and symptoms, as I said before, should guide the therapy, since these things can be observed if not clinically proven.   I hope this is of some help, although it isn't much. Best of luck to you and please keep us updated.

author: Icc12345  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri Aug 29, 2008 1:30 pm Gender: Female
title: Paranoid - Enlarged lymph node, ringing in ears HELP!
content: I hope someone can shed some light.  June 9 2008 - I had a sore throat, I thought I caught something from my recent plane ride. The walk-in doctor checked my throat and noticed a lump on my uvula. They took blood (CBC, Ferritin, THC?) & throat swab-all came back normal. But they still prescribed Azithromyacin. Sore throat went away.  June 13 2008 - Noticed my left ear was blocked and I couldn't release the pressure, I was feeling my neck and noticed the swollen lymph node. Went back to walk-in and they said its a reactive node. However they were concerned that the node didn't hurt or wasn't painful to the touch. They looked in my left ear and couldn't see anything wrong. They told me to come back if other nodes pop up. July 31 2008 - Lymph node still enlarged, went to my family doctor. was sent for Ultrasound which showed slight enlargment but not large enough to be concerned about. Family doc made appointment for ENT. Appointment is at end of Sept. Aug 26 2008 - in the a.m. I had an allergy attack began sneezing like crazy and then i blew my nose, right after my right ear was blocked. Every sound from my right ear sounded tinny/robotic. Went to bed and awoke to a high-pitched tone in my head that sounded like a t.v. station that had gone off the air. The sound has not subsided in 4 days. I notice it more at night when trying to sleep. My questions are... 1. Is it normal for a lymph node to stay enlarged for 3 months? 2. Is it possible that the lump on my uvula is cancerous and that is why the lymphnode on the left side only is swollen and because my lymph node is swollen its pushing against my eustacian tube and creating the pressure problem? 3. Can an ultrasound tell if a lymph node is cancerous? 4. What can I do to stop the ear noise on the right side? 5. After hearing about my issues what tests should I make sure to ask the ENT for?
posted_time: Post  by Icc12345 » Fri Aug 29, 2008 2:22 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Paranoid - Enlarged lymph node, ringing in ears HELP!
content: Hi there -  Having read your post, I'll try to answer your questions in order. Here goes:  1) Yes, once a lymph node is enlarged it can sometimes remain that way for a good long time. I don't know what accounts for this, but it does happen. It may shrink some, then stop while  still larger than it was.   2) It is highly unlikely the lump on your uvula is malignant. I don't know what it might be, but it was associated with a sore throat which responded to a potent antibiotic (never mind it was odd that your doctor prescribed it even though all the cultures were negative -- still, it seems to have worked).   3) An ultrasound cannot detect malignancies, but can only visualize abnormal growths, masses, formations, etc.   4) Tinnitus is  sometimes a very stubborn symptom. It is poorly understood and there is usually little that can be done to make it go away, but it usually will in time, especially if it is set off by a pharyngeal infection or allergic reaction, which seems to be the case this time.  5) The only thing I can think of you might want to ask the ENT for other than to suggest you might benefit from an allergy test to rule out some chronic irritant.   I hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Painless swollen puss stricken tonsils
content: Hello -  You definitely need to be seen again for this. While it would seem, on the face of it, to be simple tonsillitis, the fact that it's recurring this way after antibiotic therapy may mean it is atypical thrush or Vincent's angina (again, atypical), and in either case would require a different  kind of medication most likely. Then again, if it is simply a very stubborn tonsillitis, a change of antibiotic would probably be in order.  In any case, you really should get it re-checked and definitely it should be cultured.   Best of luck to you.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Swollen Lymph nods, Ear ache, Fever at night, vomiting
content: Hello -  If it were me I guarantee my next stop would be the doctor's office. It sounds as though you have either an enterovirus (in which case you can only treat the symptoms) or an acute bacterial infection which has cascaded down into your digestive system. If this is the case antibiotics might help and in either case a doctor is best able to determine which and how to best treat it. If this is a viral infection it will run its course and your best bet is to find out what will most effectively treat the symptoms so you can rest and recover. If it turns out to be bacterial, your doctor will need to prescribe the appropriate antibiotic in order to make sure it clears up. In either case you must make sure you remain adquately hydrated and get plenty of rest, but by all means yes, do see a doctor at once.  Best of luck to you.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Painful lump on head
content: Hello -  What you describe sound like cysts, either sebaceous ones (a dermatological problem) or ganglion cysts (a less problematic but more mysterious thing). Neither is serious, but if the bumps are due to sebaceous glands getting stopped up this  will eventually cause problems. Ganglions  are most common on the  wrist, but can also form on or near other joints and on the scalp as well. They don't usually require any treatment, unless, of course, one winds up resing on a nerve, which is what it sounds like  has happened with one of the bumps on your head, the painful one.   I'd see a dermatologist to try and find out what's  causing these, if it is sufficiently bothersome.  If not, and you can live with them, these bumps seem to be doing very little harm except for the one that's  painful to the touch. (Maybe don't touch it?).  I hopw this is helpful. Good luck to you.
