author: nmaist  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Feb 27, 2008 9:46 am Gender: Female
title: Dizzy after "Follow my fingure test" by Hearing Dr.
content: I have a question about a test that I just had done. I was at a VA medical facility and having my hearing checked because I get vertigo every now and again. The doctor ask me to follow his finger and when I followed his finger to the left (he stop at the left for 10 secs or so), but I got extremely dizzy. They would not tell me want they thought. Do you have any suggestions to what might cause that to happen?
posted_time: Post  by nmaist » Wed Feb 27, 2008 9:59 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Dizzy after "Follow my fingure test" by Hearing Dr.
content: Hello -  I find it extremely odd and probably annoying (for you, at least) that a doctor performing this simple and common test would not explain why he did it or what it was for. When one suffers from vertigo it is most often what is known as benign positional vertigo (BPV), which causes a characteristic eyeball "bounce" to one side or the other, when the eyes follow the examiner's finger. This bounce (the eyeballs do literally seem to bounce like  rubber balls when they reach the far left or right reach) is considered good news as a rule. It is called nystagmus and also goes with nausea sometimes, as well as other disturbances of equilibrium. It is usually rooted in a temporary thickening of the fluid in the inner ear's labyrinth (labyrinthitis), generally caused by a viral infection but sometimes for other equally benign reasons as well (ie: poor hydration). The  "follow my finger" test is a great way to ascertain the patient is most likely suffering from benign vertigo and can then be prescribed a medication to help offset the vertigo til the problem resolves on its own.   There can be also primary, intrinsic causes of vertigo in some individuals, but usually it is just an occasional occurrence which (as you no doubt know) can be temporarily disabling at times. Still, it is  most often harmless (so long as one doesn't fall and sustain an injury on the way down).   I hope this helps and that your future VA experiences involve better communication. Good luck to you.

content: Recently I had the flu which turned into bronchitis, sick for two weeks, then started having a pain which comes suddenly behind right ear and runs down like a tunnel down from ear to right before reach chin area. posted_time: Post  by DOLLYGAL » Wed Feb 27, 2008 12:55 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: EAR/NECK SPASMS
content: Hello -  What you describe sounds very much like neuralgia involving one of the cranial nerves, probably the 8th, 9th or 10th, which serve, at least in part, the area you describe as affected. The pain of neuralgia of any of the cranial nerves (usually the 5th, or trigeminal nerve is cited as causing most common pain such as you've experienced, but that nerve runs from the scalp down into the face) is often very sudden and quite severe, often brought on by pressure or even touch, and, depending on which one is actually involved, movement or maneuvers (including sneezing). Because of the things you list which can trigger the pains, I suspect it is either the vagus (10th) or glossopharyngeal (9th) nerve which is irritated.   What causes this is often unclear, but since you have a history of Bells Palsy there is quite possibly a relationship in  this case. Since Bell's Palsy affects the 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve) it would be unsurprising that a neighboring nerve could be inflamed or otherwise irritated as well.   I would bring this to the attention of an internist if it doesn't go away in short order, for two reasons: one, pain is unpleasant in it's own right, and two, pain that is sustained is telling us something is wrong. There are so many potential causes of irritation of the cranial nerves, and often neuralgia goes away in a matter of days. If it doesn't, especially if the vagus or glossopharyngeal nerves are involved there is a small potential for more serious complications in rare cases. Better to have a doctor involved, if only to find a reasonable way to relieve the pain.   I hope this is helpful to you. Good luck and please do follow up with us here.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: swelling (Lymphnde/parotid/mass)
content: Hello -   A localized or even a systemic infection (mono?) could have caused this. Sometimes one side will remain far more prominent for a long time -- years, even. If you've had it medically evaluated then it is probably a safe bet it's fine. The lymph system sometimes has to put up with a  lot of insults, some of which pass unnoticed thanks to the lymph nodes, which take the brunt of a lot of infections. It could have been any one of a number of things, and yes, you could have had mono  without knowing it. A period of just feeling out of sorts is the best case scenario for this infection, which often does affect lymph nodes in various areas,  but especially where you describe.   Hope this is helpful. Please follow up with us if there are further questions.

posted_time: Post  by dinobub » Thu Mar 06, 2008 1:23 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: bleeding in nostril (not nosebleed)
content: Hello, The most common cause of nosebleeds and nasal sores is dry air and the colds that occur especially in winter.  You can do a few things to help, in addition to not picking the scab off.  You can use a saline nasal spray or drops two or three times a day.  You can also use a mild water-based lubricant gel (not Vaseline).  Apply with the end of a cotton swab, inserted gently into the nostril.  Do not insert the swab further than the cotton tip.  A humidifier at night can help keep it from becoming too dry.  If this does not help, you should have a doctor check to see if there is some infection causing the sore.  This does not sound like something that needs to be cauterized but only a doctor could determine that.  Best wishes

title: DIZZY SPELLS
content: several times I wake up with the room spinning - very similiar to the bed spins after too much drinking - but in each instance I haven't been drinking.  And it is not vertigo becuase I do not get out of bed thiS happens when I open my eyes.
posted_time: Post  by ray_ray » Sun Feb 24, 2008 9:19 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: DIZZY SPELLS
content: Hello, It is possible you have Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV).  This is a form of vertigo caused by "ear rocks" - crystals of calcium carbonate.  It is a common cause of dizziness, especially in older people.  Unlike most other conditions that cause vertigo this one does not only happen when you stand.  People can get this problem with various movements or positions of the body.    Since yours occurs in bed, try sleeping with two pillows, instead of one and avoid lying flat.  Or, sleep in a recliner.  Change positions cautiously.  You may choose to wait it out and see if it disappears or see a doctor.  There are some exercises that are helpful.  Some people get this intermittently where it comes and goes at times.    Aside from this I don't know what else might cause your symptoms.  Best wishes.

title: Sore throat with one swollen Eustachian Tube opening
content: I've had a similar set of symptoms a few times now - one of the holes in the back of my throat that's part of the Eustachian tube system gets swollen (the right one) and it's accompanied by a sore throat.  The pain is also localized around that swollen hole.  (the hole becomes much smaller than the corresponding one on the left side).    What could cause this?  Why is it usually just one hole - and the right one at that?  Are there any steps to take to treat it differently than a standard cold/sore throat?    Thanks,  Brett
posted_time: Post  by brettswanson » Fri Feb 29, 2008 6:20 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Sore throat with one swollen Eustachian Tube opening
content: Hello Brettswanson,  The hole that you are seeing is very unlikely to be connected to the eustachian tube.  This is a commonly held belief that the Eustachian tubes connect to the back of the mouth but they actually connect to the nose.  The hole you are seeing may actually be more of a depression than a true hole.  There are a few areas on the top of the mouth that can appear this way.  These areas, when swollen, may appear to close off the hole as the overlying tissue swells.  The sore throat is likely an indication of an infection (most commonly with a virus).  If your sore throats persist I would recommend you see your doctor.  If a specialist is needed/desired, an ear/nose/throat specialist would be the place to go.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Swollen lymph node (3 Years) but no tonisil symptoms
content: Hi Ent,  Sometimes, lymph nodes will remain enlarged after they have become swollen due to infection.  These nodes still function properly but remain enlarged, often about a centimeter in size.  This may be what is going on in your case.  However, enlarged lymph nodes that begin to enlarge further should be evaluated to be sure nothing bad is happening.    In your case, if they haven't changed in 3 years there is unlikely to be anything bad.  If your ENT doctor recommended a tonsillectomy there may be a different reason.  You may want to discuss this with your primary care doctor or seek a second opinion if you are concerned.  You may also want to talk with your ENT doctor about his rational for doing the tonsillectomy.  This way you have all the information you need to make an informed decision.  Best wishes.

I figured it was some odd giant piece of earwax that fell at an odd angle and picked at it, but when I pulled the Q-tip out I didn't get anything save a bloody spot at the tip. posted_time: Post  by lesnemo » Sun Jan 06, 2008 11:19 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Ear pain/muffled
content: Hi Lesnemo,  I suspect your problem may actually be behind your ear drum rather than in your ear canal.  It sounds like you may have a condition called eustachian tube dysfunction.  Basically, this is when the eustachian tube fails to pen and close properly causing a pressure difference to form between the middle ear (behind the ear drum) and the outside air.  When this happens, the pressure difference causes the ear drum to be sucked in and unable to move properly.  Hearing depends on the ear drum moving to transmit sound.  If it is impeded a muffled sound occurs.  You may want to try using a decongestant for a day or two to see if this helps.  If it does not I would recommend you see your doctor to have your ear examined.  It may also be that there is some fluid behind the ear drum, basically causing the same problem as an air pressure difference.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: lump by right ear
content: Hello Helen20,  I suspect the sinus that your ENT doctor is referring to is not the typical sinus one thinks of with conditions like sinusitis.  A sinus also refers to a connection from the skin to a deeper structure or cyst.  In the area you are describing, this may be a condition called a branchial sinus.  During development of the embryo there are a series of branchial arches and sinuses that develop into various structures of the body.  Occasionally, these may not fully close leaving a sinus tract that can become infected or cause other problems.  The surgical removal of these sinuses is often fairly simple and straight forward.  It does depend a little on how deep the sinus goes, if it is near any major structures (such as the facial nerve), and if there are any other complicating structures or issues present.  Most likely, this will be a quick surgery, possibly even an outpatient surgery.  Best wishes.

title: Re: Ringing in left ear
content: Hello Kevtm1974,  Spinning and ringing ears may be due to a number of things involving the inner ear.  You may want to see an Ear/Nose/Throat specialist if this continues.  There are several viral infections that can cause this.  An otolith (a stone in the balance center of the ear) can cause dizziness although ringing is not a prominent part of this, typically. Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Dry Cough and Cold
content: A cold would not last for two years; allergies can.  So, I agree that you probably have allergies.  Perhaps a specialist would be helpful to identify the particular offenders (may be multiple irritants) and possibly treat you so that you would become tolerant of the substances in time.  Otherwise, treating symptoms and avoiding the things that particularly bother you is about all that can be done.  Good luck.

title: why wont the swollen glands go away and what is ?the lump
content: Hello my names Molly..And About a month ago I went to the Doctor because I was worried about my swollen glands.. and I found out I have a sinus infection and post nasal drip..I took the medication and the glands seemed to go back to normal now they are back to the same size, and I also have a lump thing near one of my swollen glands on the left side of my neck that Im worried about it doesn't hurt and it I believe has not gotten any bigger. And I have a lump a little under my adams apple that my doctor told me is my thyroid gland?....but I really don't remember it ever being there..maybe its because I have lost some weight...btw I am a real skinny person...Do you think this is cancerous? I hope not...Im real scared.  Please help
posted_time: Post  by molly1111 » Thu Dec 27, 2007 2:59 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: why wont the swollen glands go away and what is ?the lump
content: Hi Molly,  The swollen glands you are feeling are likely lymph nodes.  Lymph nodes can become enlarged during infections and subsequently reduce in size.  They may become enlarged again with another infection, even if the infection isn't causing other symptoms.  It may be that you are again fighting off a viral cold that is causing the enlargement.  Also, sometimes after lymph nodes have become enlarged they may not shrink back down to their original size.  In this case, they often remain about the size of a pea.  They still function normally.    The lump below your Adam's apple may be the thyroid gland.  It may simply be that you had not noticed its presence before.    Based on what you've described I think cancer is very unlikely.  If the lumps begin to get bigger or become painful I would recommend you have them re-evaluated by your doctor.  My colleague, Dr. Fouad, has written a very good article on lymph nodes that you may find helpful.  It can be found here.  Best wishes.

author: heydave777  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Dec 23, 2007 10:36 pm
title: Eustachian Tube Parasites
content: Eustachian Tube Parasites  Is anyone familiar with or ever heard of cases of parasitic infections of the Eustachian Tube ?  This "creature" feels like it moves when I swallow.  It also moved from one side to the opposite side. This is not a joke post.  I appear to be infected. It seems to be a higher life form not of microbial origin.  Any opinions ?  dave
posted_time: Post  by heydave777 » Sun Dec 23, 2007 11:00 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Eustachian Tube Parasites
content: Hello Dave,  I am not aware of any true parasites that infect the Eustachian tube; however, there can be small bugs that can get into the outer ear canal.  It would not be expected to travel to the other ear, though.  What you may be feeling with these sensations is changes in the middle ear pressure due to some Eustachian tube dysfunction.  Basically this is when the Eustachian tubes don't open and close at the proper times resulting in pressure mismatches between the middle ear (behind the ear drum) and the outside air.  This can occur sometimes due to inflammation of the eustachian tube with a viral infection, allergies, or any number of other causes.  If this continues I would recommend you see  your doctor for an evaluation.  Best wishes.

content: Hi Fvrofgod,  I'm a little stumped by this.  There are many infections, mostly viruses, that can cause bumps and blister-like things but they would not be expected to come and go with eating.    With eating being the onset, perhaps these spots are forming due to friction from food rubbing against the mouth basically causing a blister. author: matthan07  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Dec 26, 2007 9:44 pm
title: Sudden severe hearing loss. Clogged? Permanent?
content: Quick background. Im 23 and I was born with a moderate to severe loss in my left ear. All the docs that I've seen said it was just nerve damage and I've managed to survive.  About 10 days ago I started to feel real clogged in my left ear and with that was a major hearing loss on top of my preexisting condition. I could tell that it made me nearly totally deaf.  This may or may not have something to do with it but  I was suckerpunched on my right jaw a slightly prior to the symptoms occurring.  I figured I'd wait a few days and see what happens. I had mild ringing but nothing too severe. Over the week I had no change.  Of course I decided to go to the doctor over the weekend but Monday was Xmas eve and Tuesday was Xmas so I only got to the ENT today.  The audiologist confirmed that my hearing in my left took a big dump (i had a test from a few months prior to compare). He said it may be viral but didn't really say much at all.  I saw the ENT and he also didn't say much. Looked in my ear and up my nose. He said I should get a MRI but he made it seem like if it was expensive due to my insurance that it wasn't necessary. But he never really said what happened, although he did say there were some fluid behind my ear drum. Can this combined with my past loss cause this?  If I tap the back of the left side of my head it feels very funny(on the level of my ear but right my head begins to curve). It kind of feels very full and fluidy and makes me slightly dizzy for a split second. Actually the best way to describe it is it feels loud. But if touch the same spot on my right side it feels normal.  He prescribed prednisone and amoxiclav. Although I am worried bc I thought I should have gotten some anti-viral medication. Should I be okay with the combo I have now?  I am also debating if I should take some decongesitant just in case that coul be the cause..any recommendations?  Also what are my realistic outlook? Right now my left ear is unaidable, and I just want it to be good enough to get a hearing aid. The doctor didn't really say much (audiologist said possible viral, ENT said possible nerve damage and fluid behind my ear drum). I just want a reasonable outlook. Thanks
posted_time: Post  by matthan07 » Wed Dec 26, 2007 9:51 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Sudden severe hearing loss. Clogged? Permanent?
content: Hi Matthan07,  Hearing loss can basically be divided into two categories: conductive problems and neurological problems.  Conductive problems include things that are preventing the ear drum/ear bones from moving and conducting sound properly to the nerves.  Neurological problems are those that receive the signal from the ear but do not carry it to the brain.  Conductive problems include fluid behind the ear drum causing the drum to be less mobile.  This often gives a muffled sound, as if the person were underwater.  Given your recent trauma, a broken bone in the middle ear is a possibility although it takes a fair amount of force and the area you got hit is less likely to do this.  Using a decongestant for a few days may help if there is fluid behind the ear.    The amoxicillin/clavulonate will help if there is a bacterial infection causing puss to collect somewhere along the path (usually the middle ear) or if the infection is causing inflammation and not letting things work properly.  This will only help with bacterial infections.  The prednisone will help if there is inflammation from something, including an infection although it will not help get rid of the infection.    Unfortunately, at this point there really isn't a good antiviral medicine.  We have a few that are targeted at specific viruses if the virus is known.  Even these don't work that great and they have some nasty side effects.  This is most likely why you weren't given an antiviral medicine.  I cannot comment on whether or not this is permanent without knowing what the underlying cause is.  If it is viral it will most likely improve as the body fights off the infection.  If this is not improving an MRI may be helpful to get a better look at the middle/inner ear and see if there is any evidence of inflammation that may account for your hearing loss.  I would definitely defer to the ENT specialist about whether this is an appropriate test or not at this point.  Follow up with your ENT doctor is important.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Large tonsils relating to speech in 6yr old
content: Hi Boobear,  Tonsils can be large enough to obstruct the nasal passage (not really the tonsils but the adenoids can do this).  This can give the hyponasal voice.  I am less familiar with enlarged tonsils/adenoids causing dental malocclusion.  You may want to talk with your son's dentist about this.  It would also be reasonable to have your son evaluated by an ear/nose/throat specialist.  Typically, tonsils/adenoids will shrink in size with age but if they are particularly large they may not shrink enough to alleviate symptoms.  Best wishes.

author: Sandy Tracy RN  Nurse Posts: 60 Joined: Wed Nov 07, 2007 6:57 pm
title: Re: Runny nose
content: Hi, ERrutherford  You may be experiencing nonallergic rhinitis.  This can include a runny or stuffy nose all year round.  This usually does not have other allergy syptoms such as an itching nose or throat.  This may cause your nose to run while eating or after eating.  Drinking alcoholic beverages may cause your nose to be stuffed up.  If this is bothersome you can see your doctor and have allergy testing done.  Even if the tests come back negative they may have you try an antihistimine to see if this alleviates the symptoms.  Sometimes oral antihistimines are ineffective in treating nonallergic rhinitis and you may need a prescription nasal spray.  I hope this is helpful and thanks for writing in. Sandy RN

title: Re: Sleepless due to dry nose and Throat congestion
content: You don't indicate where you live but in a dry climate especially, this is a common problem.  Forced air heat in winter adds to the burden.  Add humidity to your room.  You can also use saline nose drops or sprays.  Raise the head of your bed 30 degrees with pillows as well.  As for waking to use the bathroom - sometimes this is habitual when you just get used to always doing it.   But, if it is a bladder issue, try limiting fluid intake after the last meal.  Be sure to drink plenty during waking hours to avoid dehydration.  I know these are sleep disrupters and that affects your whole day.  I wish you well in dealing with this frustrating problem.

author: 7235  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Fri Dec 28, 2007 10:31 am
title: Pistachio Allergy?
content: I am wondering what would make me develop a sudden allergy to pistachios? I have eaten them many times before. I do have an allergy to walnuts (sores on my tongue). But pistachios have never been a problem. I just was curious what causes a person to develop the allergy, when it hasn't been an allergy before? I am 35 years old.
posted_time: Post  by 7235 » Fri Dec 28, 2007 10:38 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Pistachio Allergy?
content: Hi there, A person can develop an allergy at any time - even to substances which have never before been a problem, as in your case.  In fact, most allergies are to something you have had in the past because the nature of allergies is that they are a hypersensitive response to a foreign substance in your body that the system perceives as a threat.  Once you have been exposed to a substance, your body can begin to rebel against it. You may notice this soon after exposure or on a subsequent exposure.  Your system is unable to recognize it as safe for you and has put out barriers against it.  In order to create the "allergy" your body must have been exposed to it once, then it develops the antibody reaction which on another occasion is a problem and you experience the reaction with histamine, etc.    It has to do with your personal immune system which may be weakened for some reason or oversensitive even though in the past it was not.  It is believed that factors such as poor nutrition may contribute to allergies because of the weakened state of your body and immune system.    Nut allergies can be especially dangerous so if you are certain it is the pistachios you reacted to, I would recommend you stay away from them in the future.  If you ever experience breathing difficulties with this allergic reaction you should get to medical help right away.  Some doctors even prescribe a device to be kept with you for such emergencies so you can have instant medication to counteract what could be a serious reaction.   I hope this information is helpful.  Thank you for your question.

author: ghostcheese  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Mon Oct 22, 2007 3:14 am
title: Tinnitis, headache and visual disturbances
content: I'm a 21 year old female.  No serious past diagnoses or past surgeries.  I have had my tonsils taken out however.  I am obese, as is my mother who has high blood pressure, heart problems, and diabetes.  Both my grandmothers have diabetes as well.  I'm not currently on any medications though I'm supposed to be on birth control to regulate my menstrual cycles, but the prescription ran out a couple months ago.  Another thing to note is that I'm on the computer constantly.  I've been plagued by the most annoying thing since last May or so.  Pulsatile tinnitus.  It whooshes in my right ear constantly, though I've learned to ignore it of late.  I had started to feel a bit of a tinge of pain deep in my ear last April, but the doctor I went to at the time said he saw nothing wrong.  The tinnitus developed a month or so later.  I spent the summer doing basically pretty much lazing around so I didn't think hard enough to notice much, except some minor peripheral vision dimming, but when I came back to the university, I noticed that I'm having difficulties concentrating lately.  I've also noticed that I have developed difficulties speaking for extended periods of time, such as when telling a joke or a story.  Strangely, I've noticed that lately I occasionally spell words backwards or invert letters...like typing big as gib.  I also frequently start to do something and forget what I had intended to say or do, but that could just be me being ditzy.  Same goes for occasional dizziness or loss of balance.  I've been sleeping an abnormally long amount of time lately, sometimes twelve to sixteen hours, and no matter what I do I always feel fatigued.  I've been getting headaches often, which isn't unusual for me, but they generally come out of nowhere and lately they've been increasingly on the right side of my forehead in the area around and including the eye.  I usually wait it out since I hate taking medicine, but if it gets to the point where it's debilitating, I take tylenol or ibuprofen and it slowly goes away.  Lately my vision has been what most bothers me.  I have astigmatism and am very nearsighted.  For as long as I remember, I've had visual snow.  I haven't been to the eye doctor in a while, but I can see pretty well with my current prescription.  Lately, however, I will be looking at something and my peripheral vision will dim or seem to swim.  Also, lately changes in light have been throwing me for a loop, or no changes in light actually do the same.  I'll be sitting there doing nothing and all of a sudden my vision will be whitewashed as if someone turned a bright light on.  I've also seen occasional flashes of light when nothing's there.  Occasionally if I walk through a well-lit hallway and lights are shining off of glossy walls or tiles it makes me feel lightheaded as I walk.  Mostly fed up with these vision problems which occur increasingly frequently, I went to the local campus health clinic last Friday and got the same doctor who told me last April that the pain in my ears was nothing.  I proceeded to recount my symptoms to the nurse and then to the doctor when he came in.  He looking in my mouth, eyes, and ears and saw nothing wrong, but gave me Neomycin, Polymyxin B, and Hydrocortisone eardrops anyway and sent me on my merry little way.  I've been using these drops, but nothing has really changed.  Besides feeling absolutely awful tonight.  My head feels "fuzzy"...my eyes are still whitewashing occasionally...and my tinnitus that's usually a soft whoosh was making strange sounds...like a rough rasping sound.  Along with this was a general sense of illness...something just felt...wrong.  As I type this I feel a slight twinge of nausea.  Anyway, should I seek a second opinion or stick with the drops and see if by some miracle they miraculously cure my eyes too?  My insurance is crappy and money is an issue...the health center doctors are free, but if I choose to go elsewhere or am referred to a specialist, there may be bill issues...
posted_time: Post  by ghostcheese » Mon Oct 22, 2007 4:07 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: I would return to the clinic.  Often when a doctor prescribes, he/she is going on a hunch based on symptoms (medicine is a combination of art and science).  Not every condition is clear cut or even verified by labwork, etc. so there is a bit of trial and error involved. Often they start with the least risky or most likely solution.  If that does not help, they must rely on the patient to let them know so they can move to the next step.  They usually have to treat one symptom at a time, when there are multiples, and use one treatment at a time.  That is the only way to know what made the difference.    If you do not return, the doctor will never know that you weren't adequately treated or even cured.  If this does not satisfy you, a second opinion might be worth it.  Good luck.

author: ghostcheese  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Mon Oct 22, 2007 3:14 am
title: Re: Tinnitis, headache and visual disturbances
content: Well, I may as well reply to this to update it.  I returned to that same doctor to no avail.  A week or so later I suddenly developed a headache and a stiff neck.  I again returned to that same doctor several times, and he kept giving me medicines without even running any tests.  At one point he gave me antibiotics even though the one test he did showed no traces of bacteria in my blood.  A week after that, the pain was enough to make me go to the emergency room in my very small town.  They ran lots of test and nothing seemed wrong.  They also did a CT scan, but they said I only had mild chronic sinusitis.  I then asked the doctor if it was possible that I had increased pressure in the brain.  I happen to have a friend who is an assistant to a neurosurgeon, and he suggested that increased ICP was likely what was causing my problems--the headaches, slight fevers, ringing in my ears, visual disturbances, lethargy, etc, etc.  The doctor said that the CT technicians would have seen that if that was the issue, so they just gave me some darvocet and flexeril and sent me on my way.  At this point I could barely sleep because my head felt so...full...and the back of my head was really sore.  Even the slight pressure of the pillow against my head hurt.  Then a couple of days later, I noticed my vision was blurry.  I thought it was a side effect from the medicines they gave me at the emergency room at first, but when my vision continued to grow steadily worse each day despite stopping those medicines, I went back to the doctor once more.  This time he said he wasn't worried since I had had a CT scan the weekend before and suggested I go to a psychologist, thinking I was imagining things.  I asked him what exactly it was that he thought a psychologist could do about my vision and had him send me to an eye doctor to have things checked out.  Turns out, I had papilledema due to increased pressure in the brain, the very thing I asked about in the emergency room.  The eye doctor sent me to a neurologist, but the earliest appointment was four days away, so I continued to lose more and more sight as my vision got blurrier and double.  At the neurologist, I was told that I had something called pseudotumor cerebri and after extensive MRI scans, that I had a blood clot in the back of my brain.  I was sent to an optic nerve eye specialist, at which point I could not even see the chart on the wall due to a large blindspot in my central vision.  Anything I looked at was blotted out by gray, and my field vision test results showed that I could barely see.  It was recommended that I have surgery and get a shunt put into my spine to drain out excess fluid continuously.  It was considered an emergency procedure in order to save what little was left of my sight.  I was told it was possible I wouldn't get any vision improvement, and that it would never be as good as it used to be.  Luckily I've gotten back most of it, though small print/thin fonts are difficult to see.  In addition I believe I have lost a small amount of color perception.  Some colors are hard to distinguish from one another...blue, teal, and green for example, though they were easy to tell apart before.  I go to the eye doctor December 27th and I guess I'll find out how extensive the permanent damage has been.  I've been getting slight high pressure headaches again, so I'll have my neurologist adjust my shunt net time I see her.  Well, there it is.  The long, exhausting ordeal finally ended, and I was able to be diagnosed and my problem dealt with.  I was told my opening pressure when they did a lumbar puncture was very, very high.  I was barely conscious at the time, but I felt much better once they drained off two or three tubes of fluid.

author: dacubster  Guest Posts: 19 Joined: Sat Jan 13, 2007 9:56 pm
title: Chronic Ear Pain
content: Hi there,  I am a 24 year old female with a history of severe asthma, bronchitis, allergies, hyperthyroidism, IST and depression.  My concern is reoccuring ear pain (and throat soreness as well).  Usually this occurs every morning when I wake up.  According to my ENT this is related to allergies.  However, I tend to get ear pain at other times as well which comes and goes and can be quite painful.  In addition I have noticed within the last year that I no longer am able to hear as well.  I need the tv up very loud and have to have people continuously repeat things to me to be able to hear them.  THe ENT did a visual exam and didn't see anything noticeably wrong with me ears.  Could these problems all be associated with the allergies?  And if so are there things to help them?  I am on allergy medicines already but it doesnt seem to clear up the pain in the ears and the pain when I swallow.  I have tried ear drops but they end up burning.  Any advice is appreciated?
posted_time: Post  by dacubster » Mon Dec 10, 2007 11:47 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Chronic Ear Pain
content: Hi Dacubster,  It is possible that your pain is related to allergies.  Since the ENT doctor did not see any problems visually it makes an infection or fluid behind the ear drum much less likely.  It may be that you have Eustachian tube dysfunction that is causing pressure differences between your middle ear (behind the ear drum) and the outside air pressure.  This can cause significant pain at times but more often causes a pressure feeling (like taking off in an airplane).    Allergies relate to this because allergies can cause inflammation of the Eustachian tube causing the tube to swell.  This, in turn, worsens the pressure problems.  Normally, the Eustachian tube will open and close as needed to balance the pressure.  With the inflammation, the tube is swollen and can't function properly.  You may want to talk with your ENT doctor about this possibility.  Sometimes, using a nasal steroid can help reduce inflammation of the Eustachian tube.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Wed Dec 19, 2007 9:45 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: ear feels closed/getting feed back
content: Hi Problems101,  Even though you don't have fluid behind the ear there may be some pressure issues in the ear that are preventing the ear drum from moving properly.  This can occur when the eustachian tube doesn't open and close properly.  Sometimes this is from inflammation of the tube.  There may also be other reasons such as problems with the bony structures of the ear.  I'd recommend you see your ENT doctor again to have this checked out.  Best wishes.

posted_time: Post  by boobear » Sun Dec 16, 2007 11:29 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Need opinion
content: Hi Boobear,  There are few possible things that could be causing this.  First, commonly with disorders in the autism spectrum, such as PDD-NOS, there can be tics that include muscular and vocal tics (such as coughs or throat clearing).  It may also be due to some gastroesophageal reflux irritating the throat.  You may want to discuss trying an anti-reflux medicine to see if this helps.  It may also be helpful to have your son evaluated by a developmental pediatrician if he hasn't been and to discuss the possibilities of this being a tic with them.  If two ENT's feel it isn't related to his throat it is probably not going to be very helpful to see another ENT.  The breathing through his mouth and the need for a tonsillectomy is probably a separate issue that the ENT's would be able to help you develop.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Lost_soul,  Amoxicillin will treat the infection part.  Claritin will treat any allergies you are having.  There are a few over-the-counter medicines that you may get some benefit from.  Guaifenesin is a mycolytic that is reported to thin mucous helping it be cleared.  Medicines such as pseudoephedrine and phenylephrine are decongestants (common brand names Sudafed and Sudafed PE, respectively).  The decongestants may help you but keep in mind that sinusitis causes thick mucous production in the sinuses so it will take a little while (even weeks) for this to resolve.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Thunderdome,  Your symptoms may be from a few things.  You may have an enlarged lymph node causing the pressure.  The lymph nodes can be a bit painful when pressed on if they are enlarged.  There are a few other things that would be a bit less likely but still possible.  One possibility is a cyst from a branchial cleft remnant.  Basically, this is an area present in a baby before they are born that subsequently dissappears.  Occasionally it remains and can cause symptoms such as you are describing.  Most of these will resolve on their own but if one of them gets infected it may need antibiotics to improve.  If your symptoms don't improve I would recommend you see your doctor to have some of these things evaluated for.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Anara,  The tonsils normally have some holes in them (called crypts).  This part probably is normal in your case.  The itching part and bleeding may be due to an infection or possibly allergies.  You may want to try an over-the-counter allergy medicine such as diphenhydramine (Benadryl) or loratidine (Claritin). If it appears you have a bacterial infection you may need antibiotics to help clear it up.  Best wishes.

posted_time: Post  by neala » Fri Dec 07, 2007 12:21 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Neala,  A persistent ear infection could certainly cause a swollen lymph node.  I think it is unlikely that you've had an ear infection for 2 years.  More likely, you had some enlargement of the node at some point due to an infection then the node simply never quite shrunk back down.  This is extremely common.    With antibiotic resistant ear infections, the recommendation for antibiotics is three consecutive days of an injected antibiotic called ceftriaxone.  This antibiotic is able to get very high concentrations in the middle ear and is very effective at clearing the infection.  If this is ineffective, evaluation by an ENT specialist is appropriate.  It may be that you have some inflammation of your eustachian tube causing the fluid in your ear to be trapped.  The ENT specialist can help recommend treatments to help this improve and evaluate the lymph node at the same time.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: It certainly sounds like you have done the pharmacy thing.  I would first try some old-fashioned home remedies if you have not already done so.  Add some humidity to your air - get a good, quiet humidifier and use it at night.  This should help loosen the secretions a bit.  Also, raise your head a bit on the bed by using several pillows.  Use a saline nose spray.  It doesn't need any active ingredients.  Also be sure you get adequate hydration.  If you're not drinking lots of water, this can make it harder too.  Sometimes the medications are drying to the passages and you need that moisture.  If you don't get any relief this way, along with all the drugs you have, you should return to your doctor.     Good luck.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Nelly145,  The tonsils are normally full of pits and bumps.  It may be that you are seeing normal tonsil tissue.  However, it is not usual for one to be significantly different in size.  If this is the case there may be an underlying infection causing an accumulation of pus (an abscess).  The abscess pushes out the tonsil.  If your pain does not improve I would recommend you have this evaluated.    Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Ent,  The area you are describing does fit a lymph node.  Usually, lymph nodes do not cause the tingling feelings you are describing.  It may be that the lymph nodes is a bit scarred causing it not to reduce fully in size (a common occurrence) and is now pressing on a nerve some.  Turning your head may cause more pressure on the nerve increasing the tingling feeling.  I'd recommend you see an ENT doctor to have this checked out.  It may be that the invovled lymph node needs to be removed to help resolve your symptoms.  Best wishes.

title: Adenoids in 15 mo
content: I have a 15 month old son who had his adenoids removed at 10 months due to severe hypertrophy (they were completely blocking his airway).  He has had a severe case of GERD since birth (taking both Prevacid and Zantac), as well as numerous other health problems before surgery and since.  My question is simple:  Is it possible for adenoids to come back after only 5 months in a child so young?  The ENT that removed them said the chances were about 50/50 that they would grow back.  We've since moved and saw another ENT who seemed dismissive as that being a cause of his current illnesses/sleeping issues.  Thanks for your reply.

content: Hi Kimmad,  Adenoids can grow back after removal.  5 months seems a little fast but I'm not certain about this. author: Dr. Tino Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 50 Joined: Fri Aug 18, 2006 12:34 pm Location: UK
title: [no title]
content: Hello there,  Your symptoms are odd, however there may be some possible explanations. First of all we need to establish your overall medical condition. How old are you?  Do you or have you suffered from any medical or surgical problems? Are you experiencing any other symptoms apart from those described? The most important causes to rule out are cardiovascular. If the arteries that exit your heart and run up the left side of your neck are under pressure due to narrowing or stiffness you may experience abnormal pulsations or waveforms into the arterial circulation on that side. This may translate into audible sounds in the left ear due to transmission of pulsations into arteries supplying that area. However it is important to note that your symptoms may be entirely benign and therefore you should not worry too much about it as you will find yourself focusing on it and feeling worse. I suggest you visit your doctor for a full cardiovascular examination and if needs be either he or your ENT surgeon may decide to arrange imaging of the arteries, normally carried out in the form of a MRA(Magnetic Resonance Angiogram) which carries no risk of radiation exposure and allows identification of any vascular malformation. I am not familiar with a case like yours but ruling out any pathological causes will be reassuring. Please let me know of any progress.  Kind Regards,  Dr Tino Solomon BSc(Hons) MBBS Senior House Officer in Surgery

author: Sandy Tracy RN  Nurse Posts: 60 Joined: Wed Nov 07, 2007 6:57 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi, Aimzley       Certain hormonal problems can cause spots on the tongue that are brown in color.  Certain antibiotics and pepto bismol can also cause black spots on the tongue.  How long have these been present?    Another reason can be diet.  If your diet is lacking roughage (fruits and vegetables).  This can be managed by lifestyle changes.  Try increasing the amount of fresh fruits and raw vegetables (celery,apples and carrots) and increasing water intake.    Smoking can also be the cause of the problem.  I encourage you to see a dentist or Healthcare provider to be sure of the cause.  Good Luck Sandy RN

title: Strange was in outer ear
content: I’m a 64 year old male and in good health. I take 12.5mg hrdrochlorot daily, 20mg omeprozole every other day and 325mg aspirin daily.  I used to have normal brown earwax in my ear canals. I use hot water and a wash towel to remove it. However, it always returns, sometimes right away or later in the day or at night when I sleep. Occasionally I go 2 or 3 days before it reappeared.   About 6 weeks ago, I had an asthma attack and my doctor put me on a 16-day regimen of prednisone. However, on the 25th day, 9 days after stopping the prednisone, the brown earwax disappeared and the sticky discharge started again.  My doctor examined my ears and seemed puzzled. She thought perhaps it was some type of skin condition, like psoriasis, and had me use 1% hydrocortisone cream. However, this hasn’t helped.  Should I be concerned or just ignore it as I have no other symptoms? Should I see a specialist and, if so, a dermatologist or ENT?

author: IndigoSensor  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Sun Oct 28, 2007 7:00 pm Gender: Male
title: Olfactory Halucinations
content: Hello,  Hello,  Ok, so for the past 6 months or so I have been having olfactory hallucinations. When I began having them I was confused (and slightly ammused) by this. I usually have about 7 a day or so, and they last anywhere from 5 seconds to 30 seconds. 99% of the time, its something plesent that I smell. Sometimes there very pertucular. Like, I would smell something like a cross between cedar, hot choclate powder, and rain. Like something you would not normally be able to imagine. The majorty of the time though its something normal (sorta). Certian smells I will taste weakly simoltainously, usually a fruit or something citrus. I can usually tell if they are a halucination, but not always. The best way to describe it would be remembering a smell, but its 50x more powerful, and you actually smell it. There really seems to be no rhyme or reason to this. They are always completly random, and have nothing to do with what I am doing or thinking about.  I informed my dad about this and he was concerned. So one thing led to another and I went to several doctors to see what was wrong. At first they thought I had a brain tumor, I had my head scanned and found that I did not have one (thankgod). So after that, they noticed that my (I think its my temporal lobes or somewhere near it) were very asymetrical. So, the doctors hooked me up to an EEG machine to see if I had a form of epilepsy. Turns out I don't, at least they think. The doctor said that nothing might have shown up because I did not have an olfactory halucination durring the test. After talking to me he said I COULD have temporal lobe seziures, but there extremely small. I decided not to take the test over 3 days to find out if I really did because I was leaving for college very soon.  I have not been to an ear, nose, and throat doctor. My dad subjested that I go to it before I left but since it didnt appear to be anything serious, I decided not to. The reason is, because it came up through talking to doctors that I eat very spicy foods, and alot of wasabi. Since I was 10 or so, I loved wasabi and whenever I do eat it with food, I eat it raw, and alot of it. (By the end of dinner I usually will have gone through a tablespoon or more). My dad thinks I "burnt out the inside of my nose" because of this. The doctors I went to said it could be this, but they didnt think so completly.  *Phew* ok, so in a nutshell, what is causing these olfactory hallucinations. Is it brain related, nerve related, or nose related? And generally if someone has some insite to this.  Thanks! Pieter (18 year old male)   Here are some other things: -Asbergers syndrome (It seems to have diminished) -Severe Depression (age 11-12) -Never had sergery (of any kind) -Family history of depression and agoraphobia, general hypersensitivity -Not currentlly medicated (Used to be on citalopram years ago and it exasperated mental problems)
posted_time: Post  by IndigoSensor » Sun Oct 28, 2007 7:07 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Pieter,  Olfactory hallucinations are actually quite interesting.  There are several possible causes.  They are also referred to as dysosmias.  Sinus or nasal infections can cause these.  Even after the infection clears it may take a little while for them to resolve.  Seizures or head trauma can also cause them.  Having the EEG was very appropriate and an normal EEG makes seizures less likely but does not rule them out.    Depression and a few other psychological disorders can also cause these hallucinations.  I would suggest you see a neurologist if this issue is not improving.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Thu Nov 08, 2007 6:44 pm

The pressure around my eyes is making my vision worse, so I have to wear my glasses more often now than I had to, just adding to the pressure on my face. posted_time: Post  by Morgan_P » Mon Oct 22, 2007 12:07 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Morgan_P,  I suspect that what you are feeling is actually a lymph node.  Behind the ear there is a lymph node chain known as the posterior auricular nodes.  They often become enlarged during infections.  Occasionally they may remain somewhat enlarged-about the size you are describing.    My colleague, Dr. Fouad, has written a very good article on lymph nodes that you may find informative.  It can be found here.  If the lump begins to get bigger I would recommend you have your doctor evaluate it.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi WendiLawhorn,  It may be that you have a viral infection.  A few of the viruses can cause gastritis and may worsen underlying reflux.  The viruses can also cause ill feelings and trembling.  If this does not improve in the next day or two, or if it gets worse you should see your doctor to evaluate this.  As a side note, acid reflux, indigestion and heartburn really are all terms that are describing the same process.  Best wishes.

author: Meganeventer  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Oct 27, 2007 9:23 am
title: reoccuring strep
content: Hi.  I've tried researching strep throat online, but everything seems to be related to children or often refers to penicillian which I don't take becuase I had an allergic reactions to amoxicillin/ampicillian when I was a kid.  I am a 23 year old female elementary teacher.  Since Feb. of 2007 I have had 6 positive strep cultures.  I've also noticed a significant increase in the number of migranes I've been getting (prior condition), which I think is linked to the strep.   Before this year, I have not had strep throat since I was 8.  I had symptoms (SEVERE sore throat, fever, etc.) in Feb. (#1)  Then May/June (#2, 3, and 4).  That time the strep came back immediatley after the final drug.  It  took all of June for my lymph nodes in the neck to go back down.  Then in Sept. I got it again (#5).  I went to the ENT doctor the other day and left feeling like we had accomplished nothing.   I took another rapid strep test- this time with no symptoms and it came up positive again!  I am on another antibiotic to "flush out" the bacteria and am going to insisit on being retested when they're done.  The new drug is:  Levaquin.  In the others instances I've taken:  azithromycin, cephalexin, cefuroxime.  Each time I've done everything I could think of to prevent getting it again, washed all sheets and blankets, jackets, bleached glasses, washed counter-tops and changed my tooth brush many times!   My boyfriend has not gotten strep through this whole time period. . .  nor has he had any symptoms.  I told the ENT doctor this and he didn't say anything.  Should my boyfriend be tested too?  Could he be giving it back to me. The doctor suggested getting my tonsils out, I may end up doing this, but I'd like to figure out why I keep getting it in the first place.  The ENT's response was that it was my 1st and 2nd year teaching and I was stressed etc.  However my stress level is much lower than when I was in college and student teaching, so that just doesn't seem to be it to me.  If I do get my tonsils out, I likely won't be able to do it until spring break or this summer, so I need to figure out how to prevent it in the meantime.  I hope this isn't too much information at once.  Any new suggestions would be helpful.
posted_time: Post  by Meganeventer » Sat Oct 27, 2007 9:47 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Meganeventer,  Strep is a confusing bug, especially strep throat.  There are a few things to consider.  1st is that strep really gets a bad rap in that many times when people have a sore throat they get treated for strep throat without the strep actually causing the infection.  There are many viruses that can do this as well.  Symptoms classically are a severe sore throat, fever and NO cough.  Most viruses cause a cough.  It sounds like your first episode certainly had symptoms consistent with strep and it is certainly important to be treated for it.  The biggest reason to treat strep throat is to prevent rheumatic fever and rheumatic heart disease.  In your case, it sounds like you also have tested positive for strep when you were not having symptoms.  This make me think you are a carrier of strep in your throat.  There is a small percentage of people that have the strep bug living in their throat normally without causing infection.  This makes it difficult to tell when the strep is causing the infection and when it is simply there without causing the infection when symptoms are present.  It is important to let your doctors know that you are a strep carrier so that they can decide if strep may be causing your symptoms or if they really don't fit and you don't need treatment.  Given your repeated infections you may want to talk to your doctor about using an antibiotic called clindamycin for a 10 day course to see if you can irradicate the carrier state in your throat.  This is occasionally effective and may prevent the need for a tonsillectomy.  Best wishes.

author: sop22  Guest Posts: 25 Joined: Sat Sep 22, 2007 7:05 am
title: ear syringing and bizare sensation
content: today i have just been to have my ears syringed, i have been putting drops in for a week prior to this and had noticed that when putting drops into my left ear i had a strange sensation that the drops were running through my ear into my eye. i thought nothing of it as it wasnt so strong, however when the nurse came to doing my left ear i nearly jumped out the seat, it was so strong, my eyes would water and i felt lik ethe water in my ear was actually running through my ear and into the corner of my left eye. it was bizare and the nurse couldnt explain it. what would cause this, theres no way that could actually happen is there?
posted_time: Post  by sop22 » Thu Oct 25, 2007 6:50 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Sop22,  This actually is possible in one situation.  Normally, the eardrum separates the outer ear from the middle ear.  The middle ear drains to the nose via the eustachian tube.  In most situation the eardrum would keep the ear drops out of the middle ear and thus out of the nose.  However, if there were a hole in the eardrum (which can happen occasionally from infections or trauma) the drops could enter the middle ear then run down the eustachian tube into the nose.  It may be that you have small hole in your eardrum.  Your doctor can look for this.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Thu Oct 25, 2007 8:11 pm

author: sop22  Guest Posts: 25 Joined: Sat Sep 22, 2007 7:05 am
title: [no title]
content: thank you, this was my eye though not my nose, is that to do with the same tube?
posted_time: Post  by sop22 » Fri Oct 26, 2007 4:11 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: I'm very sorry.  I misread your post.  There are a few possibilities about this as well.  First, the drain from the eye also goes to the nose so the drops may have been running through the ear into the nose and then back into the eye.  This is unlikely but theoretically possible.  More likely, the drops are getting into the nose as previously mentioned then irritating the nose making your eyes water and burn.  If it persists you may want to consider seeing an ophthalmologist or an ear, nose and throat doctor.  Best wishes.

title: Spider In Nose
content: I'm male, 24 years old. I woke up last night to an odd tingling sensation in my nose. I figured it was mucus and went to blow my nose. I blew several times, but the tingling did not stop and there was no mucus on the tissue. I looked up my nose in a mirror and could not see anything. Finally I covered the opposite nostril and blew as hard as I could and a little brownish/yellowish spider shot out on to the floor.  I'm in Colorado Springs, CO and I was sleeping in a bedroom in a finished basement. The room has a large window well, and we're having the first snow of the season. I think the spider was just trying to find a warm place.  I've cleaned out that nostril with saline nasal spray and I've since covered the floor around the bed and window well in insecticide.  The two things I'm concerned about are eggs and bites. It's been 8 hours or so since the incident. My nose feels normal (apart from some minor irritation around the opening of the nostril, I think from all of the itching, blowing, & scratching I've done since the incident.)  I think if he had bit me I would know it by now (some symptoms would have manifested and they haven't), and if he had laid eggs or dropped an eggsack I'd be able to feel them or they would have washed out one of the 20 or so times I've rinsed my nose with nasal spray since then.  Do I have anything to worry about?

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  You are right to suspect that your headaches are a manifestation of a possible sinusitis. However, when sinus type headache has been going on for some time (typically more than 14 days), you may have developed what is known as chronic sinusitis. This has to be confirmed by a CT scan but you may also need to determine what the infective organism is in order to treat it with the proper antibiotic. This is done by performing culture and sensitivity tests on sinus fluid aspirate.  If repeated antibiotic courses fail to treat your condition, other options include nasal glucocorticoid treatment, irrigation or sinus surgery in refractory and severe cases.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Bamagurl35565,  Given your description of a slightly tender, mobile lymph node I would not be particularly suspicious of cancer.  Cancerous lymph nodes are typically fixed (non-mobile), hard and painless.  My colleague, Dr. Fouad, has written a very good article on lymph nodes that you may find helpful.  It is located here.  The lymph node may be enlarged due to some ongoing inflammation in the tonsil.  It may also be that you have a chronic sinusitis that may be causing your lymph node to be enlarged.  I would suggest you follow up with your doctor to explore the possibility of something like chronic sinusitis.  This condition can be treated with antibiotics to help it resolve.  Best wishes.

author: Eurydice  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Sep 08, 2007 10:04 pm
title: Recurring oro-antral fistula
content: Dear Doctor:  Six months ago an endodontist drilled a 10mm hole through my sinus and into the mucosa during an apico on number 14. I went first to an oral surgeon who ordered decongestant spray and antibiotics. He did not know that two weeks on the spray would result in a rebound effect that eventually got me to an ENT, where I complained of ear pain (I had blown my nose while congested and felt material enter the ear). The ENT took a CT scan that confirmed the hole but since sinuses were clear there was no treatment beyond steroids for the rebound. A few months later, with pain at the site of the now extracted tooth, both sinuses and horrible pain in the ear, I saw the same ENT. He entered the room having apparently decided nothing was wrong (I fear in an effort to protect the endodontist, since he and the oral surgeon who referred are friends). Still, he identified white drainage from the gum. Even so, he said my ear pain was likely TMJ and was very dismissive.  Three days later I saw a family physician about the now intolerable ear pain and his sinus x-ray revealed a white mass in the floor of the sinus. A new oral surgeon (in the same office as the first) saw the x-ray and decided to go in, suspecting a growth. He found an oro-antral fistula and performed a collagen-bone graft on one of the two smaller holes, not the 10mm at the apico site. I enjoyed a reduction in sinus pain for a couple of weeks but since ear pain and congestion--especially in eustachian tubes-- increased and I developed a perforated eardrum I had another CT scan with a different ENT, also close to the oral surgeon's office. After using the spray required prior to the scan I felt something small, flat and fairly rigid slide down that side of my throat. I thought it might be part of the bone graft as soon afterward the pain where the fistula had been began to increase and the pain at the floor of the sinus returned. The ENT says there is nothing on the CT scan, not even a hole. He said, "If there was a hole there I would see it." I have all the signs of sinusitis, including two x-rays, but both doctors say the CT is definitive. Both the ENT and the oral surgeon deny any ear problem and perforation as they were diagnosed by a non-ENT.  I'm sorry this is so long but it's been a long event and we're unsure as to next steps. The oral surgeon says an ENT must find something and the ENT says to have the oral surgeon fix the fistula. I've read a review online of 27 articles on the treatment of oral-antral fistula and it does not mention a bone graft. The oral surgeon is considered he best in our area yet he told me not to get my information online. I'm stopping antibiotics today (with oral surgeon's approval) to let symptoms progress to the point that they're undeniable, but I'm unsure where to present them. Is bone graft an accepted treatment for oro-antral fistula? If not, should I see an oral surgeon or an ENT to determine if one of the other treatments are needed? Thanks so much for your kind consideration.
posted_time: Post  by Eurydice » Sat Sep 08, 2007 10:45 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Eurydice,  I'm afraid I won't be able to be of much help to you as I'm not familiar with this type of a problem nor its treatment.  I would add that your ear pain may actually be referred pain from a sinus or dental problem.  This is a very common cause of severe ear pain when the ear itself appears normal.  A perforation of the tympanic membrane is signaled by fluid leaking from the ear.  If you had this you almost certainly had a perforation.  These can heal spontaneously and may no longer be evident.  I would think that seeing an ENT doctor would be the best place for you although an oral surgeon is likely just as qualified.  Sorry I can't be of more help.  Best wishes.

title: wisdom tooth eruption taste

The right wisdom tooth has already erupted with no problems and the left one is just starting to erupt but I have noticed a werid taste that seems to come from the back of my throat when I exhale through my nose. Is it possible that the wisdom tooth could be causing this taste and possible bad breath even though there is no pain or inflammation associated with it?
posted_time: Post  by wazzagal » Sat Sep 22, 2007 3:54 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Wazzagal,  It is possible that the wisdom teeth are responsible for this but I think it is unlikely.  I would recommend you see your dentist for an evaluation.  Sometimes these types of things are due to a dental infection.    A frequent cause of this is accumulation of bacteria and plaque on the back of the tongue.  Using a strong mouthwash consistently can help prevent/treat this.  Your dentist will likely be able to examine you and help determine what may be the cause of your symptoms.  Best wishes.

I was just wondering what these symptoms could possibly be a result of. I've seen my Doctor and he gave me an anti-inflammatory, MethylPREDNIsolone, which SLIGHTLY reduced the redness and inflammation, but did not make the small bump or pronounced "vein" go away. Also, after the drug reduced the swelling in my right tonsil, the bottom of the tonsil appears more bulbous than the rest of it.  I really want to know what is wrong with me. author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Kwikness,  There are a few possibilities that I can think of off hand.  First is that you may have a viral infection that is carrying a prolonged course (such as EBV). posted_time: Post  by wg125 » Sat Aug 18, 2007 8:28 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Wg125,  There are a few possible things that may be causing your ongoing runny nose.  It may be that you now have a chronic sinusitis that needs some antibiotics for about 3 weeks to help clear up.  It may also be that you have some allergies contributing to the runny nose.  Usually a good physical examination and history can help distinguish between the two.  A simple home test for allergies is to try taking an over-the-counter allergy medicine such as diphenhydramine (Benadryl) or loratidine (Claritin).  If this helps a lot it is probably allergies.  If it doesn't help at all it is less likely to be allergies.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Ned,  With the acid taste it is very likely that you are experiencing gastroesophageal reflux, even if you are not having classic indigestion symptoms.  I would recommend you try a daily controller medicine, such as famotidine.  There are a few of these medicines available over-the-counter. author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Rdh4494,  Strep throat can cause abdominal pain in adults as well.  Typically, strep causes a very severe sore throat and fever without a significant cough. author: bijou9  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sat Sep 08, 2007 6:04 pm
title: Hay fever symptoms- tight throat?
content: Hello, I'm a 22-year-old white female in the midwestern US.  I was living in southern Japan over the summer (very hot and humid) and recently moved back to the Great Lakes area.  Soon after moving back, I developed a very tight throat near the back of my mouth(back of tongue and/or tonsil area), and post-nasal drip.  I started to lose my voice and had the sniffles and went to an urgent care center, where they diagnosed me with hay fever.  The doctor gave me Rhinocort Aqua and Claritin-D 24.  I took the Claritin for 2 days then stopped because it dried me out so much, took the Rhinocort for about 5 days and started feeling better, so I stopped taking it.  About 4-5 days after stopping it, the throat tightness and post-nasal drip came back, so I started taking it again.  I've now been taking it for about 12 days, and while the post-nasal drip has disappeared, my throat still feels tight.  Is this a normal symptom of hay fever?  I took some Benadryl Allergy and it seemed to help a bit, but the OTC allergy meds I see don't describe "tight/swollen throat" as an allergy symptom.  Is there anything else I can do to relieve this?  It gets so bad that I don't feel like doing anything.  It used to go away a bit when I ate, but now not as much (although it's not as severe now as before).  Is it really a symptom of hay fever, or something else?  It really worries me.  Both of my parents have hay fever/seasonal allergies, as does my brother.  However, none of them get the tight throat feeling like me.  I never had my tonsils out, but my doctor said they had pretty much disappeared just with age.  I know that I am sensitive to cigarette smoke and heavy dust (such as being near a cat box that has just been changed), but other than that I have never had seasonal allergies.  I usually spend a lot of time camping and being outdoors, so I really would like to clear this up or find out more about it as it has changed my lifestyle drastically :(    I'd really appreciate any insight.
posted_time: Post  by bijou9 » Sat Sep 08, 2007 6:14 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Tightness of throat can definitely go along with allergies.  If you have difficulty breathing you should contact a doctor right away or call for emergency help.  Taking antihistamines should help this type of allergic reaction.  People vary so much with their responses to allergens and we even change over time, becoming sensitive one day to something that never bothered us before.  Good luck.

author: krobbin  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Aug 19, 2007 10:54 am
title: Chronic sore throat for over 4yrs
content: My normally healthy husband (age 29) has been suffering with a chronic irritating feeling at the in his throat (near the base of his neck) ever since he visited the Ukraine over 4 years ago.  He was vaccinated for prior to his trip.  He has visited many ENT's and allergy specialists over the years.  Symptoms 1) Random coughing fits 3-4 times a week (non-productive)  2) Hurts more in the morning and after hockey 3) He feels that chronic pain in his groin, neck and back are related somehow 4) Enlarged tonsil on one side, occasionally white matter found on it (doesn't smell)  "Treatments/Diagnostics" 1) Head & neck CT scan - all clear 2) Upper endoscopy revealed inflammed spot - biopsy negative for cancer but found H. pylori - antibiotics were Rx'd but no improvement 3) Allergy tests - positive for many things, but no help from singulair or nasacort (after 1-2months) 4) Numerous blood tests for infections came back negative (except for Herpes Simplex 1 which I know is common) 5) 2 Dr's suspected GERD and he took nexium (2005) & later prilosec (2007) for a few months, no help there 6) He has tried OTC allergy meds, throat lozengers, hot tea - nothing works!  He is still hoping to have a bronoscopy and is waiting to meet with a Pulminologist. It's really beginning to affect his mental state and behavoir.  Does he simply need to try the treatments longer or what?  Any thoughts?     Worried Wife
posted_time: Post  by krobbin » Sun Aug 19, 2007 11:14 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Worried Wife,  My first thought was reflux; however, it sounds as if he has had an appropriate treatment for this without response.  If reflux is still being considered a study called a 24 hour pH probe may be helpful.  This is where a pH probe is placed in the esophagus for 24 hours.  During this time it measures how often the pH drops indicating stomach acid has refluxed into the esophagus.  Occasionally, severe reflux does not fully respond to medications and a surgery called a fundoplication can be very helpful.  A bronchoscopy is probably also appropriate to get a better look at what is going on in the airway. The bronch can also give good information about reflux and many other things.  Persistence is key.  Usually, the answer is finally found.  I cannot link the groin, neck and back pain together with the cough.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Fri Sep 07, 2007 3:19 pm

author: Jaime  Guest Posts: 8 Joined: Sun Aug 12, 2007 10:36 pm
title: Wierd Sensation in the right ear
content: Hi, I am seventeen years old, relatively physically healthy.  I've never had any surgeries, haven't had any serious illnesses, etc.  My question is that for a while now, I am sensing that my right ear feels different from my left.  I feel almost like there is a sort of heaviness inside of it.  Sometimes, when I swish my mouth with listerine, my ear will actually let out water or something, as if it had been clogged.  The problem is that it always feels like this.  When it lets out a little water, I can actually a bit of relief, but after a while it reverts back to normal.  Can somebody help me out here?  what exactly is going on.  Also, I have been checked for ear infections in the past, and its always been negative.
posted_time: Post  by Jaime » Mon Aug 13, 2007 10:09 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Jaime,  It sounds as if you may have some Eustachian tube dysfunction.  This is when the tube doesn't open and close normally.  When this happens the pressure in the ear doesn't balance properly and can cause pain or full feelings (like taking off/landing in an airplane).  It can also trap fluid in the middle ear causing a chronic effusion.  I would recommend you ask your doctor to look for any evidence of fluid in the middle ear and to test the pressures if able.  You may also want to see an Ear, Nose and Throat specialist.  Sometimes this condition is due to inflammation of the Eustachian tube that can be treated with a temporary use of a nasal steroid.  Best wishes.

author: Lauren Belle  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Mon Sep 03, 2007 6:12 am
title: possible GERD - lump in throat
content: hi,  i have noticed in the past month or so that i have a feeling of a lump stuck in my throat, usually in the morning or late at night. i also have mucus sticking in my throat frequently which causes me to cough, and i dry cough intermittently. at first i attributed this to remnants of a winter cold but it has been months since i had a cold and it still hasnt gone away. recently i have also been getting heartburn or feeling unwell after eating, sometimes even nauseous. before i go to bed some nights i also feel like my throat is swollen as though i am getting tonsilitis, but by the morning it is fine.  i researched some symptoms online and think it may be possible i have GERD? however when i was three months old (im 23 now) i had reflux surgery. im not sure of the exact problem but i do remember my parents telling me my spleen was wrapped around my esophagus to fix it and i have an inability to vomit easily and a large abdominal scar to show for it! it seems like this kind of surgery is sometimes given to people to fix GERD - so should this prevent me from having it?   i am also a light smoker.
posted_time: Post  by Lauren Belle » Mon Sep 03, 2007 6:24 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Lauren Belle,  The surgery you had is called a fundoplication.  It is when part of the stomach is wrapped around the esophagus to tighten the lower esophageal sphincter and reduce or prevent reflux.  This surgery is generally quite effective but it can come loose occasionally.  If you still have the inability to vomit it is likely still intact but it may be worth investigating this.  It may be worth trying an antacid medication for a little while to see if this improves your symptoms.  Reflux is certainly a common cause of an irritated throat and cough.  If your symptoms persist you may want to see a GI specialist.  There are a few other conditions that can cause these feelings, such as eosinophilic esophagitis.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Mon Sep 03, 2007 6:38 pm
